fLOORCRAfT <floorcraft@hossfest.com> wrote:Subject: FREEFORM>>> THIS FRIDAY <<>>

Hello lovely ones,


This Friday is a BIG, BIG night! Why? Not only is it FREEFORM, but it is the 6th month anniversary of FREEFORM! Woo-hoo! So far, we have lasted longer than lots of parties, and most marriages ;)


So, how are we going to celebrate our anniversary? The same way we do every month: Fat beats and a killer vibe! Although, this time, we promise to have the turntable working properly :) I do have to say, it was kinda nice playing my records out from start to finish.


Anyway, back to the nitty gritty. This month is super special because we have Spundae resident and SF legend, TAJ (nothing more needs to said here), and dj extraordinaire, Calamity Jane. She plays some sick ass breaks and tech. Watch what she does with the mixer. Mean, mean stuff! Please try to arrive early this night, because she will be playing the opening set.




Here are the details and the flyer. See you there and feel free to pass this on.

X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 6.0.3.0
Date: Mon, 05 Apr 2004 18:42:47 -0700

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_6607110==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Rocktronica shines through Crystal Method's prism

--=====================_6607110==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Rocktronica shines through Crystal Method's prism
By Dave Wedge, Boston Herald
Monday, April 5, 2004

Count Ken Jordan of the Crystal Method among those who won't be casting a 
vote for George Bush in the upcoming election. But it isn't because of 
rising unemployment, health-care woes or the increasingly bloody war in Iraq.

      It's because, he says, the president killed the rave scene.

      ``The whole thing with the Bush administration and the (anti-rave 
legislation) had a chilling effect,'' Jordan said. ``It's made (promoters) 
afraid to do big shows and big raves. That's been terrible for (the scene).''

      Hatched in Los Angeles in the mid-1990s, the Crystal Method came up 
playing renegade warehouse parties and un-permitted massives, but it all 
came to a crashing halt in the late 1990s when the government, reacting to 
a spate of club-drug deaths, cracked down on raves. Gone now are the days 
of gargantuan underground bashes in rural fields and secluded metal 
buildings, replaced by corporate-sponsored package tours and club dates.

      ``Everything is super-legitimate now, in big clubs. Nothing really 
has an underground feel to it anymore,'' Jordan continued. ``Some parts of 
that are good, but the underground has to thrive, or overall (the scene) is 
really going to be hurting.''

      The Crystal Method has pressed on despite a fickle music industry 
that boldly touted electronic music as ``the next big thing,'' only to 
write its obituary just as quickly. Jordan and his partner-in-crime, Scott 
Kirkland, bring their ``Legion of Boom'' tour to Boston's Avalon on Tuesday.

      ``We'd rather not be in any category,'' Jordan explained during a 
recent phone interview from Myrtle Beach, S.C. ``We always sound like 
ourselves. Our sound sort of changes over time. We like to make Crystal 
Method tracks but we don't get caught up in subgenres. It's all music to us.''

      Live, the pair are like mad scientists, unleashing their signature 
big beat sound from behind a wall of keyboards, samplers, turntables and 
other digital weapons. Last month, the pair cleaned up at the Dancestar 
Music Awards at the Miami Winter Music Conference - electronic music's 
equivalent of the Grammys - taking home best act, best single and best 
album for ``Legion of Boom.''

      Like its Brit brethren the Chemical Brothers and the Prodigy, the 
Crystal Method walk a fine line between dance and alternative rock, equally 
inspiring break dancers and dwellers of the mosh pit. ``Legion of Boom'' 
also dabbles in hip-hop, with two cameos by rapper Rahzel of the Roots.

      ``We've always sort of wanted to be in with all the other acts that 
are on normal modern rock radio,'' Jordan said, naming Foo Fighters among 
the band's prime influences. ``We're sort of underground, sort of a dance 
act, but we're also sort of an alternative rock band.''

      The band's so-called ``rocktronica'' formula is on full display on 
the massive ``Weapons of Mass Distortion'' and ``Born Too Slow,'' both of 
which prominently feature the gigantic guitar work of ex-Limp Bizkit axman 
Wes Borland. Jordan and Kirkland laid the groundwork for the collaboration 
back in 1999, when Limp Bizkit and the Crystal Method were on the Family 
Values Tour.

      ``We're just trying to make cool music and whole albums,'' Jordan 
said. ``The main thing we're looking for is emotion. We're looking for that 
sound that gives us goosebumps.''

http://theedge.bostonherald.com/musicNews/view.bg?articleid=828




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_6607110==.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Canada: Downloading MP3's Not Copyright Infringement

http://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/ap/20040401/ap_en_mu/canada_music_swapping_2


TORONTO - A Canadian federal court ruled Wednesday (April 3) against a
motion that would have let the music industry begin suing individuals who
share copyright music on the Internet.


Justice Konrad von Finckenstein ruled that the Canadian Recording Industry
Association did not prove copyright infringement by 29 "music uploaders."


He said downloading a song or making files available in shared
directories, as facilitated by the popular "peer-to-peer" Kazaa service,
does not constitute copyright infringement under Canadian law.


"No evidence was presented that the alleged infringers either distributed
or authorized the reproduction of sound recordings," von Finckenstein
wrote. "They merely placed personal copies into their shared directories
which were accessible by other computer users via a P2P service."


He compared the action to a photocopy machine in a library. "I cannot see
a real difference between a library that places a photocopy machine in a
room full of copyrighted material and a computer user that places a
personal copy on a shared directory linked to a P2P service," he said.


The recording industry has argued that it, and likewise artists, have
suffered billions of dollars in lost revenue as tens of millions of people
have turned the Internet into a music-swapping bazaar.


In the United States, the Recording Industry Association of America has
launched almost 2,000 lawsuits against file swappers since last year. The
RIAA has settled some 400 cases, generally for a few thousand dollars
each.


The Canadian ruling is similar to a U.S. court setback for the recording
industry in its campaign of legal intimidation to discourage online
file-swapping. In December, a U.S. appeals court ruled that the industry
can't force Internet providers to identify file-swappers unless they first
file a lawsuit.


Just as that made the process of identifying defendants more cumbersome,
so does the Canadian judge's decision.


The Canadian Recording Industry Association took five Internet service
providers, including Bell Canada, Rogers Cable and Shaw Communications, to
Federal Court last month, trying to force the companies to hand over the
names and addresses of 29 people who allegedly shared hundreds of songs
with others last November and December.


The individuals are currently identifiable only through a numeric Internet
address and user handles, and the association can't begin civil litigation
the alleged offenders are identified.


The judge's denial of the recording industry's request means Internet
providers won't have to divulge their client list.


The Canadian Recording Industry Association's lawyer said the group
expected to appeal and said Canadian law needs to be altered to reflect
technological change.


"In our view, the copyright law in Canada does not allow people to put
hundreds or thousands of music files on the Internet for copying,
transmission and distribution to millions of strangers," said attorney
Richard Pfohl.


University of Ottawa professor Michael Geist, who specializes in Internet
and e-commerce law, anticipates the decision will push the industry to
increase its lobbying efforts for copyright reform.

Subject: [sfraves] Digital music: what’s in store?

--=====================_488913==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Digital music: what's in store?

By Jonny Evans

The music piracy debate has intensified once again, following controversial 
court decisions and a report released last week by Harvard Business School, 
and industry trends suggest the music business may eventually be forced to 
change.

The <http://www.macworld.co.uk/news/main_news.cfm?NewsID=8303>Harvard 
report disputes record industry claims that file-sharing has impacted 
against sales; calling the impact of file sharing "statistically 
insignificant". It suggests that competing entertainment formats; economic 
worries; limited breadth of music releases and the end of the vinyl to CD 
upgrade cycle have had more impact against music sales than file sharing.

The Canadian high court last week declared that music fans downloading 
songs using peer-to-peer services are 
<http://www.macworld.co.uk/news/main_news.cfm?NewsID=8332>not breaking 
local copyright law; and a Florida court also last week 
<http://www.macworld.co.uk/news/main_news.cfm?NewsID=8356>denied music 
labels attempt to extract personal information about file sharers from a 
local ISP. The Canadian decision is subject to change.

These revelations arrive as the music business prepares to extend its legal 
action against file-sharers internationally.

Commenting on the Harvard report, International Federation of Phonographic 
Industries (IFPI) chairman and CEO Jay Berman told 
<http://www.guardian.co.uk/online/story/0,3605,1185973,00.html>The 
Guardian: "If I listened to that study my business would have improved."

It appears the music industry remains blinkered to the Harvard researchers' 
alternative explanations for falling music sales, preferring to continue 
its tactic of demonizing file sharers as the business attempts to maintain 
its grip on the means of music production and distribution.

P2P United chair Wayne Rosso counters: "The recording industry is so 
completely misguided in its use of fear tactics that it can only engender 
even more contempt from fans. And what's even more ridiculous is that 
they're all profitable and their business is up, in part due to the free 
marketing they get from P2P networks. They should be paying us!"

Europe is ripe for digital music sales. Online music service OD2 
<http://www.macworld.co.uk/news/main_news.cfm?NewsID=8337>sold one million 
tracks in Europe in the first quarter of this year. Support for licensed 
music-download services are an essential element to the music labels' 
strategic plan for dealing with digital music – litigation without a viable 
legal alternative can only be counter-productive. Berman observed: "I want 
iTunes, Real and Napster here as soon as possible. I'm trying more than 
ever for a licence on behalf of all these services."

Leave me alone

However, artists and music fans are increasingly vexed by the music label's 
litigious tactics. And this is creating an interesting phenomenon. Artists 
are going it alone online.

Blur drummer Dave Rowntree is furious at music industry plans to litigate 
music fans, telling New Media Age: "It's preposterous". And the 
professional musician is not convinced that file-sharing music fans buy 
fewer records. "How do they know?" he asked.

Musicians are turning to the Internet in an attempt to create an 
alternative ways to make a living than working with the established music 
business, and since that business is built on artists' talent, it appears 
that its control of the means of production may be under attack.

George Michael last month 
<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/3499534.stm>announced plans 
to dump the music business, promising never to make another album for 
retail sale. Michael will instead make future releases available online to 
fans in exchange for charitable donations.

Explaining this decision, he said it would take him out of the music 
industry mechanism, which requires artists create new song collections 
every "so many" years, "which nearly killed me," he said.

Music-business contracts commit artists to certain release cycles. For 
example, a musician can have created a collection of songs across many 
years before winning a record deal. They then find themselves committed to 
a gruelling touring cycle, and to a record release every year.

This creates the phenomenon of the difficult second album, as artists 
attempt to manage more fame and commitments while struggling to find the 
inspiration to create new music in order to fulfill their contract. 
Commercial realities can arguably transform artists into musical battery 
hens, and dampen the quality of their art.

Thank you for the music

In recent weeks, both Metallica – renowned for their litigation against 
Napster – and The Bare Naked Ladies have begun their own experiments with 
digital distribution – experiments that could lead musicians toward 
more-autonomous futures.

While both remain committed to their existing labels, the acts are making 
MP3s of their live shows available from their Web sites for sale to fans.

Metallica's unedited soundboard recordings cost $9.95 as MP3s and 
<http://www.livemetallica.com/>are available here. The band is also making 
FLAC (an alternative higher-quality digital music file format) downloads 
available for $12.95. Downloadable CD labels – including tray and front 
cover inserts are also supplied, along with special booklets. The band is 
currently engaged on a mammoth North American tour, and each gig is made 
available within days of its taking place.

Bare Naked Ladies are offering recordings from up to 80 per cent of their 
shows for download, as MP3s with cover art ($13.99), or on CD ($20). The 
band sold over 35,000 songs in the first week of the experiment, with 
downloads outselling physical CDs by two-to-one, reports claim. While 
existing label Warner takes a slice of those sales, the band gets three 
times the royalties it accrues from studio albums.

These actions show that established musicians are already in position to 
make a profit online.

BPI representative Steve Redmond said the Metallica and Bare Naked Ladies 
actions show what can be done using the Internet for copyright holders: 
"This is bands profiting from their own copyrighted music."

He added: "Some people have come up with the idea that the music business 
is against the Internet. That's absolutely not true. But artists still need 
to be paid for what they do."

Culture shock at the power exchange

Other recent innovations from the creative community hint at future 
developments in music. The recent story of the 
<http://www.wired.com/news/digiwood/0,1412,62372,00.html>Grey Album shows 
how the Internet fundamentally changes music distribution and control.

The Grey Album in brief: DJ Danger Mouse remixed the vocals from Jay-Z's 
The Black Album and the Beatles' White Album and called his creation The 
Grey Album. He sent about 3,000 promos out, until EMI told him to stop. 
However, Internet activists continue to make the Grey Album available online.

The Beatles and Metallica pop-up once again in another recent online 
happening, Beatallica, a pair of anonymous musicians who play Beatles songs 
in the style of Metallica.

The songs are made available free, and the musicians concerned hope to 
avoid legal action from Metallica or Beatles lawyers by remaining 
anonymous. It appears popular – since the release of the second album last 
week the official site has run out of bandwidth.

Break on through

Is it possible we are seeing the creation of a 'third estate' for music, 
opening the doors to new creative expression accompanied by a need to 
create new economic models. EMI's move to 
<http://www.macworld.co.uk/news/main_news.cfm?NewsID=8324>axe 1,500 jobs 
last week shows change is in the air. The company intends further focusing 
itself on a smaller roster of large artists.

Existing legal music download services are experimenting with the new 
territory. Apple's iTunes Music Store, for instance, has begun selling 
exclusive live shows – some recorded at Apple's own retail stores. The 
company is also offering pre-release tracks, for example from popular US 
novelty act <http://biz.yahoo.com/prnews/040322/nym103_1.html>William Hung.

The music business is reluctantly going through growing pains, as artists, 
consumers and the business itself renegotiate its business proposition, and 
the labels attempt to cling to control.

As Karl Marx once wrote: "Wherever a part of society possesses a monopoly 
of the means of production, the labourer must add to the working-time 
necessary for his own maintenance an extra working-time in order to produce 
the means of subsistence for the owners of the means of production."

<http://www.macworld.co.uk/news/main_news.cfm?NewsID=8365>http://www.macworld.co.uk/news/main_news.cfm?NewsID=8365



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

when i dance at the party i get looks & stares
they're looking at me but there's nobody there
i move to the sound of chirps blips and glitches
my limbs seem to disapear then reapear, twitches
i vibrate to beats that are too fast for effect
then pause to the silence like a nervous insect
never an arrogant smile for a dance move well done
not one nerv of pride because i have none
anxiety flows through my bones like a circut
i can hit every beat of the sound how i work it
i count up to zero and become one with the void
my soul is binary like a tribal android...

--part1_15f.2dd278bc.2da45a26_boundary--

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Politician-Speak Translated

"In our time, political speech and writing are largely the defense of
the indefensible... Thus, political language has to consist largely of
euphemism, question-begging, and sheer cloudy vagueness... Political
language [is] designed to make lies sound truthful and murder
respectable."

-- George Orwell, "Politics and the English Language," 1945. 

***********************************************************************

Politician-Speak Translated
by former Libertarian Party News editor Bill Winter

Libertarians have long pointed out that when politicians talk about
"cuts" in government spending, they usually don't mean an actual
decrease, as understood by (non-politician) human beings. Instead,
they mean that government spending won't increase quite as fast as
they hoped it would.

This creative use of English was brought into sharp focus in a March 1
article in USA Today. The article noted that last year, government
experts widely predicted that a downturn in tax revenues would force
states to cut 1 million people from Medicaid rolls. In fact, USA Today
reported, enrollment in the government-subsidized health insurance
program *rose* by 1.6 million in 2003.

So, how did a "cut" turn out to be a huge increase? Stephen Heffler,
an economist (and federal employee) at the Centers for Medicare and
Medicaid Services, took a stab at explaining it.

Said Heffler: "Sometimes people get confused when they hear the word
'cut,' and they think there is an actual reduction in spending or
enrollment."

Well, that explains things. Let's see if we've got this right: When a
politician promises an "increase" in government spending or a
government program, he really means an increase. When he says it will
remain "stable," he really means an increase. And when he threatens a
"cut," he really means an increase.

Thanks, Mr. Heffler! We're not confused anymore.

* * *

(Sources: USA TODAY:
http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2004-03-01-medicaid-rolls_x.htm ;
Commentary for Liberator Online by Bill Winter)

* * *

Subject: Re: [sfraves] email viruses from sfr peeps?

yknow

a lil while ago, I was getting emails to my normally used @hard-grooves.com
email accounts, from "management" & administration@hard-grooves.com saying
that I need to follow this link (that looks like it'll go to my site but
doesn't) to read the rest of the message. I was getting several of those,
and it even had my actual web address, but the management and admin
addresses don't exist.
now, I'm getting defaulted emails (anything to hard-grooves.com comes to me
if there isn't an address with that name) sent to those administration, and
management email addresses with lots of other viruses, saying things in the
body of the message like
+++something something Virus protection
+++virus free

makes me wonder who has access to fraudulent emails, that is sending other
fraudulent emails. . .

and just today, like out of 40 messages there were 6-7 viruses, mostly all
to my ak addy thats just subbed to these lists. . .

I think I pissed off a indonesian credit fraud group. . . kinda did it on
purpose tho. . .


: )

aK

Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
Message-ID: <BAY9-DAV32cGT07FTMW000277d3@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 07 Apr 2004 00:19:37.0581 (UTC) FILETIME=[02E859D0:01C41C36]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] email viruses from sfr peeps?

someone like osby (sorry dood - you've had some issues with this before)
that has just about everyone on this list in his address book is infected.
The virus randomly takes the contacts from the user's addy book and then
emails you with an attachment that's viral. If you open it, and don't have
Norton, or the like, running you start sending out emails the same way.

It's very annoying that people out there can't be smart enough to have an
anti-virus application running to prevent such things from occuring. An
annoyance on par with spammers.

:: r ::

--=====================_3687702==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

http://www.gopusa.com/news/2004/april/0406_souder_jennings_ecstasy.shtml

House Anti-Narcotics Chairman Reacts Strongly to Ecstasy Promotion by ABC, 
Jennings
By Jimmy Moore
Talon News
April 6, 2004

WASHINGTON (Talon News) -- Rep. Mark Souder (R-IN), the House 
anti-narcotics chairman, reacted strongly to the
reporting on an illegal drug by ABC News anchorman Peter Jennings.

Souder responded to comments he read in the Palm Beach Post by Jennings 
last week regarding the popular mind-
altering drug Ecstasy.

Jennings said he was concerned that claims by the U.S. government that 
Ecstasy is unsafe are exaggerated, causing
young people to question any information provided in the future.

"Government is best when government is most honest, especially for the 
younger generation, which is more susceptible
to trying drugs," Jennings remarked to the Palm Beach Post. "If they can't 
rely on the government for good and
honest information, then government has lost something enormously valuable, 
which is people's belief in the
government's credibility."

In a one-hour news special that aired last Thursday called "Peter Jennings 
Reporting: Ecstasy Rising," Jennings
examined the government's futile record for slowing the distribution of the 
pills.

"This was an opportunity for us to look at whether or not the government 
isn't its own worst enemy in trying to
control illegal drugs," Jennings explained to the Palm Beach Post regarding 
the show.

Promoting the benefits of Ecstasy rather than the dangers in his show, 
Jennings said he is not concerned at all that
this will pique the interest of young people to try the illegal drug.

"It can't be a concern," Jennings said regarding young people wanting to 
try Ecstasy. "Our job is to lay out the
facts."

Souder said he could not believe a well-known news anchor like Jennings 
would make such comments about a drug that
has been banned in the United States since 1985.

"I'm outraged by the irresponsible comments that [Jennings] made in advance 
of its airing," Souder exclaimed. "Their
appalling nature does not leave me optimistic about the veracity and good 
intentions of the 'production' he's
touting."

Using his experience dealing with anti-narcotics issues in Congress, Souder 
said the research conducted by Jennings
and ABC is severely flawed.

"Jennings exposes a great deal about his own selective research methods 
when he claims that the government's
'science was not good,'" Souder states. "Countless studies have proven that 
Ecstasy is far from a benign drug."

He added, "[R]eams of evidence demonstrate that Ecstasy causes brain damage 
and even death."

As for the carefree manner that Jennings conducted this program, Souder 
said the lack of a moral compass by the ABC
news anchor is especially disturbing.

"If Jennings' nonchalant comments about this dangerous drug are indicative 
of the outlook of his 'special,' then he
is misleading his viewers," Souder remarked. "To make matters worse, 
Jennings appears to have no moral qualms about
offering the American public what the Palm Beach Post cast as 'a glossy, 
late-night infomercial.'"

Questioning the motives of Jennings' reporting of this story, Souder said 
Jennings needed to look into the subject
further.

"Jennings somehow believes that his take on Ecstasy is tantamount to 
'lay[ing] out the facts.' But how much does
Jennings actually know about the facts?," Souder commented.

Providing an example of how Ecstasy has caused harm, Souder challenged 
Jennings to show the whole truth about the
negative effects of Ecstasy to complete his story.

"In 2002, I heard testimony from the mother of 23-year-old Kelley Baker who 
died of an Ecstasy overdose," Souder
noted. "Will Jennings' 'special' offer the facts about Ecstasy's effects on 
her young life?"

Copyright © 2004 Talon News -- All rights reserved.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

From: Dan Haskovec <dan@pry.com>
To: innocentchild <innocentchild@hotmail.com>
cc:  <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-DAV32cGT07FTMW000277d3@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0404061805330.777-100000@charm>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] email viruses from sfr peeps?

It's not enough to have an anti-virus program running. There are new
variants of these viruses coming out faster than then anti-virus vendors
can keep up. It usually takes a day or more for the vendors to update
their virus database, and in that time period you're vulnerable to the new
virus. The bottom line is, don't run any attachments, especially if you're
on windows. Even if the return address is someone you know. Even if it
claims to be from your system administrator. Even if it says that it's
"scanned virus free". Just don't do it.


On Tue, 6 Apr 2004, innocentchild wrote:

> someone like osby (sorry dood - you've had some issues with this before)
> that has just about everyone on this list in his address book is infected.
> The virus randomly takes the contacts from the user's addy book and then
> emails you with an attachment that's viral. If you open it, and don't have
> Norton, or the like, running you start sending out emails the same way.
>
> It's very annoying that people out there can't be smart enough to have an
> anti-virus application running to prevent such things from occuring. An
> annoyance on par with spammers.
>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] email viruses from sfr peeps?

-----Original Message-----
From: Dan Haskovec [mailto:dan@pry.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, April 06, 2004 6:09 PM
To: innocentchild
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] email viruses from sfr peeps?

It's not enough to have an anti-virus program running. There are new
variants of these viruses coming out faster than then anti-virus vendors
can keep up. It usually takes a day or more for the vendors to update
their virus database, and in that time period you're vulnerable to the
new
virus. The bottom line is, don't run any attachments, especially if
you're
on windows. Even if the return address is someone you know. Even if it
claims to be from your system administrator. Even if it says that it's
"scanned virus free". Just don't do it.


On Tue, 6 Apr 2004, innocentchild wrote:

> someone like osby (sorry dood - you've had some issues with this
before)
> that has just about everyone on this list in his address book is
infected.
> The virus randomly takes the contacts from the user's addy book and
then
> emails you with an attachment that's viral. If you open it, and don't
have
> Norton, or the like, running you start sending out emails the same
way.
>
> It's very annoying that people out there can't be smart enough to have
an
> anti-virus application running to prevent such things from occuring.
An
> annoyance on par with spammers.
>
> :: r ::
>

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: *especially TRANCE* Defending my friend, Warren

------=_NextPart_000_015B_01C41C34.8D713420
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hey, all on the SFRAVES list!=20

I know that y'all have issues with spelling and with trance addicts. =
Well, I want to defend my friend, Warren, who posts on this list as =
DJBigDaddyG@aol.com.=20

I met Warren back when he posted on the MokshaTribe list in a moment of =
great excitement (he was happy to be invited by Apollo).=20

What's the big (bitchy) deal on SFraves? Why are we making fun of =
someone who can't spell correctly?=20

I have a college degree in English with a specialty in editing, but I =
still want to dance beside Warren someday before I leave this email list =
and this region of the country. In fact, you will be hearing more =
non-fiction messages from me in the next month because I have a lot to =
say about raving and American lifestyles.=20

In the past, Warren has asked me to help him edit his postings. I =
actually edited a few of these, but I strongly feel that your English or =
grammar habits have no significance to raving if you want to tell the =
World how you feel.=20

I feel that this list should continue discussions about raving, =
regardless of email filters and significant law-making authorities =
(spies).=20

Therefore, this message is a defense of Warren. I have a new personal =
tag line, for as long as I am raving,=20

"Trance puts the prance in your dance."=20

In addition, I mean it, sincerely,=20

Greg VP

------=_NextPart_000_015B_01C41C34.8D713420--

Subject: [sfraves] Dancing in the dark with candles [was:sfraves Tribal Android]

I don't know how to thank you except via a public reply to this list.

Your poem expressed my daily emotional sentiments.

I dance at the park on weekdays, by using a Rebok Step or a PowerSlide (thus
guaranteeing strange stares from bystanders), but I also dance in the dark
with candles (at home), with no one around to see my silly expressions.

Your poem moved me to tears.

Yes, I feel like an android when I am expressing dance movements without
inhibitions.
(at home or at at raves)

Sincerely,
Greg VP
"Trance puts the prance in your dance."


- Original Message -----
From: <JBlaze112@aol.com>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, April 06, 2004 12:08 PM
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Tribal Android...


when i dance at the party i get looks & stares
they're looking at me but there's nobody there
i move to the sound of chirps blips and glitches
my limbs seem to disapear then reapear, twitches
i vibrate to beats that are too fast for effect
then pause to the silence like a nervous insect
never an arrogant smile for a dance move well done
not one nerv of pride because i have none
anxiety flows through my bones like a circut
i can hit every beat of the sound how i work it
i count up to zero and become one with the void
my soul is binary like a tribal android...

References: <20040406165059.25673.h012.c021.wm@mail.viberation.com.criticalpath.net> <BAY8-DAV4YBr4BvRnfv0001b4bc@hotmail.com> <00bb01c41c35$596c7120$2efea8c0@sziggo>
Date: Wed, 7 Apr 2004 07:59:43 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] email viruses from sfr peeps?

That email that is going around that appears to be from staff@whatever.com
or
management@whatever.com
and sports an attachment (usually .pif) is a strain of the
Netsky worm.

The relevant information on the worm as well as a removal tool for any of
our customers who were infected is available here:

http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/w32.netsky.d@mm.html

The updated Norton Antivirus & MacAfee definitions include the ability to
detect this
virus, so if the affected customer has it installed update the definitions
and run a scan.

You can also set up spam filters to block the email
address of staff@whatever.com  or management@whatever.com unless you
expect mail from that address.


swik da moan

-----Original Message-----
From: Greg Van Pelt [mailto:gregvp@comcast.net]
Sent: Wednesday, April 07, 2004 12:09 AM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: *especially TRANCE* Defending my friend, Warren


Hey, all on the SFRAVES list!=20

I know that y'all have issues with spelling and with trance addicts. =
Well, I want to defend my friend, Warren, who posts on this list as =
DJBigDaddyG@aol.com.=20

I met Warren back when he posted on the MokshaTribe list in a moment of =
great excitement (he was happy to be invited by Apollo).=20

What's the big (bitchy) deal on SFraves? Why are we making fun of =
someone who can't spell correctly?=20

I have a college degree in English with a specialty in editing, but I =
still want to dance beside Warren someday before I leave this email list =
and this region of the country. In fact, you will be hearing more =
non-fiction messages from me in the next month because I have a lot to =
say about raving and American lifestyles.=20

In the past, Warren has asked me to help him edit his postings. I =
actually edited a few of these, but I strongly feel that your English or =
grammar habits have no significance to raving if you want to tell the =
World how you feel.=20

I feel that this list should continue discussions about raving, =
regardless of email filters and significant law-making authorities =
(spies).=20

Therefore, this message is a defense of Warren. I have a new personal =
tag line, for as long as I am raving,=20

"Trance puts the prance in your dance."=20

In addition, I mean it, sincerely,=20

Greg VP

-----Original Message-----
From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org]
Sent: Tuesday, April 06, 2004 5:41 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: House Anti-Narcotics Chairman Reacts to ABC
Ecstasy Show


http://www.gopusa.com/news/2004/april/0406_souder_jennings_ecstasy.shtml

House Anti-Narcotics Chairman Reacts Strongly to Ecstasy Promotion by =
ABC,=20
Jennings
By Jimmy Moore
Talon News
April 6, 2004

WASHINGTON (Talon News) -- Rep. Mark Souder (R-IN), the House=20
anti-narcotics chairman, reacted strongly to the
reporting on an illegal drug by ABC News anchorman Peter Jennings.

Souder responded to comments he read in the Palm Beach Post by Jennings=20
last week regarding the popular mind-
altering drug Ecstasy.

Jennings said he was concerned that claims by the U.S. government that=20
Ecstasy is unsafe are exaggerated, causing
young people to question any information provided in the future.

"Government is best when government is most honest, especially for the=20
younger generation, which is more susceptible
to trying drugs," Jennings remarked to the Palm Beach Post. "If they =
can't=20
rely on the government for good and
honest information, then government has lost something enormously =
valuable,=20
which is people's belief in the
government's credibility."

In a one-hour news special that aired last Thursday called "Peter =
Jennings=20
Reporting: Ecstasy Rising," Jennings
examined the government's futile record for slowing the distribution of =
the=20
pills.

"This was an opportunity for us to look at whether or not the government =

isn't its own worst enemy in trying to
control illegal drugs," Jennings explained to the Palm Beach Post =
regarding=20
the show.

Promoting the benefits of Ecstasy rather than the dangers in his show,=20
Jennings said he is not concerned at all that
this will pique the interest of young people to try the illegal drug.

"It can't be a concern," Jennings said regarding young people wanting to =

try Ecstasy. "Our job is to lay out the
facts."

Souder said he could not believe a well-known news anchor like Jennings=20
would make such comments about a drug that
has been banned in the United States since 1985.

"I'm outraged by the irresponsible comments that [Jennings] made in =
advance=20
of its airing," Souder exclaimed. "Their
appalling nature does not leave me optimistic about the veracity and =
good=20
intentions of the 'production' he's
touting."

Using his experience dealing with anti-narcotics issues in Congress, =
Souder=20
said the research conducted by Jennings
and ABC is severely flawed.

"Jennings exposes a great deal about his own selective research methods=20
when he claims that the government's
'science was not good,'" Souder states. "Countless studies have proven =
that=20
Ecstasy is far from a benign drug."

He added, "[R]eams of evidence demonstrate that Ecstasy causes brain =
damage=20
and even death."

As for the carefree manner that Jennings conducted this program, Souder=20
said the lack of a moral compass by the ABC
news anchor is especially disturbing.

"If Jennings' nonchalant comments about this dangerous drug are =
indicative=20
of the outlook of his 'special,' then he
is misleading his viewers," Souder remarked. "To make matters worse,=20
Jennings appears to have no moral qualms about
offering the American public what the Palm Beach Post cast as 'a glossy, =

late-night infomercial.'"

Questioning the motives of Jennings' reporting of this story, Souder =
said=20
Jennings needed to look into the subject
further.

"Jennings somehow believes that his take on Ecstasy is tantamount to=20
'lay[ing] out the facts.' But how much does
Jennings actually know about the facts?," Souder commented.

Providing an example of how Ecstasy has caused harm, Souder challenged=20
Jennings to show the whole truth about the
negative effects of Ecstasy to complete his story.

"In 2002, I heard testimony from the mother of 23-year-old Kelley Baker =
who=20
died of an Ecstasy overdose," Souder
noted. "Will Jennings' 'special' offer the facts about Ecstasy's effects =
on=20
her young life?"

Copyright =A9 2004 Talon News -- All rights reserved.

is=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a =
purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the =

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually =
become=20
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the=20
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club,=20
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to =
that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: *especially TRANCE* Defending my friend, Warren

Grammar and spelling are key to communicating effectively. That's why you
have the job that you do. No one would read anything from you and treat it
as credible information if you didn't have the capacity to spell and from
grammatically correct sentences. The excuses of "it's an email list" or
"it's just aim" are complete bullshit. In any forum that uses written
communication your ability to communicate accurately *does* have a bearing
on your perceived intelligence and credibility.

Does spelling and grammar have anything to do with dancing? No, they do not.
When one is out dancing he//she is not participating in an online forum that
revolves around written communication. When that person decides to send an
email to a forum, be it rave related or otherwise, that email is
representative of you. If you have horrible grammar and spelling you present
yourself in a manner that's not conducive to being intelligent or credible.

Emotions and plur-like thinking aside, that is the real world truth.

:: r ::

"trance in your pants puts the dance in your prance"

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Greg Van Pelt" <gregvp@comcast.net>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, April 07, 2004 12:09 AM
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: *especially TRANCE* Defending my friend, Warren


Hey, all on the SFRAVES list!

I know that y'all have issues with spelling and with trance addicts. Well, I
want to defend my friend, Warren, who posts on this list as
DJBigDaddyG@aol.com.

I met Warren back when he posted on the MokshaTribe list in a moment of
great excitement (he was happy to be invited by Apollo).

What's the big (bitchy) deal on SFraves? Why are we making fun of someone
who can't spell correctly?

I have a college degree in English with a specialty in editing, but I still
want to dance beside Warren someday before I leave this email list and this
region of the country. In fact, you will be hearing more non-fiction
messages from me in the next month because I have a lot to say about raving
and American lifestyles.

In the past, Warren has asked me to help him edit his postings. I actually
edited a few of these, but I strongly feel that your English or grammar
habits have no significance to raving if you want to tell the World how you
feel.

I feel that this list should continue discussions about raving, regardless
of email filters and significant law-making authorities (spies).

Therefore, this message is a defense of Warren. I have a new personal tag
line, for as long as I am raving,

"Trance puts the prance in your dance."

In addition, I mean it, sincerely,

Greg VP

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> region of the country. In fact, you will be hearing more non-fiction
> messages from me in the next month because I have a lot to say about 
> raving
> and American lifestyles.
>
> In the past, Warren has asked me to help him edit his postings. I 
> actually
> edited a few of these, but I strongly feel that your English or grammar
> habits have no significance to raving if you want to tell the World 
> how you
> feel.
>
> I feel that this list should continue discussions about raving, 
> regardless
> of email filters and significant law-making authorities (spies).
>
> Therefore, this message is a defense of Warren. I have a new personal 
> tag
> line, for as long as I am raving,
>
> "Trance puts the prance in your dance."
>
> In addition, I mean it, sincerely,
>
> Greg VP

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: *especially TRANCE* Defending my friend, Warren

> Perhaps the answer is humans as a food source. Breaded stupid people
> served with lemon aioli.

Soylent green is made out of people... who can't spell.

Ryan voiced an opinion that I've been thinking about for the last few
weeks of my participation on a message board with quite a few more bad
spellers and grammatical manhandlers than the Hyperreal list.  In some
places the English language is becoming horribly corroded from instant
messengers and rapid-fire discussion threads... not to mention poor
education in the language or an indifference to learning good writing
style.

If someone wants to be taken seriously in a forum of the written word, one
must write well.  There may be valuable thoughts behind the words, but
unless we can read those words without getting confused or getting a
migraine, those thoughts won't be communicated.

C.

From: JonnyR@aol.com

Date: Wed, 7 Apr 2004 14:26:31 EDT
To: innocentchild@hotmail.com, gregvp@comcast.net, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="-----------------------------1081362391"
X-Mailer: 9.0 for Windows sub 5107
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: *especially TRANCE* Defending my friend, Warren

-------------------------------1081362391
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Hi, as usual in a debate, I feel that everybody is write ... oops, "right"  
:)  ... to some degree. Like Greg, I make my living editing the mistakes that 
other people make when writing, so in a way I have a vested interest in the 
continued misuse and abuse of the English language by so many people. 

I think what we're witnessing is the fallout from the "Hooked on Phonics" 
phenomenon. In the past, many kids who were not solid in language skills felt 
awkward about expressing themselves. Phonics encouraged them to go ahead and 
write, with less emphasis on correct spelling and other emphases of older methods. 
That's great, up to a point -- eventually kids should learn how to spell 
correctly because, as Ryan says, people will not take them seriously if their 
language is severely mangled.  We see with some SFR members an exuberance about 
self-expression that would be welcome, except that the spelling and grammatical 
choices do indeed make the brain hurt at times. 

It's all a matter of degree. I don't think that the population, in general, 
spells as well as in the past. Many of the posts on SFR contain spelling or 
grammatical mistakes, but if they are below a certain threshhold, readibility is 
not threatened. Very many posts contain words that pass a spellchecker but are 
in fact the "wrong word," such as "their" vs. "they're." The spelling of many 
words is only a guess; for example, "feening" (as in desiring something) is 
really spelled "fiending" (as in "drug fiend"). A common mistake, even found in 
many publications, is the word "phased" (meaning affected) when it really 
should be "fazed." Even the best grammarians will leave in small mistakes and 
uncapitalized letters, knowing that they are communicating well enough to be 
understood, especially in the informal realm of online media. 

I recommend to everyone not to be too reliant on spellchecking. Spellcheckers 
are the front-line soldiers in the war against bad English but they're not 
the whole solution. For those who really have a lot of difficulty with written 
language, I recommend classes at a local community college or a similar 
program. Your ability to communicate really does affect your chances of success in 
life. 

I have not yet met Warren in person but he seems to be a very sincere and 
warm person who has only the best intentions. In a way, I'm reminded of a 
friend's younger brother who is always eager and wants to tag along all the time. You 
might get annoyed that he can't communicate in a more polished way, but you 
can't really get mad at him for being himself. 

that's my Too Sense     :)
John

-------------------------------1081362391--

From sfraves-return-111612-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 07 18:38:05 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-111612-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] SRR: *especially TRANCE* Defending my friend, Warren

This reminds me of a grammer issue that I had to do lots of research to =
figure out since no one seems to really know:

What is the correct usages of "effect" vs. "affect".

Effect is not for human use. Affect is for when a chemical affects you =
and you feel the effects. Got it?=20

"affect" is a verb and "effect" is a noun.

My grammer is really good until I take too much cough syrup, I'm sure =
many other users of this list have similar problems.



-----Original Message-----
From: JonnyR@aol.com [mailto:JonnyR@aol.com]
Sent: Wednesday, April 07, 2004 11:27 AM
To: innocentchild@hotmail.com; gregvp@comcast.net; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: *especially TRANCE* Defending my friend,
Warren


Hi, as usual in a debate, I feel that everybody is write ... oops, =
"right" =20
:)  ... to some degree. Like Greg, I make my living editing the mistakes =
that=20
other people make when writing, so in a way I have a vested interest in =
the=20
continued misuse and abuse of the English language by so many people.=20

I think what we're witnessing is the fallout from the "Hooked on =
Phonics"=20
phenomenon. In the past, many kids who were not solid in language skills =
felt=20
awkward about expressing themselves. Phonics encouraged them to go ahead =
and=20
write, with less emphasis on correct spelling and other emphases of =
older methods.=20
That's great, up to a point -- eventually kids should learn how to spell =

correctly because, as Ryan says, people will not take them seriously if =
their=20
language is severely mangled.  We see with some SFR members an =
exuberance about=20
self-expression that would be welcome, except that the spelling and =
grammatical=20
choices do indeed make the brain hurt at times.=20

It's all a matter of degree. I don't think that the population, in =
general,=20
spells as well as in the past. Many of the posts on SFR contain spelling =
or=20
grammatical mistakes, but if they are below a certain threshhold, =
readibility is=20
not threatened. Very many posts contain words that pass a spellchecker =
but are=20
in fact the "wrong word," such as "their" vs. "they're." The spelling of =
many=20
words is only a guess; for example, "feening" (as in desiring something) =
is=20
really spelled "fiending" (as in "drug fiend"). A common mistake, even =
found in=20
many publications, is the word "phased" (meaning affected) when it =
really=20
should be "fazed." Even the best grammarians will leave in small =
mistakes and=20
uncapitalized letters, knowing that they are communicating well enough =
to be=20
understood, especially in the informal realm of online media.=20

I recommend to everyone not to be too reliant on spellchecking. =
Spellcheckers=20
are the front-line soldiers in the war against bad English but they're =
not=20
the whole solution. For those who really have a lot of difficulty with =
written=20
language, I recommend classes at a local community college or a similar=20
program. Your ability to communicate really does affect your chances of =
success in=20
life.=20

I have not yet met Warren in person but he seems to be a very sincere =
and=20
warm person who has only the best intentions. In a way, I'm reminded of =
a=20
friend's younger brother who is always eager and wants to tag along all =
the time. You=20
might get annoyed that he can't communicate in a more polished way, but =
you=20
can't really get mad at him for being himself.=20

that's my Too Sense     :)
John

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

In a message dated 4/7/2004 11:47:38 AM Pacific Standard Time, 
SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com writes:
"affect" is a verb and "effect" is a noun.
That's true, except when talking about "effecting a change," meaning "to 
bring about a change."  Then "effect" is a verb.  A lot of writers, especially in 
newspapers, don't get this right. 

-------------------------------1081364571--

i was just laughing as well.

i don't think anyone was being bitchy, i think we were all
poking some harmless fun.  if i misspell something, i expect to
get ribbed for it too.  i mean, come on!  use the spell check
if you know that you can't spell.  don't give your emails to
someone else to proofread.

anyway, this reminds me of when i was offering advice for
warped records.  i told people that if their records were
"bowel shaped" they could flatten them in a certain way.  i got
plenty of comments (both public and private) on that one.

just take it in stride and laugh.  it's no big deal.

m

what i got:

Jason Lee is headlining the night, from
10:45pm-midnight.  he's sick, amazing, and basically
able to surpass any grand epiphanic experience most
dj's i hear shoot for, and he does it every time i see
him spin.  you can check out his website
http://jl.halogen.org to further investigate, dog

Sheztek & Jauncy are doing a tag set from 8:15pm to
10:45pm - i have absolutely no idea what these two are
coming with, so get there early to find out.  If you
like them at Moksha parties, you'll love them in a
dark basement with no available exit and only a tray
of drinks in sight.. ;) 

Finally, we have our man Danny doing a tag set with
Sir Nod - i'm not sure what they're playing either but
whatever the hell it's going to be (and if i know
Don), it'll most likely be driving techno.  wouldn't
it be awesome to wear a suit made solely of bass
traps?  /fear 

finally, upstairs we have our AuraSF/Hosstribe crew:

7:30p-9p Koroma
9p-10:30p Cronos
10:30p - 12am Floorcraft
12a-1:30am JC.

drinks are cheap!  <duh, if you're of age> 2 dollar
drafts, 3 dollar wells, video games and airline seats.

Spam? Army C-rations circa World War II? Osby dude you should visit Hawaii 
... they love Spam over there. Dunno why, really. Pork shoulder and ham ... and 
that weird gelatinous stuff that fills the rest of the can ... I don't know if 
it's officially "aspic" but it's something of the sort. 
Modern soldiers get "Meals Ready to Eat" instead of Spam. There's more 
variety, and like Spam, these meals don't have to be cooked. I'm not sure if the 
soldiers like MREs any better than Spam, as their nickname is "Meals Rejected by 
Ethiopians." 
BTW studies have shown that the soldiers' morale improves when brand-name 
snacks like Skittles are included in the MRE.  

Here is a recipe for Osby:
Take one can Spam
Put it back on the shelf
Buy a cheeseburger at the Smokehouse on Telegraph, along with an order of 
their great fries!

-------------------------------1081368950--

Message-ID: <20040407201933.60861.qmail@web13905.mail.yahoo.com>

From: Nathan Seven <scosol@yahoo.com>
To: Steve Osteen <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>, JonnyR@aol.com,
  innocentchild@hotmail.com, gregvp@comcast.net, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <340D5A031E64C2468AF37960805A374506E232@us1-mail16.pcle.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR effect/affect RE: [sfraves] SRR: *especially TRANCE* Defending my friend, Warren

Your "grammer"?

Sorry- I had to :P

I love nothing more than seeing someone bitching about
someone else's "grammer"-
It seems to happen at least once a day on /. 

As to your question, someone please correct me if this
is incorrect because I'm not a professional-

But "affect" and "effect" differ mainly by their use
as nouns and verbs.
"effect" is always(*) a noun.
"affect" is always(*) a verb.
Correct: "I'm feeling that blunt's effects""
Correct: "Man, that 40 is affecting my judgement!"

(*) The only exception I've seen to this is the phrase
"to effect change"
(Meaning- "to bring about change")
I think it's that way because it's describing the
condition of change (noun).
If that phrase meant "to change change" (change used
first as verb, then as noun- which makes no sense)
then it would be written as "to affect change"-
Tho, lots of people write that too, so maybe its
interchangable.

--- Steve Osteen <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com> wrote:
> This reminds me of a grammer issue that I had to do
> lots of research to figure out since no one seems to
> really know:
> 
> What is the correct usages of "effect" vs. "affect".
> 
> Effect is not for human use. Affect is for when a
> chemical affects you and you feel the effects. Got
> it? 
> 
> "affect" is a verb and "effect" is a noun.
> 
> My grammer is really good until I take too much
> cough syrup, I'm sure many other users of this list
> have similar problems.
> 
> 
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: JonnyR@aol.com [mailto:JonnyR@aol.com]
> Sent: Wednesday, April 07, 2004 11:27 AM
> To: innocentchild@hotmail.com; gregvp@comcast.net;
> sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: *especially TRANCE*
> Defending my friend,
> Warren
> 
> 
> Hi, as usual in a debate, I feel that everybody is
> write ... oops, "right"  
> :)  ... to some degree. Like Greg, I make my living
> editing the mistakes that 
> other people make when writing, so in a way I have a
> vested interest in the 
> continued misuse and abuse of the English language
> by so many people. 
> 
> I think what we're witnessing is the fallout from
> the "Hooked on Phonics" 
> phenomenon. In the past, many kids who were not
> solid in language skills felt 
> awkward about expressing themselves. Phonics
> encouraged them to go ahead and 
> write, with less emphasis on correct spelling and
> other emphases of older methods. 
> That's great, up to a point -- eventually kids
> should learn how to spell 
> correctly because, as Ryan says, people will not
> take them seriously if their 
> language is severely mangled.  We see with some SFR
> members an exuberance about 
> self-expression that would be welcome, except that
> the spelling and grammatical 
> choices do indeed make the brain hurt at times. 
> 
> It's all a matter of degree. I don't think that the
> population, in general, 
> spells as well as in the past. Many of the posts on
> SFR contain spelling or 
> grammatical mistakes, but if they are below a
> certain threshhold, readibility is 
> not threatened. Very many posts contain words that
> pass a spellchecker but are 
> in fact the "wrong word," such as "their" vs.
> "they're." The spelling of many 
> words is only a guess; for example, "feening" (as in
> desiring something) is 
> really spelled "fiending" (as in "drug fiend"). A
> common mistake, even found in 
> many publications, is the word "phased" (meaning
> affected) when it really 
> should be "fazed." Even the best grammarians will
> leave in small mistakes and 
> uncapitalized letters, knowing that they are
> communicating well enough to be 
> understood, especially in the informal realm of
> online media. 
> 
> I recommend to everyone not to be too reliant on
> spellchecking. Spellcheckers 
> are the front-line soldiers in the war against bad
> English but they're not 
> the whole solution. For those who really have a lot
> of difficulty with written 
> language, I recommend classes at a local community
> college or a similar 
> program. Your ability to communicate really does
> affect your chances of success in 
> life. 
> 
> I have not yet met Warren in person but he seems to
> be a very sincere and 
> warm person who has only the best intentions. In a
> way, I'm reminded of a 
> friend's younger brother who is always eager and
> wants to tag along all the time. You 
> might get annoyed that he can't communicate in a
> more polished way, but you 
> can't really get mad at him for being himself. 
> 
> that's my Too Sense     :)
> John
> 
>

Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <Law10-F70mlEbrXzy3N0002f23e@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 07 Apr 2004 20:54:41.0017 (UTC) FILETIME=[8BFF5690:01C41CE2]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Any good SPAM (that canned meat thingie) recepies?

i used to make a mean spicy spam sushi in college.

cut spam into long strips about 1/2 inch x 1/2 inch.  marinate in Sriracha 
hot sauce and simmer in frying pan.  lay out dried seaweed, spread rice on 
seaweed and place spam strips in middle.  roll up a fatty and slice.

you can also make a hawaiian spam musubi and can even buy a little plastic 
box thingy at an asian market so you can "mold" the rice and the spam into a 
single block.  add a strip of seaweed to hold it all together.

spam fried rice rocks, too.

< Brandon / DJ Bam >

http://www.invibe.com/bam

Download the new mix online!

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

 sfraves@hyperreal.org,
 osby@hellokitty.com
From: John B. <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 7 Apr 2004 14:02:01 -0700
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.613)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Any good SPAM (that canned meat thingie) recepies?

The story I heard way back when my dad was stationed at Pearl, and we 
lived in Honolulu goes something like this:

During WWII just about everything was rationed in the US... gas, tires, 
milk, everything... including meat.  So beef was already in short 
supply.  What's more, transportation was mostly monopolized by military 
uses.  And Hawaii has very little grazing land, and hence, very few 
cattle.  With the bulk of shipping being used to fuel the war effort, 
beef became that much MORE expensive in Hawaii... prohibitively so, for 
most of the population.  And remember, this was before refrigeration 
was common, especially in the shipping industry; so unless you were 
shipping live cattle, beef would mostly spoil on the way anyway.  What 
WAS in abundant supply (and CHEAP), because it was fueling the war 
effort, and because it doesn't perish, was Spam.  So the islanders 
learned how to cook with it so as to make it taste somewhat decent; 
mainly out of necessity.  And eventually they came to like it.

Now, I dunno, for sure, if this is the truth, or just an urban legend.  
But it makes sense to me.  Beef is STILL fairly expensive on the 
islands.  But the real reason, I'm sure, that it is thought of well 
NOW, is because they were raised on the stuff.


cya,
john


JohnnyR wrote:

 > Osby dude you should visit Hawaii...
 > they love Spam over there. Dunno why, really.

language changes and the Internet certainly has had much impact on 
"correct" usage or lack thereof of the King's English.  I like Dr. Samuel 
Johnson's quote on grammar:  "No man forgets his original trade: the rights 
of nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar, if grammarians 
discuss them."

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

visible."

beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Your *King's English* comment is a tangent that confuses the original
argument. Last I checked we weren't an imperialist society with king and
queen figure heads. People that have horrible grammar and spelling will
appear to be uneducated and lack credibility in written form. Don't try to
add in *well he's a good person* or any other character attributes because
they have no bearing on an ability to communicate intelligently in written
form. As for modernization of the English language we have the Modern
Language Association for that purpose. Those that haven't been to school or
encountered MLA before should read up. http://www.mla.org.

"But it's a rave list..." - and that means you have an excuse to bypass
basic English skills? HA!

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Thank ABC for Ecstasy Documentary!

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


Thank ABC for Ecstasy Documentary!

ABC News anchor Peter Jennings hosted a 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=27002>special report 
April 1 on the risks and misconceptions of the drug MDMA, also known as 
Ecstasy. The hour-long documentary highlighted the federal government's 
campaign against Ecstasy, centered on the idea that the drug causes brain 
damage. But "Ecstasy Rising" also included plenty of testimonials from 
people who say MDMA has improved their emotional well-being. Please 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=27037>e-mail ABC to say 
thanks.

Far from a new drug, MDMA was patented in 1914 by Merck. Mental health 
professionals used it widely in the 1970s and 1980s to treat psychiatric 
disorders. The federal government moved Ecstasy to Schedule I, defined as 
having no valid medical use and high potential for abuse, in 1986 after a 
resurgence of the drug on the club scene. Yet some patients report a 
feeling of openness and a willingness to talk after taking MDMA, which the 
Drug Enforcement Administration recently 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=27001>approved for a 
first-of-its-kind psychotherapy study.

The Jennings documentary marks the first time a network news broadcast has 
dedicated so much time to a balanced examination of federal drug policy. 
Please let the network's staff know you're grateful for their hard work.

To view an archive of "Ecstasy Rising," 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=27002>click here.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Date: Wed, 7 Apr 2004 14:57:05 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: =?iso-8859-1?B?T6dieSBKYW16 ?= <osby@hellokitty.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20040407200306.188C521B330@ws5-6.us4.outblaze.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0404071415580.12697-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Any good SPAM (that canned meat thingie) recepies?


Here ya go Osby (most of you might not know this, but my favorite thing
ever is cooking weird stuff with whatever is in the pantry/fridge):

SpamFry (serves 2-3)
--------------------
1 can of spam
1 brick of firm tofu
8 green onions
1 cup of rice
2 tbsp of peanut oil
sesame seeds
crushed cashews
some nori flakes (or just a quarter sheet of nori held over a burner till
it changes color and ripped into little shreds)


dry press tofu (best done with a brick).
start yer rice.
when rice has about 10-15 minutes left on it...
cut up tofu into 1/4" thick pieces
blot with a paper towel.
cut spam into 1/4" thick pieces
heat up oil in frying pan on medium high heat (make sure the pan is big
enough to keep all ingredients flat in one layer)
when the oil's hot... (if you're not sure throw a grain of rice in
there... it should dance but not burn)
fry up your tofu + spam
cook till spam is starting to brown and tofu starts to skin (about 2-3
minutes a side if you got the oil right)
drain oil from above crap (best to just rest it on paper towel and turn
once).
with still hot pan, pour off the remaining oil and sear the green onions
(crank up the heat and cook until you get some dark lines on the onions).

serving:
top with spam with nori, the tofu with crushed cashews and the green
onions with sesame... served over rice in funky pattern (you can skip soy
sauce for this one cause the spam is so salty as is... try a Tonkatsu
sauce instead!).  goes perfect with a dry tasting beer (saporro, kirin)
and a dessert of green tea ice cream and some dark chocolate shavings.


---------------------------------------------------------------------

At 02:52 PM 4/7/2004, innocentchild wrote:
>Your *King's English* comment is a tangent that confuses the original
>argument. Last I checked we weren't an imperialist society with king and
>queen figure heads. People that have horrible grammar and spelling will
>appear to be uneducated and lack credibility in written form. Don't try to
>add in *well he's a good person* or any other character attributes because
>they have no bearing on an ability to communicate intelligently in written
>form. As for modernization of the English language we have the Modern
>Language Association for that purpose. Those that haven't been to school or
>encountered MLA before should read up. http://www.mla.org.

Yep, well I have a PhD in English lit and the MLA style sheet is an 
excellent document.  But the MLA has many motivations and, like many 
academic organizations, needs to spend a bit more time outside the King's 
walls:)

The "King's English" is an old phrase and has absolutely nothing to do with 
"imperialism."  Wow:)

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

>From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Thank ABC for Ecstasy Documentary!
>Date: Wed, 07 Apr 2004 14:53:44 -0700
>
>
>Thank ABC for Ecstasy Documentary!
>
>ABC News anchor Peter Jennings hosted a 
><http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=27002>special report 
>April 1 on the risks and misconceptions of the drug MDMA, also known as 
>Ecstasy. The hour-long documentary highlighted the federal government's 
>campaign against Ecstasy, centered on the idea that the drug causes brain 
>damage. But "Ecstasy Rising" also included plenty of testimonials from 
>people who say MDMA has improved their emotional well-being. Please 
><http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=27037>e-mail ABC to say 
>thanks.
>
>Far from a new drug, MDMA was patented in 1914 by Merck. Mental health 
>professionals used it widely in the 1970s and 1980s to treat psychiatric 
>disorders. The federal government moved Ecstasy to Schedule I, defined as 
>having no valid medical use and high potential for abuse, in 1986 after a 
>resurgence of the drug on the club scene. Yet some patients report a 
>feeling of openness and a willingness to talk after taking MDMA, which the 
>Drug Enforcement Administration recently 
><http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=27001>approved for a 
>first-of-its-kind psychotherapy study.
>
>The Jennings documentary marks the first time a network news broadcast has 
>dedicated so much time to a balanced examination of federal drug policy. 
>Please let the network's staff know you're grateful for their hard work.
>
>To view an archive of "Ecstasy Rising," 
><http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=27002>click here.
>
>
>
>Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
>House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
>not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a 
>purpose."
>-Helen Keller
>
>"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
>rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
>visible."
>-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
>life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
>beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
>party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to 
>that..."
>-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

At 03:03 PM 4/7/2004, innocentchild wrote:
>So obviously you should have the intelligence to not defend bad grammar 
>and spelling then. =)
>
>:: r ::


"The king's English, correct or current language of good
       speakers; pure English. --Shak."

Moi, I look for character and talent first in others.  I've learned much 
from people who have "poor" language skills.  Right now, for example, I'm 
communicating with some very talented DJs and producers from back in 
seventies NYC before revising House Music 101.  Some of these guys have 
real problems with writing.  We've had to move from emails to the 
telephone.  If, for example, I got my tits in a ringer over Barry's all 
caps emails, with horrid grammar and spelling, I would learn nothing new.

Just me.

Love,

Apollo

>House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
>not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
>-Helen Keller
>
>"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
>rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
>visible."
>-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
>life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
>beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
>party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
>-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

>So obviously you should have the intelligence to not defend bad grammar 
>and spelling then. =)

>:: r ::


<<"The king's English, correct or current language of good
       speakers; pure English. --Shak."

Moi, I look for character and talent first in others.  I've learned much 
from people who have "poor" language skills.  Right now, for example, I'm 
communicating with some very talented DJs and producers from back in 
seventies NYC before revising House Music 101.  Some of these guys have 
real problems with writing.  We've had to move from emails to the 
telephone.  If, for example, I got my tits in a ringer over Barry's all 
caps emails, with horrid grammar and spelling, I would learn nothing new.>>

Ah, that should be tits in a "wringer:)"  Although tits in a ringer has 
something to it.  You know, when I was a small boy my mother got her tits 
in a wringer.  We had to call a doctor.  Remember it vividly.

Love,

Apollo
