Subject: [sfraves] Alloy Trex CD out now!



Hi all,

Alloy Trex is proud to announce the release of their first full-length
CD, "Algo-Rhythm".  This CD was recorded just like we do our shows, completely
live.  If you are not familiar with Alloy Trex, we have performed in
numerous chill-rooms around the Bay Area for over five years, including
Koinonea, Thump, Tantra, Key of Life and G.o.a Play parties.

Alloy Trex combines funky breakbeat grooves with ripping psytrance
inspired synth work with lots of random weirdness thrown in for good measure.
The Alloy Trex sound has a dynamic, evolving quality that can only
come from a live, real-time performance.

"Algo-Rhythm" is available for online purchase at CDstreet.com:

http://www.cdstreet.com/artists/alloytrex/

Here you will find plenty of sample clips from the CD.  We invite
you to come take a listen.

-troy and alex

THE MOST NATURAL SELECTION

Steven Kotler, LA Weekly

Charles Darwin would say that since homosexuality is not a
reproductive strategy, it's an aberration that should die
off. But a new book arrives at another conclusion: Darwin's
theory of sexual selection must be wrong.

http://www.alternet.org/story.html?StoryID=18437



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

X-Originating-IP: [130.212.184.193]

Bcc: 
Date: Mon, 19 Apr 2004 23:35:16 +0000
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY12-F48JXrRjbDt3H00058a6a@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 19 Apr 2004 23:35:16.0553 (UTC) FILETIME=[F82E7390:01C42666]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: THE MOST NATURAL SELECTION

An interesting read.  I study genetics (and other stuff, he he) and right 
now there is no convincing evidence that homosexuality or variations in 
sexual behavior are inherited.  There are many homosexual individuals who 
have offspring before they "come-out" and as far as I know, their children 
do not have a higher occurance of homosexuality than nonhomosexuals.  To me, 
it seems that sexuality is something that is more of a spectrum and 
preference than a definable categorizable matter.  In my own life, as well 
as in the lives of many close friends, my ideas and sexual behavior have 
changed.  There is no evidense genetically or from personal experience, that 
sexuality is something that is inhertible or something that is permanent.
Just my 2 pesos,
Joey

At 04:35 PM 4/19/2004, Joey Frisco wrote:

>An interesting read.  I study genetics (and other stuff, he he) and right 
>now there is no convincing evidence that homosexuality or variations in 
>sexual behavior are inherited.  There are many homosexual individuals who 
>have offspring before they "come-out" and as far as I know, their children 
>do not have a higher occurance of homosexuality than nonhomosexuals.  To 
>me, it seems that sexuality is something that is more of a spectrum and 
>preference than a definable categorizable matter.  In my own life, as well 
>as in the lives of many close friends, my ideas and sexual behavior have 
>changed.  There is no evidense genetically or from personal experience, 
>that sexuality is something that is inhertible or something that is permanent.
>Just my 2 pesos,
>Joey

> His IQ was zero and his head was up his tush.
> He drank like a fish while he drove all about.
> But that didn't matter 'cuz his daddy bailed him out.
> DUI, that is.
> Criminal record.
> Cover-up.
> Well, the first thing you know little Georgie goes to Yale.
> He can't spell his name but they never let him fail.
> He spends all his time hangin' out with student folk.
> And that's when he learns how to snort a line of coke.
> Blow, that is.
> White gold.
> Nose Candy.
> The next thing you know there's a war in Vietnam.
> Kin folks say, "George, stay at home with Mom."
> We'll buy you a spot in the Texas Air Guard.
> Cushy, that is.
> Country clubs.
> Nose candy.
> Twenty years later George gets a little bored.
> He trades in the booze, says that Jesus is his Lord.
> He said, "Now the White House is the place I wanna be."
> So he called his daddy's friends an they called the GOP.
> Gun owners, that is.
> Falwell.
> Jesse Helms.
> Come November 7, the election ran late.
> Kin folks said "Jeb, give the boy your state!"
> "Don't let those colored folks get into the polls."
> So they put up barricades so they couldn't punch their holes.
> Chads, that is.
> Duval County.
> Miami-Dade.
> Before the votes were counted five Supremes stepped in.
> Told all the voters, "Hey, we want George to win."
> "Stop counting votes!" was their solemn invocation.
> And that's how George finally got his coronation.
> Rigged, that is.
> Illegitimate.
> No moral authority.
> Y'all come vote now.
> Ya hear?

 sfraves@hyperreal.org

From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
In-Reply-To: <BAY12-F48JXrRjbDt3H00058a6a@hotmail.com>
Message-Id: <3877D8BD-928D-11D8-96B1-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: THE MOST NATURAL SELECTION

	Perhaps there *is* a biological (inherited) aspect of homosexuality,  
but one that does not function in a completely straightforward manner.  
While I think a fair amount of sexual orientation may be  
social/cultural, some people clearly have strong dispositions from a  
very early age that cannot really be explained by anything other than  
an inherited trait.

	I agree with Joey that gender is a spectrum, with extreme masculine on  
one end and extreme feminine on the other. People on both ends are less  
likely to have strong homosexual tendencies than people near the  
middle, but there are exceptions in both cases. Say a particular set of  
parents have strong feminine genes. This would mean that if they have a  
*son*, he is more likely than average to be gay, but if they have a  
*daughter*, she is *less* likely than average to be lesbian. The  
reverse would be true for parents with strong masculine genes.

	Of course it's my personal opinion that all of us are bisexual -- most  
people just have a strong enough attraction in one direction or the  
other that they don't bother to experiment much (or at all) with the  
non-preferred sex.

Groove on,
						<<< Starchild >>>


On Monday, April 19, 2004, at 04:35  PM, Joey Frisco wrote:

> An interesting read.  I study genetics (and other stuff, he he) and  
> right now there is no convincing evidence that homosexuality or  
> variations in sexual behavior are inherited.  There are many  
> homosexual individuals who have offspring before they "come-out" and  
> as far as I know, their children do not have a higher occurance of  
> homosexuality than nonhomosexuals.  To me, it seems that sexuality is  
> something that is more of a spectrum and preference than a definable  
> categorizable matter.  In my own life, as well as in the lives of many  
> close friends, my ideas and sexual behavior have changed.  There is no  
> evidense genetically or from personal experience, that sexuality is  
> something that is inhertible or something that is permanent.
> Just my 2 pesos,
> Joey
>

I heard an interesting theory once that homosexuality occurs in nature as a 
means for population control. Given the fact that there are so many people 
on the planet sucking up it's resources at an accelerated rate - maybe it's 
the earth regulating things.

It's *A* theory, not *my* theory. Something to think about anyway...

Either way, people can theorize any way they want, to me it's just another 
part of the yin and yang of life.

>>have offspring before they "come-out" and  as far as I know, their 
>>children do not have a higher occurance of  homosexuality than 
>>nonhomosexuals.  To me, it seems that sexuality is  something that is more 
>>of a spectrum and preference than a definable  categorizable matter.  In 
>>my own life, as well as in the lives of many  close friends, my ideas and 
>>sexual behavior have changed.  There is no  evidense genetically or from 
>>personal experience, that sexuality is  something that is inhertible or 
>>something that is permanent.
>>Just my 2 pesos,
>>Joey

Origin of 420:  What I've heard (and this has been disputed) is that a bunch 
of Marin kids would meet at a statue in front of school at 4:20 pm to smoke. 
This was either San Rafael High (in San Rafael) or Redwood High (Larkspur). 
Seems like an odd time, though ... an hour after school lets out? 
It's also been said that the number is a police code for people smoking pot, 
but that's not true. 
I always grin when I hear ravers say, "I'm sober tonight ... yeah ... just 
smoked some weed tonight, that's all."  it's a matter of degree! 

Today I celebrated by enjoying some, and then treating myself to ice cream.  
:D

-------------------------------1082477557--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 420!!!!BABY!!!!!!HA HA!!!!!!

Heh....  My personal anti-favorite are those stoners who come up with 
ridiculous little slogans like: "baked, not fried"; and who talk about 
how "pot's not a drug, man, it's an herb"; and "I only do drugs that 
grow naturally, man".

Well, things like hemlock also grow naturally.

I don't get where the idea came from that one is somehow virtuous 
because they chose to get high off of some drug that grows as a plant 
vs. a drug that's cooked up in a lab, or people who stay sober.  (And, 
when you come right down to it, many of those "synthetic" drugs can 
ultimately be derived from plant sources; if you'rfe willing to do a 
little more work.)

'Reminds me of this wonderful article about anti-drugs:

http://www.theonion.com/onion3727/my_anti-drug_is_alcohol.html


cya,
john

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Davey D on Democracy Now-Police Surveillance and Hip Hop

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Davey D on Democracy Now-Police Surveillance and Hip Hop

Entire article can be found at www.daveyd.com

Recent reports in Miami and New York have revealed how the police in
these cities have been closely monitoring the hip hop community in
ways critics say are a throwback to COINTELPRO.  We talk acclaimed hip
hop journalist Davey D who hosts a daily show on Pacifica station
KPFA.  [includes rush transcript]
Since the Bush administration took office three years ago, the
number of secret surveillance warrants sought by the FBI has increased
some 85 percent.  This is one of the findings of the commission
investigating the 9/11 attacks.

Recently, there have been a number of stories in the press about
surveillance against Hip Hop artists.  Recently, the New York Police
Department hosted a hip-hop training seminar, attended by several law
enforcement agencies.  At the meeting, a six-inch thick black binder
was handed out.  It included the arrest records and photos of dozens
of rap artists and their companions.  Also, the Village Voice
newspaper recently revealed the existence of a Hip-Hop Intelligence
Unit within the New York Police Department.


Davey D, a hip hop historian, journalist, deejay and community
activist.  He is the webmaster for what is considered one of the
oldest and largest Hip Hop sites on the web: Davey D's Hip Hop Corner.




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Living in a "model" home

------=_NextPart_000_004E_01C426C6.F37AADE0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Well, this is way-off-topic but I thought I would share the feeling. You =
might be in this boat someday.

In real estate, when you are selling your house, it's important to set a =
trend. You have to show off--make your place very presentable, like a =
model home.

The agents call it "staging" and there are professional firms to handle =
this for sellers.

We have some nice furniture so our agent suggested doing our own =
staging. We got rid of some items, and this is hard to do for things =
that you like, but when the place is not cluttered, it looks better. I =
even stored away my 5-minidisc + 3 CD bookshelf system, and we took out =
5 bookshelves and all books and personal items. (Try cooking without =
cookbooks)

The realtor said that you would be surprised how distracting =
photographs, calendars, posters, refrigerator magnets, and such are to =
prospective buyers. So we took them down. No one has to see our happy, =
smiling faces on the walls.

So, when you are living in a "model" home, you have to put things away =
constantly, vacuum a lot, try not to cook smelly seafood, keep the patio =
swept, play CLASSICAL music (NOT jungle, house, or trance) during home =
tours, turn on all the lights and open the windows, hide the dog and her =
bed and toys, and just be presentable.

Man, it's work living in a model home! But maybe since this is the Bay =
Area we will get a lot of money from this deal, and we can see the =
U.S.A.

Greg VP


------=_NextPart_000_004E_01C426C6.F37AADE0--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 420!!!!BABY!!!!!!HA HA!!!!!!

the 420 term came from a group of northbayers who called themselves the
"Waldos". When they were in high school they used 4:20 as their own code
speak meet at the regular place to get smoked after school. I think there
was a nearby amusement park they would routinely go to.

the only chemical in cannabis that really needs any mention is thc. like
tetrahydracannibinol . Some marijuana like plants (ruderalis something or
other) are very similar to cannabis but do not contain thc. Vaporizing is
the absolute best way to take thc, since there is basically no carbon
monoxide produced from the burning of plant matter, cuz thc "vaporizes" at a
lower temp than the actual plant material burns, thus basically eliminating
any and all of the negative effects of the "smoking" part.
In some coffee houses, vaporizers are allowed (not in us) because it's
technically not "smoking".
The us govmt has their own synthesized form of thc that can be prescribed by
doctors in capsule, liquid or powder form.

I think it's funny when people always talk about 420 and have no idea what
they're talking about. Just a catch phrase basically like "wolf tickets",
I'm suprised it caught on, but then again anything that gives cannabis
lovers another reason to love cannabis is usually heavily supported buy
cannabis lovers.

I've been reading high times, and grow books and things like that for like
more than 10 years. . .I'm a supporter of the cause and have even instructed
and helped several people set up groovie grow projects to success. . . it's
a good healthy habit in a lot of ways. It's too badd that some positive
things can kind of be exploited by others, like the HS kids who just are
irresponsible and try to get high all the time cuz they just want to be high
all the time. If they only knew about the other good things they're doing
for themselves, the whole issue could change from "drug users" to educated
beneficiaries of natures gift.

: )

aK

Also a notable fact:

Even tho in CA, if on federally owned land, such as in the presidio area in
SF, federal law governs and you can be arrested for posession even tho you
have all the required doctors recommendations n such. A ticket for posession
is like $250, and they confiscate everything. I assume the same would be
said for military/ex military bases, like in alameda. . .but those are
mainly just security patrolled areas and not patrolled by federal police
officers really (or I've never seen them). Maybe airports also, local and
larger ones. Or FAA governed land.
I'm curious as to what would happen if not actually on federal land, but
within sight of federal officers. . . like on the border of the land area.

At 11:34 AM 4/20/2004, aK wrote:
>the only chemical in cannabis that really needs any mention is thc. like
>tetrahydracannibinol . Some marijuana like plants (ruderalis something or
>other) are very similar to cannabis but do not contain thc. Vaporizing is
>the absolute best way to take thc, since there is basically no carbon
>monoxide produced from the burning of plant matter, cuz thc "vaporizes" at a
>lower temp than the actual plant material burns, thus basically eliminating
>any and all of the negative effects of the "smoking" part.
>In some coffee houses, vaporizers are allowed (not in us) because it's
>technically not "smoking".
>The us govmt has their own synthesized form of thc that can be prescribed by
>doctors in capsule, liquid or powder form.

Vaporizing is perhaps the worst way to introduce cannabinoids into your 
body.  The sensation is entirely different from smoking, and I don't find 
it nearly as pleasant.  THC is the most prevalent chemical, and perhaps the 
one we understand the most, but the others shouldn't be dismissed or 
overlooked.  Marinol (synthetic) is also nothing like smoking, and many 
patients prefer the effects of smoking, if they even register the marinol.


sarilion

yknow really. . .

if someone synthesizes anything, it may be based or similar to natural
compounds, but it will never be exactly the same.

Manufactured and processed chemicals create environmental issues that most
people won't even think about until years from now when it all comes back to
bite us in the ass. . .

and there are major diffirences between "use" and "abuse" of.

Any natural non processed chemical is vastly superior to anything created or
manufactured.

Look at our medicines versus ancient medicine. . . Here in the us, we're
wonderful at covering things up (symptoms n such), but are horrible at
cures. Herbalism, chinese medicine, natural medecines are the sources for
actual cures/remedies, and not simply "making a headache go away", but
making it so you don't get headaches in the first place. (eg)


people who tend to argue about the natural drug thing also tend to be the
same people that embrace manufactured chemicals on a daily basis. Which
realistically, if they changed their tune, they would be much more likely to
find cures for the ailments that they were covering up with their daily
Alleve or high blood pressure meds or whatever.

I've been thru several surgeries on my knees, feet, hands. . .mostly from
broken things. . . after the first time, I tossed out the vicodin crap, and
the pills they told me to take. I simply used herbs, cannabis, proper eating
and diet, and spirituality, and I recieved relief that no manufactured drug
has ever been able to give me, relief that lasts a lifetime, safely. I used
to take zoloft, n xanax, n tried all of these other things, but ultimately I
gave all those things up for natural remedies, and have been much much
better off since.

it's not a simple as "one pill a day", but it actually works at remedying
the cause of the issues.

aK

EVERY TUESDAY @ Sublounge
Local artists display their art.

The bar owners are very supportive of the artists and the burning man communinty. They have donated the space for 2-4 hours every Tuesday for artists to sell thir art/jewerly/music to help support their dreams.

4/20/04 next ART Show at Sublounge-"elevator in the brain hotel" an overly anticipated art show curated by Mr. Deeper Beeper himself Christopher 'drunk good friend' Fabbri

please don't concider this SPAM, it's only a friendly reminder to come out and drink heavily with us as we bring you a beautiful display of art by Michelle White glam fine arts, DeeDee Russell of the Big Daddy Yo Yo swinger dealings, KevinJ. of the G-Whiz Jewelers and- also, Glenn Allen- crazy performance artist 
staight out of The Willy Bologna Circus Show. Yea, this is a show not to be missed.

DJ sounds will be stunted by Awesome Rock climber Justin Walker, Jive talkin' tech oner Juan Segovia and SlyJam connecter Erik Hertz +guests droppin' bombs all nite.

I hope to see you there at 6pm, we'll be stayin' open as long as you stay there and dance, drink and admire the art. By midnite or later you should be passed out. $2 buds/tecate $3 well happy hours 6pm to 9pm, first one on the house FREE/21+  are you out of your mind? Donations at the door please.

Sublounge, 628 20th St., SF, 415.552.3603 or call the lovely curator at 925.330.6509 

http://groups.msn.com/chrisfabbriartistpoethomepage/fabbri.msnw

From: Sarilion [mailto:sarilion@sarilion.org]

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 420!!!!BABY!!!!!!HA HA!!!!!!


At 11:34 AM 4/20/2004, aK wrote:
>the only chemical in cannabis that really needs any mention is thc. =
like
>tetrahydracannibinol . Some marijuana like plants (ruderalis something =
or
>other) are very similar to cannabis but do not contain thc. Vaporizing =
is
>the absolute best way to take thc, since there is basically no carbon
>monoxide produced from the burning of plant matter, cuz thc "vaporizes" =
at a
>lower temp than the actual plant material burns, thus basically =
eliminating
>any and all of the negative effects of the "smoking" part.
>In some coffee houses, vaporizers are allowed (not in us) because it's
>technically not "smoking".
>The us govmt has their own synthesized form of thc that can be =
prescribed by
>doctors in capsule, liquid or powder form.

Vaporizing is perhaps the worst way to introduce cannabinoids into your=20
body.  The sensation is entirely different from smoking, and I don't =
find=20
it nearly as pleasant.  THC is the most prevalent chemical, and perhaps =
the=20
one we understand the most, but the others shouldn't be dismissed or=20
overlooked.  Marinol (synthetic) is also nothing like smoking, and many=20
patients prefer the effects of smoking, if they even register the =
marinol.


sarilion=20

Marinol is a synthetic form of THC.

here's the bad part.  it's patented.  therefore, it makes a drug company
rich.

here's another bad part.  it doesn't taste amazingly great like skunk or
hash oil.

here's another bad part.  marinol is the same thing over and over and over
again.  therefore, i can build tolerance to it.

i want 50,000,000 different kinds of cannabis.  variety is the spice. the
spice expands consciousness.  i want to choose which types of effects i
want to feel.

bill o'reilly, let me grow my own medicine so i don't have to waste my
money making another drug company rich.

jeez billy O' which drug company writes your paycheck.

Jonas

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 420!!!!BABY!!!!!!HA HA!!!!!!

the effects from smoking and vaporizing are diffirent,

carbon monoxide, and other chemicals you absorb from the burning of the
plant matter also gives you that light headed, woozy sometimes kind of
feeling, which thc itself isn't the main contributor to.

like, you know how if sometimes you smoke a cig, and get a lil nauseous,
room spins, light headed n such. . . most of that is from smoking all the
crap from the burning of the papers and materials in the cig and not the
nicotine itself. (some might be sensitivity to nicotine, but mostly the
burning stuff). Try this if you're a smoker. . .smoke an herbal cigarette,
or even just a paper itself or something. . .you'll get a lil short term
woozy buzz feeling. . .you just don't get the fulfillment from the chemical
you're craving, but still feel the lil side effects.

vaporizing is also non cancerous, which is a huge plus, since carbon
monoxide is one of the main causes of cancer in smokers, and the carbon
monoxide is from the burning of the plant matter itself. Carbon monoxide is
poison to most all living creatures, and in small doses cause all those
other heavyish effects you feel, esp with low quality buds.

btw, I personally don't vaporize, even tho I know it's better. . .it's not
too convenient really.I don't own one of those contraptions, but have used
them before.

at a

>eliminating
> > >any and all of the negative effects of the "smoking" part.
> > >In some coffee houses, vaporizers are allowed (not in us) because it's
> > >technically not "smoking".
> > >The us govmt has their own synthesized form of thc that can be 
>prescribed
>by
> > >doctors in capsule, liquid or powder form.
> >
> > Vaporizing is perhaps the worst way to introduce cannabinoids into your
> > body.  The sensation is entirely different from smoking, and I don't 
>find
> > it nearly as pleasant.  THC is the most prevalent chemical, and perhaps
>the
> > one we understand the most, but the others shouldn't be dismissed or
> > overlooked.  Marinol (synthetic) is also nothing like smoking, and many
> > patients prefer the effects of smoking, if they even register the 
>marinol.
> >
> >
> > sarilion
> >
> >
> > ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> > To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> > For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 420!!!!BABY!!!!!!HA HA!!!!!!

The govmt medical whatever organizations created marinol as a substitute for
cannabis, trying to fight the idea of cannabis being medically beneficial.
Marinol I believe is supposed to have the benefits of consuming canabis, but
without all the side effects (getting high etc).

they were mainly just trying to stop people from finding simple relief. The
drug companies had to get their hands in the mix and they're not gardeners.
. .so what else could they do.

I've heard the question often about how the drug industry would regulate or
make their money if everyone was growing their own pot. . .the answer is,
they wouldn't. . . so it's basically another attempt of the govmt to control
this.
Also, cannabis is not an acceptable reason (even with a docs referral) for
someone to be able to have a pass on a drug test with a positive result. But
most groups accept marinol, even tho it most likely will produce a positive
result, but if you can prove your Rx, they'll let it slide.
So if you really wanted to, get the rx, keep it handy, and show it to the
drug people when you fail the pre employment test. I haven't tried that yet,
but it's such a sensitive issue, it's usually best to mask your urine with
something else, and avoid the subject all together.

aK

sorry if I tend to sound like a know it all. . .but cannabis is one subject
I know I know more than average about. . .but not everything. . . I've just
been involved with ocbc, cures not wars,the MM March group (may day is jay
day), various pro cannabis groups for years. . .so I tend to hear a wide
range of thoughts and ideas on the subject (especially from people who've
never tried it).

> >the only chemical in cannabis that really needs any mention is thc. like
> >tetrahydracannibinol . Some marijuana like plants (ruderalis something or
> >other) are very similar to cannabis but do not contain thc. Vaporizing is
> >the absolute best way to take thc, since there is basically no carbon
> >monoxide produced from the burning of plant matter, cuz thc "vaporizes"
at a
> >lower temp than the actual plant material burns, thus basically
eliminating
> >any and all of the negative effects of the "smoking" part.
> >In some coffee houses, vaporizers are allowed (not in us) because it's
> >technically not "smoking".
> >The us govmt has their own synthesized form of thc that can be prescribed
by
> >doctors in capsule, liquid or powder form.
>
> Vaporizing is perhaps the worst way to introduce cannabinoids into your
> body.  The sensation is entirely different from smoking, and I don't find
> it nearly as pleasant.  THC is the most prevalent chemical, and perhaps
the
> one we understand the most, but the others shouldn't be dismissed or
> overlooked.  Marinol (synthetic) is also nothing like smoking, and many
> patients prefer the effects of smoking, if they even register the marinol.

On Apr 20, 2004, at 12:41 PM, aK wrote:

> the effects from smoking and vaporizing are diffirent,
>
> carbon monoxide, and other chemicals you absorb from the burning of the
> plant matter also gives you that light headed, woozy sometimes kind of
> feeling, which thc itself isn't the main contributor to.
>
> like, you know how if sometimes you smoke a cig, and get a lil 
> nauseous,
> room spins, light headed n such. . . most of that is from smoking all 
> the
> crap from the burning of the papers and materials in the cig and not 
> the
> nicotine itself. (some might be sensitivity to nicotine, but mostly the
> burning stuff). Try this if you're a smoker. . .smoke an herbal 
> cigarette,
> or even just a paper itself or something. . .you'll get a lil short 
> term
> woozy buzz feeling. . .you just don't get the fulfillment from the 
> chemical
> you're craving, but still feel the lil side effects.
>
> vaporizing is also non cancerous, which is a huge plus, since carbon
> monoxide is one of the main causes of cancer in smokers, and the carbon
> monoxide is from the burning of the plant matter itself. Carbon 
> monoxide is
> poison to most all living creatures, and in small doses cause all those
> other heavyish effects you feel, esp with low quality buds.
>
> btw, I personally don't vaporize, even tho I know it's better. . .it's 
> not
> too convenient really.I don't own one of those contraptions, but have 
> used
> them before.

> > >Subject: Re: [sfraves] 420!!!!BABY!!!!!!HA HA!!!!!!
> > >Date: Tue, 20 Apr 2004 12:41:37 -0700
> > >
> > >the effects from smoking and vaporizing are diffirent,
> > >
> > >carbon monoxide, and other chemicals you absorb from the burning of the
> > >plant matter also gives you that light headed, woozy sometimes kind of
> > >feeling, which thc itself isn't the main contributor to.
> > >
> > >like, you know how if sometimes you smoke a cig, and get a lil 
>nauseous,
> > >room spins, light headed n such. . . most of that is from smoking all 
>the
> > >crap from the burning of the papers and materials in the cig and not 
>the
> > >nicotine itself. (some might be sensitivity to nicotine, but mostly the
> > >burning stuff). Try this if you're a smoker. . .smoke an herbal
>cigarette,
> > >or even just a paper itself or something. . .you'll get a lil short 
>term
> > >woozy buzz feeling. . .you just don't get the fulfillment from the
>chemical
> > >you're craving, but still feel the lil side effects.
> > >
> > >vaporizing is also non cancerous, which is a huge plus, since carbon
> > >monoxide is one of the main causes of cancer in smokers, and the carbon
> > >monoxide is from the burning of the plant matter itself. Carbon 
>monoxide
>is
> > >poison to most all living creatures, and in small doses cause all those
> > >other heavyish effects you feel, esp with low quality buds.
> > >
> > >btw, I personally don't vaporize, even tho I know it's better. . .it's
>not
> > >too convenient really.I don't own one of those contraptions, but have
>used
> > >them before.
> > >----- Original Message -----
> > >From: "Sarilion" <sarilion@sarilion.org>
> > >To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > >Sent: Tuesday, April 20, 2004 12:04 PM
> > >Subject: Re: [sfraves] 420!!!!BABY!!!!!!HA HA!!!!!!
> > >
> > >
> > > > At 11:34 AM 4/20/2004, aK wrote:
> > > > >the only chemical in cannabis that really needs any mention is thc.
> > >like
> > > > >tetrahydracannibinol . Some marijuana like plants (ruderalis
>something
> > >or
> > > > >other) are very similar to cannabis but do not contain thc.
>Vaporizing
> > >is
> > > > >the absolute best way to take thc, since there is basically no 
>carbon
> > > > >monoxide produced from the burning of plant matter, cuz thc
>"vaporizes"
> > >at a
> > > > >lower temp than the actual plant material burns, thus basically
> > >eliminating
> > > > >any and all of the negative effects of the "smoking" part.
> > > > >In some coffee houses, vaporizers are allowed (not in us) because
>it's
> > > > >technically not "smoking".
> > > > >The us govmt has their own synthesized form of thc that can be
> > >prescribed
> > >by
> > > > >doctors in capsule, liquid or powder form.
> > > >
> > > > Vaporizing is perhaps the worst way to introduce cannabinoids into
>your
> > > > body.  The sensation is entirely different from smoking, and I don't
> > >find
> > > > it nearly as pleasant.  THC is the most prevalent chemical, and
>perhaps
> > >the
> > > > one we understand the most, but the others shouldn't be dismissed or
> > > > overlooked.  Marinol (synthetic) is also nothing like smoking, and
>many
> > > > patients prefer the effects of smoking, if they even register the
> > >marinol.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > sarilion

beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

there now.  Some over $400.00.  A friend has an expensive high tech device 
that, it would seem to me, would be easily broken when coordination is 
somewhat impaired after a few tokes.  Also, with vaporizers, it's hard for

you're down...

X-Originating-IP: [68.121.210.40]
X-Originating-Email: [invibe@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: invibe@hotmail.com
From: "Brandon S." <invibe@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Tue, 20 Apr 2004 15:14:59 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <LAW10-F74y4zmLpLqae000006cd@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 20 Apr 2004 22:14:59.0442 (UTC) FILETIME=[EB5F6520:01C42724]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] nrr:  50 worst songs of all time

`We Built This City' tops Blender's 50 worst songs list

Tuesday, April 20, 2004
©2004 Associated Press

(04-20) 14:18 PDT NEW YORK (AP) --

Starship may have built this city on rock and roll, but Blender magazine is 
tearing it down, naming the band's "We Built This City" as the worst song 
ever.

Some tunes on the "50 Worst Songs Ever!" list were selected for their 
melodies, others "are wretchedly performed" and "quite a few don't make 
sense whatsoever," the magazine said.

The list, which appears in the May issue, includes songs by New Kids on the 
Block, Meat Loaf, The Doors, Lionel Richie, Hammer and The Beach Boys, among 
others.

Blender describes 1985's "We Built This City" as "the truly horrible sound 
of a band taking the corporate dollar while sneering at those who take the 
corporate dollar."

Starship lead singer Grace Slick says, "This is not me," when the magazine 
reminds her of the tune. "Now you're an actor. It's the same as Meryl Streep 
playing Joan of Arc."

Rounding out the top 10: "Achy Breaky Heart," Billy Ray Cyrus; "Everybody 
Have Fun Tonight" Wang Chung; "Rollin'," Limp Bizkit; "Ice Ice Baby," 
Vanilla Ice; "The Heart of Rock & Roll," Huey Lewis and the News; "Don't 
Worry Be Happy," Bobby McFerrin; "Party All the Time," Eddie Murphy; 
"American Life," Madonna; and "Ebony and Ivory," Paul McCartney and Stevie 
Wonder.

Other songs on the list: Toby Keith's "Courtesy of the Red, White and Blue" 
(No. 22); Whitney Houston's "Greatest Love of All" (No. 30); Ricky Martin's 
"She Bangs" (No. 39); Billy Joel's "We Didn't Start the Fire" (No. 41); 
Simon & Garfunkel's "The Sounds of Silence" (No. 42); The Beatles' 
"Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da" (No. 48); and Celine Dion's "My Heart Will Go On" (No. 
50).

Blender and VH1's TV special "50 Most Awesomely Bad Songs ... Ever" airs May 
12.




-------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.invibe.com/bam

Download the new mix online!

Subject: [sfraves] This Friday- DJ FLIGHT (Metalheadz, 1Xtra) @ SOMA Sessions

SOMA Sessions
Drum 'n Bass Fourth Fridays
AsiaSF, San Francisco
http://www.somasessions.com


THIS FRIDAY - April 23, 2004

** Discount $8 presale tickets available now at
http://www.somasessions.com **

DJ FLIGHT (BBC 1Xtra, Metalheadz - UK)
Nathalie Wright aka DJ Flight's accomplishments speak
for themselves; a resident at the legendary Metalheadz
Sunday Sessions and at Fabio's Swerve night in London,
host of her own radio show, "Next Chapter" on BBC's
1Xtra and, most recently, a co-producer with Breakage
as "Alias" for 31 Records.  All this plus a heavy DJ
touring schedule showcasing the latest cuts from all
flavors of upfront D&B adds up to a knockout Bay Area
debut.

ROHAN (Bassbin Recordings - Ireland)
At the heart of Ireland's Drum 'n Bass scene lies
Bassbin Recordings in Dublin. Co-founded by Rohan and
Naphta in 1996, the organization has grown to include
sublabels, Breakin, Solas and Looney Toonz and is home
to such talents as Beta 2, Zero Tolerance, Equinox and
Breakage. SOMA Sessions welcomes the return of the
Bassbin don for another rolling set of dubbed-out
floor smashers.

Resident Support:
SOUND:BOY (SOMA Sessions, Brass Tax)
DJ M (SOMA Sessions, Faultline)

** Discount $8 presale tickets available now at
http://www.somasessions.com **

Tickets:  $8 presale
Hours:  10:30pm - 3am
Entry:  21+ with photo ID
Bar:  $3 drink specials all night

AsiaSF
201 Ninth Street at Howard St
San Francisco, California 94103
AsiaSF serves 3-Star Cal-Asian cuisine in a festive
and stylish atmosphere.  For Sunday through Thursday
dinner reservations, please call 415.255.ASIA(2742)
from 1pm to 8pm or visit http://www.asiasf.com.

SOMA branding & print design by Ryan @ Citizen-7
http://www.citizen-7.com/


NEXT MONTH - Friday May 28, 2004
*** 1993-1997 Old Skool Jungle Night ***
_ DJ ABSTRACT (Phunckateck, Pneuma)
_ STAR EYES (Syrup, Groundscore)
_ 4REAL (Phuturo, Groundscore)
_ MC DUH (Phuturo, Groundscore)
_ SPECIAL AGENT UTAH (Offshore - NYC)

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: THE MOST NATURAL SELECTION

Because the wrapper "gay" is a construct of society-

<theory>
Both animals and humans both simply engage in
behaviors based upon their wants/needs and their
associated opportunity costs.  
Both animals and humans are both basically driven by a
chemical reward system, and a not-just-physical "pain"
sensation.
Both animals and humans are complicated enough, and
react to their environment enough, to develop
"preferences" that truly are unique to the individual.

What this means is that a person or animal is not
"gay" or "not gay"- it simply means that for lots of
humans and animals, their preferences have evolved to
the point that the benefits of engaging in homosexual
sex outweigh whatever the particular opportunity costs
might be.
In otherwords, it's just something that some people
like to do, based off of their being as a whole, and
not pinpointable down to genetics or environment
specifically, though those 2 factors certainly have a
say in it (as they do with all other activities that a
human or animal might engage in)
</theory>

Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) GOP Senator joins Democrats in calling for military draft

--Apple-Mail-8--1030073054
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed

	This is a bit of a downer, but...

 From http://russoforpresident.com/batm/index.php/2004/04/20/p181:

THE MASK COMES OFF: AARON RUSSO BLASTS GOP CALL FOR MILITARY DRAFT

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
APRIL 20, 2004

Contact: Stephen Gordon
stephen@russoforpresident.com

In the first public display of bi-partisan congressional sentiment for 
conscription, US Senator Chuck Hagel (R-NE) today floated the idea of a 
draft to address the deteriorating military situation in Iraq. "Why 
shouldn't we ask all of our citizens to bear some responsibility and 
pay some price?" Hagel asked the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. He 
holds that conscription would force "our citizens to understand the 
intensity and depth of challenges we face."

The spectre of conscription has loomed over Washington for months, 
despite denials from the Bush administration that a draft was under 
consideration.

With re-enlistment rates plummeting and recruitment flat, the 
administration has quietly begun staffing Selective Service boards. US 
commanders in Iraq have called for an immediate deployment of 10,000 
additional troops to bolster the American occupation, and Secretary of 
Defense Donald Rumsfeld has announced his intention to expand the Army 
by 30,000 next year, with no details as to how.

Democrats have been calling for conscription with a slightly louder 
voice for more than a year, receiving round condemnation from 
Republican legislators until now. US Representative Charles Rangel 
(D-NY) and US Senator Ernest F. Hollings (D-SC) introduced a draft bill 
in early 2003 which remains in committee. US Senator Hillary Clinton, 
in a March 25th speech at the Brookings Institution, referred to a 
volunteer military as "inadequate."

Democratic presidential hopeful John Kerry (D-MA), called for 
"mandatory national service" on his campaign web site until last week, 
when Libertarian presidential candidate Aaron Russo's highlighting of 
the issue embarrassed him into removing the language.

"A Washington Times reporter called me, asking where Kerry's use of the 
word 'mandatory' existed on his web site. I looked and it was gone. We 
have collected a Google cache proving it once existed, and will be 
posting it on our web site soon", commented Russo spokesperson Stephen 
Gordon.

"This isn't speculative," Russo says. "The draft is coming. Republicans 
and Democrats have been trying to put off the public discussion until 
after the November elections, but there's no doubt that the American 
people will be threatened with conscription by the end of this year."

Independent candidate Ralph Nader's voice joined Russo's last week in a 
press release aimed at American students. "Young Americans need to know 
that a train is coming," said Nader, "and it could run over their 
generation."

Russo greets Hagel's trial balloon, and Nader's engagement of the issue 
with enthusiasm. "For six months now, I've been telling Americans about 
the coming draft, and the Republicans and Democrats have denied it out 
of one side of their mouths while talking around it with the other. 
It's coming, and it's time we had a real public discussion about it. If 
Bush and Kerry want this issue to go away, all they have to do is make 
clear, public pledges that there will be no draft."

Russo's campaign web site (www.russoforpresident.com)features an 
anti-draft petition which has collected thousands of signatures.

"The question is this simple," Russo says. "Should the government have 
the power to take our sons and daughters, against their will, in order 
to rescue themselves from the situation they themselves brought about 
with an immoral, unwinnable war? The answer is no. The war in Iraq was 
a mistake a year ago, and it's a mistake today. Not one more drop of 
American blood to save our politicians from their own wrong-headed 
policies.

"Americans have always responded in their country's time of need. If 
this war was justifiable, the recruiting offices would have lines 
around the block of young men and women eager to serve. The fact that 
they don't should tell our politicians that it's time to re-think what 
they're doing. But the draft? No. It's not right and it can't be 
allowed to happen."

And with both "major" parties now on record as supporting conscription? 
"That just shows how disconnected from reality the Democrats and 
Republicans are," says Russo. "And it demonstrates the clear necessity 
of electing a president to this November who will put the nation back 
on the path to peace and prosperity."

As the Libertarian Party's likely nominee, Russo is the only 
presidential candidate opposed to the draft and to the war in Iraq whom 
Americans will find on the ballot in all fifty states this November. 
His platform includes immediate withdrawal of US forces from the Middle 
East.

###
--Apple-Mail-8--1030073054--

>> > (04-20) 14:18 PDT NEW YORK (AP) --
>> >
>> > Starship may have built this city on rock and roll,
>> but
>> > Blender magazine is
>> > tearing it down, naming the band's "We Built This
>> City"
>> > as the worst song
>> > ever.
>> >
>> > Some tunes on the "50 Worst Songs Ever!" list were
>> > selected for their
>> > melodies, others "are wretchedly performed" and "quite
>> > a few don't make
>> > sense whatsoever," the magazine said.
>> >
>> > The list, which appears in the May issue, includes
>> > songs by New Kids on the
>> > Block, Meat Loaf, The Doors, Lionel Richie, Hammer and
>> > The Beach Boys, among
>> > others.
>> >
>> > Blender describes 1985's "We Built This City" as "the
>> > truly horrible sound
>> > of a band taking the corporate dollar while sneering
>> at
>> > those who take the
>> > corporate dollar."
>> >
>> > Starship lead singer Grace Slick says, "This is not
>> > me," when the magazine
>> > reminds her of the tune. "Now you're an actor. It's
>> the
>> > same as Meryl Streep
>> > playing Joan of Arc."
>> >

>> Ray
>> > Cyrus; "Everybody
>> > Have Fun Tonight" Wang Chung; "Rollin'," Limp Bizkit;
>> > "Ice Ice Baby,"
>> > Vanilla Ice; "The Heart of Rock & Roll," Huey Lewis
>> and
>> > the News; "Don't
>> > Worry Be Happy," Bobby McFerrin; "Party All the Time,"
>> > Eddie Murphy;
>> > "American Life," Madonna; and "Ebony and Ivory," Paul
>> > McCartney and Stevie
>> > Wonder.
>> >

>> > Red, White and Blue"
>> > (No. 22); Whitney Houston's "Greatest Love of All"
>> (No.
>> > 30); Ricky Martin's
>> > "She Bangs" (No. 39); Billy Joel's "We Didn't Start
>> the
>> > Fire" (No. 41);

>> > The Beatles'

>> > Heart Will Go On" (No.
>> > 50).

>> > Songs ... Ever" airs May

>From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) GOP Senator joins Democrats in calling for 
>military draft
>Date: Tue, 20 Apr 2004 16:30:25 -0700
>
>	This is a bit of a downer, but...
>
>>From http://russoforpresident.com/batm/index.php/2004/04/20/p181:
>
>THE MASK COMES OFF: AARON RUSSO BLASTS GOP CALL FOR MILITARY DRAFT
>
>FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
>APRIL 20, 2004
>
>Contact: Stephen Gordon
>stephen@russoforpresident.com
>
>In the first public display of bi-partisan congressional sentiment for 
>conscription, US Senator Chuck Hagel (R-NE) today floated the idea of a 
>draft to address the deteriorating military situation in Iraq. "Why 
>shouldn't we ask all of our citizens to bear some responsibility and pay 
>some price?" Hagel asked the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. He holds 
>that conscription would force "our citizens to understand the intensity and 
>depth of challenges we face."
>
>The spectre of conscription has loomed over Washington for months, despite 
>denials from the Bush administration that a draft was under consideration.
>
>With re-enlistment rates plummeting and recruitment flat, the 
>administration has quietly begun staffing Selective Service boards. US 
>commanders in Iraq have called for an immediate deployment of 10,000 
>additional troops to bolster the American occupation, and Secretary of 
>Defense Donald Rumsfeld has announced his intention to expand the Army by 
>30,000 next year, with no details as to how.
>
>Democrats have been calling for conscription with a slightly louder voice 
>for more than a year, receiving round condemnation from Republican 
>legislators until now. US Representative Charles Rangel (D-NY) and US 
>Senator Ernest F. Hollings (D-SC) introduced a draft bill in early 2003 
>which remains in committee. US Senator Hillary Clinton, in a March 25th 
>speech at the Brookings Institution, referred to a volunteer military as 
>"inadequate."
>
>Democratic presidential hopeful John Kerry (D-MA), called for "mandatory 
>national service" on his campaign web site until last week, when 
>Libertarian presidential candidate Aaron Russo's highlighting of the issue 
>embarrassed him into removing the language.
>
>"A Washington Times reporter called me, asking where Kerry's use of the 
>word 'mandatory' existed on his web site. I looked and it was gone. We have 
>collected a Google cache proving it once existed, and will be posting it on 
>our web site soon", commented Russo spokesperson Stephen Gordon.
>
>"This isn't speculative," Russo says. "The draft is coming. Republicans and 
>Democrats have been trying to put off the public discussion until after the 
>November elections, but there's no doubt that the American people will be 
>threatened with conscription by the end of this year."
>
>Independent candidate Ralph Nader's voice joined Russo's last week in a 
>press release aimed at American students. "Young Americans need to know 
>that a train is coming," said Nader, "and it could run over their 
>generation."
>
>Russo greets Hagel's trial balloon, and Nader's engagement of the issue 
>with enthusiasm. "For six months now, I've been telling Americans about the 
>coming draft, and the Republicans and Democrats have denied it out of one 
>side of their mouths while talking around it with the other. It's coming, 
>and it's time we had a real public discussion about it. If Bush and Kerry 
>want this issue to go away, all they have to do is make clear, public 
>pledges that there will be no draft."
>
>Russo's campaign web site (www.russoforpresident.com)features an anti-draft 
>petition which has collected thousands of signatures.
>
>"The question is this simple," Russo says. "Should the government have the 
>power to take our sons and daughters, against their will, in order to 
>rescue themselves from the situation they themselves brought about with an 
>immoral, unwinnable war? The answer is no. The war in Iraq was a mistake a 
>year ago, and it's a mistake today. Not one more drop of American blood to 
>save our politicians from their own wrong-headed policies.
>
>"Americans have always responded in their country's time of need. If this 
>war was justifiable, the recruiting offices would have lines around the 
>block of young men and women eager to serve. The fact that they don't 
>should tell our politicians that it's time to re-think what they're doing. 
>But the draft? No. It's not right and it can't be allowed to happen."
>
>And with both "major" parties now on record as supporting conscription? 
>"That just shows how disconnected from reality the Democrats and 
>Republicans are," says Russo. "And it demonstrates the clear necessity of 
>electing a president to this November who will put the nation back on the 
>path to peace and prosperity."
>
>As the Libertarian Party's likely nominee, Russo is the only presidential 
>candidate opposed to the draft and to the war in Iraq whom Americans will 
>find on the ballot in all fifty states this November. His platform includes 
>immediate withdrawal of US forces from the Middle East.

On Tue, Apr 20, 2004 at 04:30:25PM -0700, Starchild wrote:
> 	This is a bit of a downer, but...
> 
> From http://russoforpresident.com/batm/index.php/2004/04/20/p181:
> 
> THE MASK COMES OFF: AARON RUSSO BLASTS GOP CALL FOR MILITARY DRAFT
> 
> FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
> APRIL 20, 2004
> 
> Contact: Stephen Gordon
> stephen@russoforpresident.com
> 
> In the first public display of bi-partisan congressional sentiment for 
> conscription, US Senator Chuck Hagel (R-NE) today floated the idea of a 
> draft to address the deteriorating military situation in Iraq. "Why 
> shouldn't we ask all of our citizens to bear some responsibility and 
> pay some price?" Hagel asked the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. He 
> holds that conscription would force "our citizens to understand the 
> intensity and depth of challenges we face."
> 
> The spectre of conscription has loomed over Washington for months, 
> despite denials from the Bush administration that a draft was under 
> consideration.
> 
> With re-enlistment rates plummeting and recruitment flat, the 
> administration has quietly begun staffing Selective Service boards. US 
> commanders in Iraq have called for an immediate deployment of 10,000 
> additional troops to bolster the American occupation, and Secretary of 
> Defense Donald Rumsfeld has announced his intention to expand the Army 
> by 30,000 next year, with no details as to how.
> 
> Democrats have been calling for conscription with a slightly louder 
> voice for more than a year, receiving round condemnation from 
> Republican legislators until now. US Representative Charles Rangel 
> (D-NY) and US Senator Ernest F. Hollings (D-SC) introduced a draft bill 
> in early 2003 which remains in committee. US Senator Hillary Clinton, 
> in a March 25th speech at the Brookings Institution, referred to a 
> volunteer military as "inadequate."
> 
> Democratic presidential hopeful John Kerry (D-MA), called for 
> "mandatory national service" on his campaign web site until last week, 
> when Libertarian presidential candidate Aaron Russo's highlighting of 
> the issue embarrassed him into removing the language.
> 
> "A Washington Times reporter called me, asking where Kerry's use of the 
> word 'mandatory' existed on his web site. I looked and it was gone. We 
> have collected a Google cache proving it once existed, and will be 
> posting it on our web site soon", commented Russo spokesperson Stephen 
> Gordon.
> 
> "This isn't speculative," Russo says. "The draft is coming. Republicans 
> and Democrats have been trying to put off the public discussion until 
> after the November elections, but there's no doubt that the American 
> people will be threatened with conscription by the end of this year."
> 
> Independent candidate Ralph Nader's voice joined Russo's last week in a 
> press release aimed at American students. "Young Americans need to know 
> that a train is coming," said Nader, "and it could run over their 
> generation."
> 
> Russo greets Hagel's trial balloon, and Nader's engagement of the issue 
> with enthusiasm. "For six months now, I've been telling Americans about 
> the coming draft, and the Republicans and Democrats have denied it out 
> of one side of their mouths while talking around it with the other. 
> It's coming, and it's time we had a real public discussion about it. If 
> Bush and Kerry want this issue to go away, all they have to do is make 
> clear, public pledges that there will be no draft."
> 
> Russo's campaign web site (www.russoforpresident.com)features an 
> anti-draft petition which has collected thousands of signatures.
> 
> "The question is this simple," Russo says. "Should the government have 
> the power to take our sons and daughters, against their will, in order 
> to rescue themselves from the situation they themselves brought about 
> with an immoral, unwinnable war? The answer is no. The war in Iraq was 
> a mistake a year ago, and it's a mistake today. Not one more drop of 
> American blood to save our politicians from their own wrong-headed 
> policies.
> 
> "Americans have always responded in their country's time of need. If 
> this war was justifiable, the recruiting offices would have lines 
> around the block of young men and women eager to serve. The fact that 
> they don't should tell our politicians that it's time to re-think what 
> they're doing. But the draft? No. It's not right and it can't be 
> allowed to happen."
> 
> And with both "major" parties now on record as supporting conscription? 
> "That just shows how disconnected from reality the Democrats and 
> Republicans are," says Russo. "And it demonstrates the clear necessity 
> of electing a president to this November who will put the nation back 
> on the path to peace and prosperity."
> 
> As the Libertarian Party's likely nominee, Russo is the only 
> presidential candidate opposed to the draft and to the war in Iraq whom 
> Americans will find on the ballot in all fifty states this November. 
> His platform includes immediate withdrawal of US forces from the Middle 
> East.
> 
> ###

Jefferson Airplane    cool
Jefferson Starship     pretty cool and then pretty sucky
Starship     incredibly sucky

I've been following Paul Kantner and whoever else he's with for a long time, 
going back to Haight St festivals in the late 60s. To me, "We Built This City" 
is the absolute nadir of the Jefferson Airplane/Starship repertoire. Awful 
corporate rock, not written by the band but by hack songwriters, and sung by the 
soulless Mickey Thomas. But is it one of the 50 worst songs of all time? 
That's so subjective. I can think of worse! 

After all, there are a lot of terrible songs that nobody knows because they 
never became hits. To be a "huge" terrible song, somebody had to like it. This 
is really a list of "50 Really Popular Songs That I Always Hated." Some of 
these songs wouldn't be remembered with such hatred if they hadn't been 
overplayed so much when new, or repeated endlessly on "classic rock" stations. 

Some classic rock songs even end up as trance mixes, lol.  You know how Mars 
never met a remix of a rock song he didn't like...   :)    

-------------------------------1082505061--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 420!!!!BABY!!!!!!HA HA!!!!!!

Aryck,

	I'm a fan of holistic medicine and herbal cures/remedies in many 
respects, but humans are a *part* of nature, not outside it. The 
distinction between "natural" and "artificial" is ultimately an 
artificial one, and trying to draw a solid line between the two makes 
no sense. "Natural" carcinogens will cause cancer just as surely as 
man-made carcinogens.

	To say that "any natural non processed chemical is vastly superior to 
anything created or manufactured" is sheer ignorance, imho. Are you 
telling me that if you knew you were going to get polio, you wouldn't 
want the polio vaccine because it was "manufactured?" That you'd take 
your chances on some Chinese medicine or something? That you wouldn't 
want penicillin for any of its numerous beneficial anti-biotic 
applications? That tobacco, a natural drug, is better than ecstasy, a 
manufactured drug? Etcetera, etcetera...

Groove on,
					<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) "Assault weapon" confiscation turns violent in Boston

	This was supposed to go out yesterday... Happy (belated) Patriots Day.

					<<< Starchild >>>


"Assault weapon" confiscation turns violent in Boston
Scores Killed, Hundreds Injured As Para-Military Extremists Riot

BOSTON, April 19 - National Guard units seeking to confiscate a cache 
of recently banned assault weapons were ambushed on April 19th by 
elements of a para-military extremist faction. Military and law 
enforcement sources estimated that 72 were killed and more than 20 
injured before government forces were compelled to withdraw.

Speaking after the clash, Massachusetts Governor Thomas Gage declared 
that the extremist faction, which was made up of local citizens, has 
links to the radical right-wing tax protest movement. Gage blamed the 
extremists for recent incidents of vandalism directed against internal 
revenue offices.

The governor, who described the group's organizers as "criminals," 
issued an executive order authorizing the summary arrest of any 
individual who has interfered with the government's efforts to secure 
law and order.

The military raid on the extremist arsenal followed wide-spread refusal 
by the local citizenry to turn over recently outlawed assault weapons. 
Gage issued a ban on military-style assault weapons and ammunition 
earlier in the week. This decision followed a meeting in early April 
between government and military leaders at which the governor 
authorized the forcible confiscation of illegal arms. One government 
official, speaking on condition of anonymity, pointed out that "none of 
these people would have been killed had the extremists obeyed the law 
and turned their weapons over voluntarily."

"Government troops initially succeeded in confiscating a large supply 
of outlawed weapons and ammunition. However, troops attempting to seize 
arms and ammunition in Lexington met with resistance from heavily-armed 
extremists who had been tipped off regarding the government's plans.

During a tense standoff in Lexington's town park, National Guard 
Colonel Francis Smith, commander of the government operation, ordered 
the armed group to surrender and return to their homes. The impasse was 
broken by a single shot, which was reportedly fired by one of the 
right-wing extremists. Eight civilians were killed in the ensuing 
exchange.

Ironically, the local citizenry blamed government forces rather than 
the extremists for the civilian deaths. Before order could be restored, 
armed citizens from surrounding areas had descended upon the guard 
units. Colonel Smith, finding his forces overmatched by the armed mob, 
ordered a retreat.

Governor Gage has called upon citizens to support the state/national 
joint task force in its effort to restore law and order. The governor 
has also demanded the surrender of those responsible for planning and 
leading the attack against the government troops. Samuel Adams, Paul 
Revere, and John Hancock, who have been identified as "ringleaders" of 
the extremist faction, remain at large.

The price of freedom is eternal vigilance."
-- Thomas Jefferson

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> That's so subjective. I can think of worse! 
> 
> After all, there are a lot of terrible songs that nobody
> knows because they 
> never became hits. To be a "huge" terrible song, somebody had
> to like it. This 
> is really a list of "50 Really Popular Songs That I Always
> Hated." Some of 
> these songs wouldn't be remembered with such hatred if they
> hadn't been 
> overplayed so much when new, or repeated endlessly on
> "classic rock" stations. 
> 
> Some classic rock songs even end up as trance mixes, lol. 
> You know how Mars 
> never met a remix of a rock song he didn't like...   :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) GOP Senator joins Democrats in calling for military draft

-------------------------------1082508071
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

There are definite plans in the works for a selective type of draft. What, 
exactly, I don't know. It doesn't mean they'll do it but the planning is going 
on. People with some specific skill that the military wants. People who can 
speak Arabic, Farsi, or Pashto. People who retired from the military and have 
experience in some area where the current forces are weak. This could really 
happen. 

The war is going so badly now that a general draft is being discussed. 
Earlier, the White House was strongly against a draft because people remember 
Vietnam and how anti-draft protests became such a huge issue. Charles Rangel, a 
Democrat, started talking about a draft a year ago as a way to point out how 
minorities would die at a disproportionate rate in the all-volunteer armed services 
if we went on to an extended war (which we're in now -- it's not "over" as 
Bush said many months ago). A lot of young people with limited opportunities 
join the military as a way to get ahead, while rich kids go to college or get 
businesses handed to them by daddy. When you have a draft (in theory, at least), 
the burden is spread over a wider spectrum of society. Of course, the really 
privileged kids would still get out of having to serve. They could just emulate 
our fearless leader:  get daddy to pull strings so they could get into the 
National Guard AND away from combat, and then pull more strings so they can 
quit. 

Now, with the military stretched so thin, a draft is becoming a real 
possibility. However, all the parents remember Vietnam, and Bush doesn't want millions 
of moms showing up at the White House to protest.  

Also, i want to point out that there are many women in the military now. 
There would be no way to draft men without drafting women too; there would be 
constitutional challenges. I don't think the American public will stand for the 
drafting of women. Only in extremely rare circumstances have nations sent their 
women to war. It just doesn't make sense to kill off the women, because future 
generations would be lost. So, starting a general draft is a real hornet's 
nest, and if you see Republicans urging one, yeah ... it's time to move to 
Canada.

Even WITH Celine Dion, Canada looks pretty good about now. 

-------------------------------1082508071--

Anything that burns that was previously alive gives off carbon 
monoxide.  I've never heard claims before that there's any correlation 
between CO and cancer.  I have smoked many things - herbal cigs, 
cloves,  and tobacco straight out of a glass pipe - I can say with 
certainty that the lightheaded / nauseas feeling comes from the 
nicotine.  If you want to get a rush from O2 dep. just hyperventilate.  I 
do emissions testing.. on cars.. and I smoke.  I can tell the difference 
between the cigarette and the CO.


sarilion

At 12:41 PM 4/20/2004, aK wrote:

>the effects from smoking and vaporizing are diffirent,
>
>carbon monoxide, and other chemicals you absorb from the burning of the
>plant matter also gives you that light headed, woozy sometimes kind of
>feeling, which thc itself isn't the main contributor to.
>
>like, you know how if sometimes you smoke a cig, and get a lil nauseous,
>room spins, light headed n such. . . most of that is from smoking all the
>crap from the burning of the papers and materials in the cig and not the
>nicotine itself. (some might be sensitivity to nicotine, but mostly the
>burning stuff). Try this if you're a smoker. . .smoke an herbal cigarette,
>or even just a paper itself or something. . .you'll get a lil short term
>woozy buzz feeling. . .you just don't get the fulfillment from the chemical
>you're craving, but still feel the lil side effects.
>
>vaporizing is also non cancerous, which is a huge plus, since carbon
>monoxide is one of the main causes of cancer in smokers, and the carbon
>monoxide is from the burning of the plant matter itself. Carbon monoxide is
>poison to most all living creatures, and in small doses cause all those
>other heavyish effects you feel, esp with low quality buds.
>
>btw, I personally don't vaporize, even tho I know it's better. . .it's not
>too convenient really.I don't own one of those contraptions, but have used
>them before.

At 03:42 PM 4/20/2004, Nathan Seven wrote:

>Because the wrapper "gay" is a construct of society-
>
><theory>
>Both animals and humans both simply engage in
>behaviors based upon their wants/needs and their
>associated opportunity costs.
>Both animals and humans are both basically driven by a
>chemical reward system, and a not-just-physical "pain"
>sensation.
>Both animals and humans are complicated enough, and
>react to their environment enough, to develop
>"preferences" that truly are unique to the individual.
>
>What this means is that a person or animal is not
>"gay" or "not gay"- it simply means that for lots of
>humans and animals, their preferences have evolved to
>the point that the benefits of engaging in homosexual
>sex outweigh whatever the particular opportunity costs
>might be.
>In otherwords, it's just something that some people
>like to do, based off of their being as a whole, and
>not pinpointable down to genetics or environment
>specifically, though those 2 factors certainly have a
>say in it (as they do with all other activities that a
>human or animal might engage in)
></theory>
>

This is how I feel about things,

I'm not christian/catholic or whatever, I do not believe "god" created
everything on earth. I do believe however that the universe was designed to
fuel/feed itself. If it was a simple world, without heavily influence by
manmade instruments, I believe the world has everything to support itself,
and its inhabitants supported naturally. Disease, and whatever issues could
be cured from various products all around us. But our world is at a point
where so much damage has already been done. Diseases and such have surpassed
natures ability to heal, and its our fault basically. We created stronger
diseases that the world isn't designed to support, we've made organisms
stronger, that could withstand any previous normal means for treatment, with
our industry, air pullution, chemicals we've created n such.

Thats the onl;y drawback really, that you can live a natural type of
existance in efforts to keep away and avoid illness now better than you can
immediately cure it. You only need strong antibiotics because diseases are
stronger now because of our efforts to treat them and such.

The natural method is more of a preventative means, and it works, but still
the world more or less has emphasized finding manufactured remedies for
things instead of exploring for components which are already here that do
the same if not better.

I'm allergic to penicillin actually. And isn't a carcinogen a bi-product of
processing various materials ? Like do cancinogens grow on/in trees ?

And yes, I do prefer natural means to things like antibiotics. but to
confess, the natural means are sometimes processed in some fashion, like
mineral supplements, herbal supplements. . .but these elements are also
present and naturally occuring in materials we were originally meant to
eat/drink.
Also again, little research has been done on these methods.
I have fought off illnesses with copper, and silver that no man made
chemical or antibiotic could even touch. My father is 78 and has had issues
from meds he's been taking for years that destroy his skin, make it really
thin, bruises, tears super easily. . .he takes meds which are supposed to
help that also, and has for years, but they don't work. I started him on
copper supplements (copper is required by the body to build connective
tissues) and he doesn't bruise at all much anymore, his skin is healing,
doesn't tear. . . it even firms skin and removes wrinkles.

I haven't had a cold in almost 2 years, haven't had the flu since I was like
12, and never get flu shots.

Silver is a wonderful detoxifier. Theres actually like 80 minerals we
absolutely need on a day to day basis, to ward off things like arthritis,
bone deterioration, illnesses, and most everyone in the world is deficient.
But a major source of all of these in large amounts is also a naturally
occurring substance. Most people don't believe it, but if people intake
(don't even pay attention to the RDA) enough of the required minerals, they
WILL notice that they hardly ever get sick anymore, and they WILL live much
much longer lives.

people argue that science has helped us live longer lives, and in ways it
has, but science has also helped us find and mine/grow/harvest naturally
occurring remedies to most all ailments also, which hundreds of years ago
weren't really thought of. When was the last time you saw anything about the
old west, and people taking their vitamins, or eating their vegetables. . .
it's the meat eating thats killed people with high blood pressure, and the
chemical companies who are called on to try to mask the real issue.

about tobacco vs extasy. . . tobacco obviously wasn't meant for an extasy
type of enlightenment.Lots of things have their specific purpose, and
broader purposes. I feel shrooms gave me a much deeper sense of extasy
(spiritual/emotional) than I ever felt with E. And it was a more
natural/real/totally understood feeling, not the fake type of happy e gives
you. But extasy in knowing your purpose, being fulfilled, being "ok" with
everything everywhere. I know I emphasize minerals in this post, but other
naturally occurring means are also suitable remedies for anything from pain,
stress, bleeding, skin healing, infection prevention and so forth.

basically the point is, everything we need is around us, but less than there
used to be cuz of the population of course. It's our environment that we
created and live in which create some people's needs for manufactured
remedies. Nature has the cure to everything, and we would never need quick
vaccines for super illnesses that can kill you in a matter of days, if we
didn't create an environment where the disease needed to develop in a way to
become so unnaturally strong. Otherwise the natural way would work for
everyone, but if someone doesn't follow the rules, they get the super
diseases we helped develop and need the super cures we had to create because
of ourselves.

sorta thing

: )

aK


> Aryck,
>
> I'm a fan of holistic medicine and herbal cures/remedies in many
> respects, but humans are a *part* of nature, not outside it. The
> distinction between "natural" and "artificial" is ultimately an
> artificial one, and trying to draw a solid line between the two makes
> no sense. "Natural" carcinogens will cause cancer just as surely as
> man-made carcinogens.
>
> To say that "any natural non processed chemical is vastly superior to
> anything created or manufactured" is sheer ignorance, imho. Are you
> telling me that if you knew you were going to get polio, you wouldn't
> want the polio vaccine because it was "manufactured?" That you'd take
> your chances on some Chinese medicine or something? That you wouldn't
> want penicillin for any of its numerous beneficial anti-biotic
> applications? That tobacco, a natural drug, is better than ecstasy, a
> manufactured drug? Etcetera, etcetera...

  Gospel Music Online

--=====================_14976815==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Thou Shalt Not Steal? Christian Teens Seen Pirating Gospel Music Online

By: Frank Meyer

04-20-2004

CYBERSPACE - The Gospel Music Association isn't exactly singing 
"hallelujah" over the news that avowedly Christian teenagers are getting 
gospel music through Internet downloads and CD burnings at a rate 
comparable to that of secular music fans in the vast peer-to-peer community.

Association president John Styll told the Dallas Morning News he was 
surprised and disappointed to learn of Christian teenagers behaving so 
similarly to non-Christian teens when it came to music downloading.

But the downloaders themselves don't quite see it that way, Agape Press 
said. "Talks with (Christian) teens reveal that many simply do not think of 
it as stealing when they copy CDs or download free music from the Internet, 
or even when they share such unauthorized copies with others," the news 
service said.

A poll taken by the Barna Group, which performs tracking and surveying from 
a religious perspective, says one in 10 Christian teens they surveyed 
consider online music piracy to be morally wrong and 64 percent of them 
said they participated in one or another kind of music piracy.

Agape also said that "many" adult believers "and even church leaders" think 
Christian teenagers downloading gospel music from cyberspace is no big 
deal. "Some suggest," the news service said, "that getting the gospel 
message out should matter more to industry professionals than getting paid 
anyway."

Tell that to Barry Landis, president of gospel label Word Records. "You 
would never steal Bibles to give them away," he told the Morning News. "You 
shouldn't steal Christian music to give away, either."



http://www.avn.com/index.php?Primary_Navigation=Articles&Action=View_Article&Content_ID=81302


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

-Helen Keller

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

>From: JonnyR@aol.com
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) GOP Senator joins Democrats in calling for 
>military draft
>Date: Tue, 20 Apr 2004 20:41:11 EDT
>
>There are definite plans in the works for a selective type of draft. What,
>exactly, I don't know. It doesn't mean they'll do it but the planning is 
>going
>on. People with some specific skill that the military wants. People who can
>speak Arabic, Farsi, or Pashto. People who retired from the military and 
>have
>experience in some area where the current forces are weak. This could 
>really
>happen.
>
>The war is going so badly now that a general draft is being discussed.
>Earlier, the White House was strongly against a draft because people 
>remember
>Vietnam and how anti-draft protests became such a huge issue. Charles 
>Rangel, a
>Democrat, started talking about a draft a year ago as a way to point out 
>how
>minorities would die at a disproportionate rate in the all-volunteer armed 
>services
>if we went on to an extended war (which we're in now -- it's not "over" as
>Bush said many months ago). A lot of young people with limited 
>opportunities
>join the military as a way to get ahead, while rich kids go to college or 
>get
>businesses handed to them by daddy. When you have a draft (in theory, at 
>least),
>the burden is spread over a wider spectrum of society. Of course, the 
>really
>privileged kids would still get out of having to serve. They could just 
>emulate
>our fearless leader:  get daddy to pull strings so they could get into the
>National Guard AND away from combat, and then pull more strings so they can
>quit.
>
>Now, with the military stretched so thin, a draft is becoming a real
>possibility. However, all the parents remember Vietnam, and Bush doesn't 
>want millions
>of moms showing up at the White House to protest.
>
>Also, i want to point out that there are many women in the military now.
>There would be no way to draft men without drafting women too; there would 
>be
>constitutional challenges. I don't think the American public will stand for 
>the
>drafting of women. Only in extremely rare circumstances have nations sent 
>their
>women to war. It just doesn't make sense to kill off the women, because 
>future
>generations would be lost. So, starting a general draft is a real hornet's
>nest, and if you see Republicans urging one, yeah ... it's time to move to
>Canada.
>
>Even WITH Celine Dion, Canada looks pretty good about now.
