>At 03:42 PM 4/20/2004, Nathan Seven wrote:
>
>>Because the wrapper "gay" is a construct of society-
>>
>><theory>
>>Both animals and humans both simply engage in
>>behaviors based upon their wants/needs and their
>>associated opportunity costs.
>>Both animals and humans are both basically driven by a
>>chemical reward system, and a not-just-physical "pain"
>>sensation.
>>Both animals and humans are complicated enough, and
>>react to their environment enough, to develop
>>"preferences" that truly are unique to the individual.
>>
>>What this means is that a person or animal is not
>>"gay" or "not gay"- it simply means that for lots of
>>humans and animals, their preferences have evolved to
>>the point that the benefits of engaging in homosexual
>>sex outweigh whatever the particular opportunity costs
>>might be.
>>In otherwords, it's just something that some people
>>like to do, based off of their being as a whole, and
>>not pinpointable down to genetics or environment
>>specifically, though those 2 factors certainly have a
>>say in it (as they do with all other activities that a
>>human or animal might engage in)
>></theory>
>>

"Brandon S." <invibe@hotmail.com> wrote:
`We Built This City' tops Blender's 50 worst songs list

Tuesday, April 20, 2004
©2004 Associated Press

(04-20) 14:18 PDT NEW YORK (AP) --

Starship may have built this city on rock and roll, but Blender magazine is 
tearing it down, naming the band's "We Built This City" as the worst song 
ever.

Some tunes on the "50 Worst Songs Ever!" list were selected for their 
melodies, others "are wretchedly performed" and "quite a few don't make 
sense whatsoever," the magazine said.

The list, which appears in the May issue, includes songs by New Kids on the 
Block, Meat Loaf, The Doors, Lionel Richie, Hammer and The Beach Boys, among 
others.

Blender describes 1985's "We Built This City" as "the truly horrible sound 
of a band taking the corporate dollar while sneering at those who take the 
corporate dollar."

Starship lead singer Grace Slick says, "This is not me," when the magazine 
reminds her of the tune. "Now you're an actor. It's the same as Meryl Streep 
playing Joan of Arc."

Rounding out the top 10: "Achy Breaky Heart," Billy Ray Cyrus; "Everybody 
Have Fun Tonight" Wang Chung; "Rollin'," Limp Bizkit; "Ice Ice Baby," 
Vanilla Ice; "The Heart of Rock & Roll," Huey Lewis and the News; "Don't 
Worry Be Happy," Bobby McFerrin; "Party All the Time," Eddie Murphy; 
"American Life," Madonna; and "Ebony and Ivory," Paul McCartney and Stevie 
Wonder.

Other songs on the list: Toby Keith's "Courtesy of the Red, White and Blue" 
(No. 22); Whitney Houston's "Greatest Love of All" (No. 30); Ricky Martin's 
"She Bangs" (No. 39); Billy Joel's "We Didn't Start the Fire" (No. 41); 
Simon & Garfunkel's "The Sounds of Silence" (No. 42); The Beatles' 
"Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da" (No. 48); and Celine Dion's "My Heart Will Go On" (No. 
50).

Blender and VH1's TV special "50 Most Awesomely Bad Songs ... Ever" airs May 
12.

below is the BSP that Andy sent out.



***********************************************



Liquidvinyldjs.com is very proud to present..


 MAY DAY! .
Saturday, May 1st 2004
8:00pm - 4:00am
500 Person Capacity
1 ROOM VIRGIN LOCATION - Centrally located in the Bay Area!
ALL RESPONSIBLE AGES WELCOME!


With MAY DAY!, we would like to celebrate the beginnings of Summer with a
very intimate 1 room experience! Join us as we kick the summer of just right
in a

brand new location, close to everyone here in the Bay Area!


DJ's for the night:


|| DJ LUNA-C
[Kniteforce North American Tour || KFA/Kniteforce, UK] - SPECIAL BIRTHDAY
SET!!
We are very proud to bring DJ LUNA-C to the Bay for his special Birthday
Set. This will be the last stop on his very exclusive Kniteforce North
American

Tour, and this night just happens to be on his birthday! He's coming
prepared to showcase a very special set exclusive to us here in San
Francisco, which is

sure to absolutely blow you away. If you've seen LUNA-C at any of our past
events, you know he will completely take the roof off the place and have you

moving, from the first record to the last! Please allow us to wish our good
friend a very Happy Birthday here in the Bay!

|| CLOUDSKIPPER vs. THE NICE GUYS
[Raw Elements/Kniteforce/Liquidvinyldjs.com vs. Liquidvinyldjs.com/K-12] -
3X6 INSANITY SET!
In what is sure to be one of the more talked about sets this year,
Cloudskipper faces off against The Nice Guys. Relatively little is known
about The Nice

Guys, except, well, they're nice. In any case, be prepared for in your face
up front hardcore, a lot of unreleased music, as well as onstage antics that
can

only be described as pure madness!

|| DJ TRONIC
[Resistance Recordings/Liquidvinyldjs.com/CHR]
In preparation for his anticipated European tour, Tronic's set is going to
be chalked full of brand new hard hittin material! This will be his last
local

appearance before he heads off to Europe for 2 weeks, so be ready for the
Hard Beats!

|| MAJERE
[Elektrosorcery, DJMajere.com] - SPECIAL TRANCECORE/FREEFORM SET!
In a rare appearance playing trancecore/freeform, Majere is taking a bit of
a step back into his roots. Expect a set of fast and hard mind melting
music,

which can only be appreciated by those ready to move!

|| THE DOCTOR & MC FADER
[Liquidvinyldjs.com/Bayraves.com || Gravitycrew.com/Emceeds]
Quite possibly one of the best DnB/Jungle DJ's in Northern California, The
Doctor has become a household name. You can catch him almost every weekend
droppin

those hard hittin tracks all over! In tow is the MC called Fader, in which
really needs no introduction. These two go together like steak and eggs,
like

butter on toast, like.. well you get the idea!

|| DJ J-MARR
[Liquidvinyldjs.com/Bayraves.com] - FAREWELL SET!
The man, the myth, the legend. Need we say more? Known from up and down the
West Coast for not only his music, but also his energetic charisma, J-Marr
is a

legend in the scene. This will be his last set behind the decks, ending a
tenure other DJ's can only dream about. Be there to witness J-Marr rocking
in his

usual manner, for the last time!

|| CARLOS ALFONZO vs. RECLIPSE
[Resistance Recordings/Soop Recordings vs. D&A Music/Bayraves]
The battle of the BBQ Iron Chef Carlos and the Maddest Mad DJ around, this
will be a treat to all those who appreciated hard techno... and we do mean
HARD.

These two will come out swingin' with pure dancefloor driven material.. get
ready to rock!

|| LEON COOK vs. PETER GO-ZANIA!
[Hardscience/Logik Pro Audio]
These two have been rapidly rising among the Hardcore faithful here in the
Bay, and with their crowd rockin performances and talent behind the decks,
it's

really no wonder why. Expect a set full of freeform and upfront Hardcore
material only these guys bring to the table.

|| DJ DMS
[Oakland Bounce/Dream Crew]


>From the same people who brought you HAPPY TOGETHER 1 & 2, OVERLOAD 1, 2, &
3, SUMMER ROCKIN, and GET UP!. MAY DAY will be an extremely special night to
us,

where we are celebrating the coming of summer, as well as our good friend
LUNA-C's birthday. If you've loved the vibe and sharing of the music we've
had at

past events, this will be no different!!


MAY DAY SOUND PROVIDED BY: HARDSCIENCE
MAY DAY VISUALS & LASERS PROVIDED BY: STIMULIGHTS.COM


VERY LIMITED $5 Presale Tickets will go on sale Wednesday, March 31st at the
following locations:

SKILLS DJ WORKSHOP  |    BERKELEY   |  510.704.9876
SOLID GROOVES       |  SANTA CLARA  |  408.248.6399
FREQUENCY 8         | SAN FRANCISCO |  415.221.4142
STRAIGHT HITS       |    FREMONT    |  510.745.7843
IN THA MIX          |   SACRAMENTO  |  916.442.0499
ONLINE              |  http://www.groovetickets.com

Once those $5 Presales sell out, they will go to $10. Once those $10 tickets
sell out, we will have tickets at the door for $15! All of our previous
events

have sold out, and we don't expect this to be different! Make sure you get a
presale ticket for guaranteed entry!

Giveaways from most of the DJ's playing! CD's, Vinyl, T-Shirts, maybe even
some dishes! ;)

If you've enjoyed our events in the past, this will be no different! Don't
miss out on MAY DAY!! Thank you and we appreciate your support!


For more information:

(415) 820-1454

http://www.liquidvinyldjs.com


We look forward to seeing you all there for MAY DAY!

Date: Thu, 22 Apr 2004 10:24:26 -0700

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;

Subject: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS

--=====================_1560193==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS

TABLE OF CONTENTS

1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE

2.  MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION

3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES AT STATE ASSEMBLY

4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB

5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/


1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE

The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state legislation
to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to make it out
of committee
at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of passage this
year.

While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the bill,
statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433, claiming that
it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of the
State.

Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last call in
San
Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that their
Department
could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those officers were
speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as individuals,
but
their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.

In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a drunk
driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting for the
legislation.
Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but the
format of the assembly did not offer much chance for rebuttal.  Many
democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against Drunk
Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough votes to
move the bill out of committee.

San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with Assemblymembers
Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of Supervisor members
and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that was clearly
not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of Sacramento.
We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento legislative
process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we more clearly
understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next year.

The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals who
showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to Sacramento.  We'd
also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for all
their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.  Make
sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls Assembly
elections.

2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION

After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events in San
Francisco
may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an after-hours
permit.
The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by Supervisors
Bevan
Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into law by
Mayor
Newsom.

The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it was vetoed
by
Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored by the
San
Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's Liam Shy.
Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission, who
revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at City Hall
to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It is great
to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and taking
control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully, we'll be
seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.

3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO

While our last call legislation was defeated at the State Assembly,
the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the State
Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC licensing
hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with bipartisan
support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee last
week.

When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance of a
liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a hearing
regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often times this
hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process with the
protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes the time
and money of nightclubs and the ABC.

AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues to show
some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for unreasonable
concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor that they
find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to approve
the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this case, to
ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but would be
required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have a
hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC and
nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a hearing.


4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB

The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April 22th at 3
PM in
room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning Commission and
is a
request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
Entertainment
permit.

The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the lounge
contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to have a
permit to
have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in Bernal
Heights.
The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the permit a
few
neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right now they
are
doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not granted.
  Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar, are
supportive of the permit request.

This is a case where the owner has invested much money and effort in
renovations  and soundproofing and turned  what some referred to as a
"scary
biker bar" into a very cool lounge.   Yet still some folks don't want
a DJ
to play in his small bar.

That brings us to the hearing  on Thursday.  Please show your support
of San
Francisco Culture; tell the government to support the entertainment
community by showing up at the hearing.   You will not be required to
speak;
your presence in the audience will be enough.

4.  Please join the SFLNC and help us continue our work on behalf of
San Francisco Nightlife http://sflnc.com/index/donate/



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_1560193==.ALT--

The National Electronic Dance Music Conference
And
Remix Magazine

     We are proud to announce Remix Magazine's( http://www.remixmag.com =
) role as a sponsor for the National Electronic Dance Music Conference.=20


***The National Electronic Dance Music Conference***=20

http://www.nedmc.com

***New registration fees online***

Early registration specials are online and available until April 30th.

Regular registration-Reg. $275 Until April 30th- $210
Economy/Student registration-Reg. $150 Until April 30th- $110

8x10 Exhibit booth- Reg. $1500 Until April 30th- $1150
8x20 Exhibit booth- Reg. $2250 Until April 30th- $2000

We have also included new options for those wanting to attend or =
participate in the NEDMC. Check out the website for more info.

  Please visit http://www.nedmc.com/seminars.html for information =
regarding our seminars and panels.

  In Washington D.C. on September 3rd through 6th 2004, the National EDM =
Conference will take place at the Omni Shoreham Hotel. We will be =
utilizing the entire space of the hotel to bring you the best possible =
environment to network with others in the EDM industry. We will be =
hosting all genres, from hip hop to hardcore, from house to industrial. =
As well, we will also be showcasing the newest technologies for the =
coming year and beyond, as well as offering seminars and focus groups to =
help dj's, producers, and gear manufacturer's push the envelope of music =
production and presentation.

  We have chosen D.C. to host this event because it is a central =
location on the east coast, offering easy access from many spots around =
the country, as well as being home to one of the nations largest EDM =
focused communities. We will be working closely with all businesses =
involved to ensure top notch production on all sides for after hours =
events, as well as demonstrations of said products. There will be also =
attendee only events, so be sure to sign up early to gain access to =
these events, held exclusively in the hotel.

  If you are interested in speaking on a panel or having your company =
host a seminar, please email seminars@nedmc.com

  To stay up to date on all the happenings of the NEDMC, including =
seminar information, hotel and registration discounts, and event =
information, please visit http://www.nedmc.com/contact.html

  For further information on either sponsoring, exhibiting, attending, =
or hosting an official event, please email info@nedmc.com , or visit our =
site at http://www.nedmc.com .

  If you would like to help out with the NEDMC, please e-mail =
work@nedmc.com for intern and volunteering opportunites.=20

  For booking consideration, please send all cd's to:=20
NEDMC Booking
4331 Farm House Lane
Farifax, VA 22032


http://www.nedmc.com
The National Electronic Dance Music Conference
P.O. Box 3616
Fairfax, VA 22038
O:703-503-1020
F:703-503-1269
info@nedmc.com

>--- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> > SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
> >
> > TABLE OF CONTENTS
> >
> > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> >
> > 2.  MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> >
> > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES AT STATE ASSEMBLY
> >
> > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> >
> > 5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
> >
> >
> > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> >
> > The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state
> > legislation
> > to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to
> > make it out
> > of committee
> > at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of
> > passage this
> > year.
> >
> > While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the
> > bill,
> > statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433,
> > claiming that
> > it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of
> > the
> > State.
> >
> > Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last
> > call in
> > San
> > Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that
> > their
> > Department
> > could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those
> > officers were
> > speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as
> > individuals,
> > but
> > their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
> >
> > In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a
> > drunk
> > driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting
> > for the
> > legislation.
> > Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but
> > the
> > format of the assembly did not offer much chance for
> > rebuttal.  Many
> > democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against
> > Drunk
> > Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough
> > votes to
> > move the bill out of committee.
> >
> > San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with
> > Assemblymembers
> > Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of
> > Supervisor members
> > and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that
> > was clearly
> > not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of
> > Sacramento.
> > We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento
> > legislative
> > process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we
> > more clearly
> > understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next
> > year.
> >
> > The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals
> > who
> > showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to
> > Sacramento.  We'd
> > also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for
> > all
> > their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.
> > Make
> > sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls
> > Assembly
> > elections.
> >
> > 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> >
> > After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events
> > in San
> > Francisco
> > may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an
> > after-hours
> > permit.
> > The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by
> > Supervisors
> > Bevan
> > Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into
> > law by
> > Mayor
> > Newsom.
> >
> > The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it
> > was vetoed
> > by
> > Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored
> > by the
> > San
> > Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's
> > Liam Shy.
> > Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission,
> > who
> > revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at
> > City Hall
> > to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It
> > is great
> > to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and
> > taking
> > control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully,
> > we'll be
> > seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
> >
> > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
> >
> > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State
> > Assembly,
> > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the
> > State
> > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC
> > licensing
> > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with
> > bipartisan
> > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee
> > last
> > week.
> >
> > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance
> > of a
> > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a
> > hearing
> > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often
> > times this
> > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process
> > with the
> > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes
> > the time
> > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
> >
> > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues
> > to show
> > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for
> > unreasonable
> > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor
> > that they
> > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to
> > approve
> > the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this
> > case, to
> > ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but
> > would be
> > required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have
> > a
> > hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC
> > and
> > nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a
> > hearing.
> >
> >
> > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> >
> > The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April
> > 22th at 3
> > PM in
> > room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning
> > Commission and
> > is a
> > request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
> > Entertainment
> > permit.
> >
> > The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the
> > lounge
> > contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to
> > have a
> > permit to
> > have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in
> > Bernal
> > Heights.
> > The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the
> > permit a
> > few
> > neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right
> > now they
> > are
> > doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not
> > granted.
> >   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar,
> > are
> >
>=== message truncated ===

"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

>--- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> > SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS

> >

> >
> > 5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
> >
> >
> > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> >
> > The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state
> > legislation
> > to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to
> > make it out
> > of committee
> > at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of
> > passage this
> > year.
> >
> > While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the
> > bill,
> > statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433,
> > claiming that
> > it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of
> > the
> > State.
> >
> > Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last
> > call in
> > San
> > Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that
> > their
> > Department
> > could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those
> > officers were
> > speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as
> > individuals,
> > but
> > their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
> >
> > In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a
> > drunk
> > driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting
> > for the
> > legislation.
> > Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but
> > the
> > format of the assembly did not offer much chance for
> > rebuttal.  Many
> > democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against
> > Drunk
> > Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough
> > votes to
> > move the bill out of committee.
> >
> > San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with
> > Assemblymembers
> > Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of
> > Supervisor members
> > and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that
> > was clearly
> > not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of
> > Sacramento.
> > We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento
> > legislative
> > process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we
> > more clearly
> > understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next
> > year.
> >
> > The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals
> > who
> > showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to
> > Sacramento.  We'd
> > also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for
> > all
> > their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.
> > Make
> > sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls
> > Assembly
> > elections.
> >
> > 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> >
> > After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events
> > in San
> > Francisco
> > may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an
> > after-hours
> > permit.
> > The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by
> > Supervisors
> > Bevan
> > Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into
> > law by
> > Mayor
> > Newsom.
> >
> > The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it
> > was vetoed
> > by
> > Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored
> > by the
> > San
> > Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's
> > Liam Shy.
> > Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission,
> > who
> > revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at
> > City Hall
> > to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It
> > is great
> > to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and
> > taking
> > control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully,
> > we'll be
> > seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
> >
> > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
> >
> > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State
> > Assembly,
> > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the
> > State
> > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC
> > licensing
> > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with
> > bipartisan
> > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee
> > last
> > week.
> >
> > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance
> > of a
> > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a
> > hearing
> > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often
> > times this
> > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process
> > with the
> > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes
> > the time
> > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
> >
> > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues
> > to show
> > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for
> > unreasonable
> > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor
> > that they
> > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to
> > approve
> > the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this
> > case, to
> > ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but
> > would be
> > required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have
> > a
> > hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC
> > and
> > nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a
> > hearing.
> >
> >
> > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> >
> > The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April
> > 22th at 3
> > PM in
> > room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning
> > Commission and
> > is a
> > request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
> > Entertainment
> > permit.
> >
> > The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the
> > lounge
> > contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to
> > have a
> > permit to
> > have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in
> > Bernal
> > Heights.
> > The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the
> > permit a
> > few
> > neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right
> > now they
> > are
> > doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not
> > granted.
> >   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar,
> > are
> >
>=== message truncated ===
>
>
>
>

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club,
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to
that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

From: "michael, the red stickman" <red_stickman@yahoo.com>

Subject: [sfraves] 1015 folsom (was: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS)


> in a similar vein: when driving by 1015 folsom last saturday,
> we noticed that there was a "notice of suspension" on the
> doors.  obviously the place was empty.
>
> not sure if this was discussed on-list or not (i've been kind
> of busy) but i was wondering what was up.
>
> m
>
> --- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> > SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
> >
> > TABLE OF CONTENTS
> >
> > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> >
> > 2.  MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> >
> > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES AT STATE ASSEMBLY
> >
> > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> >
> > 5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
> >
> >
> > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> >
> > The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state
> > legislation
> > to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to
> > make it out
> > of committee
> > at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of
> > passage this
> > year.
> >
> > While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the
> > bill,
> > statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433,
> > claiming that
> > it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of
> > the
> > State.
> >
> > Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last
> > call in
> > San
> > Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that
> > their
> > Department
> > could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those
> > officers were
> > speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as
> > individuals,
> > but
> > their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
> >
> > In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a
> > drunk
> > driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting
> > for the
> > legislation.
> > Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but
> > the
> > format of the assembly did not offer much chance for
> > rebuttal.  Many
> > democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against
> > Drunk
> > Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough
> > votes to
> > move the bill out of committee.
> >
> > San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with
> > Assemblymembers
> > Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of
> > Supervisor members
> > and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that
> > was clearly
> > not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of
> > Sacramento.
> > We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento
> > legislative
> > process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we
> > more clearly
> > understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next
> > year.
> >
> > The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals
> > who
> > showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to
> > Sacramento.  We'd
> > also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for
> > all
> > their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.
> > Make
> > sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls
> > Assembly
> > elections.
> >
> > 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> >
> > After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events
> > in San
> > Francisco
> > may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an
> > after-hours
> > permit.
> > The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by
> > Supervisors
> > Bevan
> > Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into
> > law by
> > Mayor
> > Newsom.
> >
> > The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it
> > was vetoed
> > by
> > Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored
> > by the
> > San
> > Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's
> > Liam Shy.
> > Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission,
> > who
> > revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at
> > City Hall
> > to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It
> > is great
> > to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and
> > taking
> > control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully,
> > we'll be
> > seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
> >
> > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
> >
> > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State
> > Assembly,
> > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the
> > State
> > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC
> > licensing
> > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with
> > bipartisan
> > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee
> > last
> > week.
> >
> > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance
> > of a
> > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a
> > hearing
> > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often
> > times this
> > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process
> > with the
> > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes
> > the time
> > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
> >
> > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues
> > to show
> > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for
> > unreasonable
> > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor
> > that they
> > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to
> > approve
> > the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this
> > case, to
> > ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but
> > would be
> > required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have
> > a
> > hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC
> > and
> > nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a
> > hearing.
> >
> >
> > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> >
> > The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April
> > 22th at 3
> > PM in
> > room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning
> > Commission and
> > is a
> > request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
> > Entertainment
> > permit.
> >
> > The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the
> > lounge
> > contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to
> > have a
> > permit to
> > have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in
> > Bernal
> > Heights.
> > The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the
> > permit a
> > few
> > neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right
> > now they
> > are
> > doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not
> > granted.
> >   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar,
> > are
> >

> > > after-hours

> > > we'll be
> > > seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
> > >
> > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
> > >
> > > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State
> > > Assembly,
> > > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the
> > > State
> > > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC
> > > licensing
> > > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with
> > > bipartisan
> > > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee
> > > last
> > > week.
> > >
> > > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance
> > > of a
> > > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a
> > > hearing
> > > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often
> > > times this
> > > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process
> > > with the
> > > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes
> > > the time
> > > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
> > >
> > > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues
> > > to show
> > > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for
> > > unreasonable
> > > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor
> > > that they
> > > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to
> > > approve
> > > the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this
> > > case, to
> > > ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but
> > > would be
> > > required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have
> > > a
> > > hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC
> > > and
> > > nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a
> > > hearing.
> > >
> > >
> > > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> > >
> > > The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April
> > > 22th at 3
> > > PM in

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 1015 folsom (was: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS)

Mezzanine and Ruby Skye are the replacements for 1015 and the big talent
plays at both of those venues. 1015 needs a serious overhaul of its image.
1015 to me is damn near the same as a SoundFactory or City Nights type of
venue. It's the place that everyone goes to because it's big and that's all
the out-of-towners know. There is so much that I miss talent wise and all
because 1015 is a POS venue with a trashy ass, fucked up, crowd that ruins
the place.

:: r ::

> > >
> > > m
> > >
> > > --- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> > > > SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
> > > >
> > > > TABLE OF CONTENTS
> > > >
> > > > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> > > >
> > > > 2.  MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> > > >
> > > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES AT STATE ASSEMBLY
> > > >
> > > > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> > > >
> > > > 5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> > > >
> > > > The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state
> > > > legislation
> > > > to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to
> > > > make it out
> > > > of committee
> > > > at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of
> > > > passage this
> > > > year.
> > > >
> > > > While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the
> > > > bill,
> > > > statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433,
> > > > claiming that
> > > > it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of
> > > > the
> > > > State.
> > > >
> > > > Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last
> > > > call in
> > > > San
> > > > Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that
> > > > their
> > > > Department
> > > > could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those
> > > > officers were
> > > > speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as
> > > > individuals,
> > > > but
> > > > their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
> > > >
> > > > In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a
> > > > drunk
> > > > driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting
> > > > for the
> > > > legislation.
> > > > Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but
> > > > the
> > > > format of the assembly did not offer much chance for
> > > > rebuttal.  Many
> > > > democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against
> > > > Drunk
> > > > Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough
> > > > votes to
> > > > move the bill out of committee.
> > > >
> > > > San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with
> > > > Assemblymembers
> > > > Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of
> > > > Supervisor members
> > > > and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that
> > > > was clearly
> > > > not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of
> > > > Sacramento.
> > > > We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento
> > > > legislative
> > > > process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we
> > > > more clearly
> > > > understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next
> > > > year.
> > > >
> > > > The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals
> > > > who
> > > > showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to
> > > > Sacramento.  We'd
> > > > also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for
> > > > all
> > > > their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.
> > > > Make
> > > > sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls
> > > > Assembly
> > > > elections.
> > > >
> > > > 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> > > >
> > > > After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events
> > > > in San
> > > > Francisco
> > > > may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an
> > > > after-hours
> > > > permit.
> > > > The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by
> > > > Supervisors
> > > > Bevan
> > > > Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into
> > > > law by
> > > > Mayor
> > > > Newsom.
> > > >
> > > > The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it
> > > > was vetoed
> > > > by
> > > > Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored
> > > > by the
> > > > San
> > > > Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's
> > > > Liam Shy.
> > > > Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission,
> > > > who
> > > > revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at
> > > > City Hall
> > > > to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It
> > > > is great
> > > > to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and
> > > > taking
> > > > control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully,
> > > > we'll be
> > > > seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
> > > >
> > > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
> > > >
> > > > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State
> > > > Assembly,
> > > > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the
> > > > State
> > > > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC
> > > > licensing
> > > > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with
> > > > bipartisan
> > > > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee
> > > > last
> > > > week.
> > > >
> > > > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance
> > > > of a
> > > > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a
> > > > hearing
> > > > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often
> > > > times this
> > > > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process
> > > > with the
> > > > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes
> > > > the time
> > > > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
> > > >
> > > > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues
> > > > to show
> > > > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for
> > > > unreasonable
> > > > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor
> > > > that they
> > > > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to
> > > > approve
> > > > the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this
> > > > case, to
> > > > ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but
> > > > would be
> > > > required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have
> > > > a
> > > > hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC
> > > > and
> > > > nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a
> > > > hearing.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> > > >
> > > > The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April
> > > > 22th at 3
> > > > PM in
> > > > room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning
> > > > Commission and
> > > > is a
> > > > request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
> > > > Entertainment
> > > > permit.
> > > >
> > > > The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the
> > > > lounge
> > > > contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to
> > > > have a
> > > > permit to
> > > > have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in
> > > > Bernal
> > > > Heights.
> > > > The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the
> > > > permit a
> > > > few
> > > > neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right
> > > > now they
> > > > are
> > > > doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not
> > > > granted.
> > > >   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar,
> > > > are
> > > >
> > > === message truncated ===
> > >
> > >
> > >

> > > > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> > > >
> > > > The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state
> > > > legislation
> > > > to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to
> > > > make it out
> > > > of committee
> > > > at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of
> > > > passage this
> > > > year.
> > > >
> > > > While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the
> > > > bill,
> > > > statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433,
> > > > claiming that
> > > > it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of
> > > > the
> > > > State.
> > > >
> > > > Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last
> > > > call in
> > > > San
> > > > Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that
> > > > their
> > > > Department
> > > > could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those
> > > > officers were
> > > > speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as
> > > > individuals,
> > > > but
> > > > their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
> > > >
> > > > In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a
> > > > drunk
> > > > driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting
> > > > for the
> > > > legislation.
> > > > Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but
> > > > the
> > > > format of the assembly did not offer much chance for
> > > > rebuttal.  Many
> > > > democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against
> > > > Drunk
> > > > Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough
> > > > votes to
> > > > move the bill out of committee.
> > > >
> > > > San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with
> > > > Assemblymembers
> > > > Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of
> > > > Supervisor members
> > > > and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that
> > > > was clearly
> > > > not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of
> > > > Sacramento.
> > > > We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento
> > > > legislative
> > > > process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we
> > > > more clearly
> > > > understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next
> > > > year.
> > > >
> > > > The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals
> > > > who
> > > > showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to
> > > > Sacramento.  We'd
> > > > also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for
> > > > all
> > > > their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.
> > > > Make
> > > > sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls
> > > > Assembly
> > > > elections.
> > > >
> > > > 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> > > >
> > > > After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events
> > > > in San
> > > > Francisco
> > > > may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an
> > > > after-hours
> > > > permit.
> > > > The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by
> > > > Supervisors
> > > > Bevan
> > > > Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into
> > > > law by
> > > > Mayor
> > > > Newsom.
> > > >
> > > > The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it
> > > > was vetoed
> > > > by
> > > > Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored
> > > > by the
> > > > San
> > > > Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's
> > > > Liam Shy.
> > > > Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission,
> > > > who
> > > > revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at
> > > > City Hall
> > > > to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It
> > > > is great
> > > > to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and
> > > > taking
> > > > control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully,
> > > > we'll be
> > > > seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
> > > >
> > > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
> > > >
> > > > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State
> > > > Assembly,
> > > > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the
> > > > State
> > > > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC
> > > > licensing
> > > > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with
> > > > bipartisan
> > > > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee
> > > > last
> > > > week.
> > > >
> > > > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance
> > > > of a
> > > > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a
> > > > hearing
> > > > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often
> > > > times this
> > > > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process
> > > > with the
> > > > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes
> > > > the time
> > > > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
> > > >
> > > > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues
> > > > to show
> > > > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for
> > > > unreasonable
> > > > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor
> > > > that they
> > > > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to
> > > > approve
> > > > the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this
> > > > case, to
> > > > ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but
> > > > would be
> > > > required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have
> > > > a
> > > > hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC
> > > > and
> > > > nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a
> > > > hearing.
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> > > >
> > > > The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April
> > > > 22th at 3
> > > > PM in
> > > > room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning
> > > > Commission and
> > > > is a
> > > > request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
> > > > Entertainment
> > > > permit.
> > > >
> > > > The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the
> > > > lounge
> > > > contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to
> > > > have a
> > > > permit to
> > > > have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in
> > > > Bernal
> > > > Heights.
> > > > The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the
> > > > permit a
> > > > few
> > > > neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right
> > > > now they
> > > > are
> > > > doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not
> > > > granted.
> > > >   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar,

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 1015 folsom (was: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS)


I just don't like 1015 in general. It's the logistics of the building that 
makes it sh@tty to me. If I'm getting to party to great music in a quality 
venue, I could not care less how trashy the tourist clubbers around me are. 
It's the structure itself that kind of ruins 1015 to me.

Ruby Skye and Mezzanine are the replacements and are my favorite clubs in 
the city and besides for small shows thrown by friends, the only large clubs 
in the city I'll go to.

Now if they start getting Carl Cox, Oliver Lieb, Derrick Carter, & Misstress 
Barbara at those two clubs (I know, Richie Hawtin @ Mezzanine was a start) 
instead of having them play at 1015 every time they come to town, there will 
really be no need for 1015 anymore. Although, an overhaul of the club could 
change everything. But would be too expensive, even for them...

> > > > in a similar vein: when driving by 1015 folsom last saturday,

> > > > of busy) but i was wondering what was up.
> > > >
> > > > m
> > > >
> > > > --- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> > > > > SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
> > > > >
> > > > > TABLE OF CONTENTS
> > > > >
> > > > > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> > > > >
> > > > > 2.  MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> > > > >
> > > > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES AT STATE ASSEMBLY
> > > > >
> > > > > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> > > > >
> > > > > 5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> > > > >
> > > > > The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state
> > > > > legislation
> > > > > to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to
> > > > > make it out
> > > > > of committee
> > > > > at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of
> > > > > passage this
> > > > > year.
> > > > >
> > > > > While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the
> > > > > bill,
> > > > > statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433,
> > > > > claiming that
> > > > > it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of
> > > > > the
> > > > > State.
> > > > >
> > > > > Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last
> > > > > call in
> > > > > San
> > > > > Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that
> > > > > their
> > > > > Department
> > > > > could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those
> > > > > officers were
> > > > > speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as
> > > > > individuals,
> > > > > but
> > > > > their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
> > > > >
> > > > > In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a
> > > > > drunk
> > > > > driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting
> > > > > for the
> > > > > legislation.
> > > > > Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but
> > > > > the
> > > > > format of the assembly did not offer much chance for
> > > > > rebuttal.  Many
> > > > > democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against
> > > > > Drunk
> > > > > Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough
> > > > > votes to
> > > > > move the bill out of committee.
> > > > >
> > > > > San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with
> > > > > Assemblymembers
> > > > > Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of
> > > > > Supervisor members
> > > > > and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that
> > > > > was clearly
> > > > > not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of
> > > > > Sacramento.
> > > > > We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento
> > > > > legislative
> > > > > process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we
> > > > > more clearly
> > > > > understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next
> > > > > year.
> > > > >
> > > > > The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals
> > > > > who
> > > > > showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to
> > > > > Sacramento.  We'd
> > > > > also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for
> > > > > all
> > > > > their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.
> > > > > Make
> > > > > sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls
> > > > > Assembly
> > > > > elections.
> > > > >
> > > > > 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> > > > >
> > > > > After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events
> > > > > in San
> > > > > Francisco
> > > > > may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an
> > > > > after-hours
> > > > > permit.
> > > > > The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by
> > > > > Supervisors
> > > > > Bevan
> > > > > Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into
> > > > > law by
> > > > > Mayor
> > > > > Newsom.
> > > > >
> > > > > The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it
> > > > > was vetoed
> > > > > by
> > > > > Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored
> > > > > by the
> > > > > San
> > > > > Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's
> > > > > Liam Shy.
> > > > > Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission,
> > > > > who
> > > > > revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at
> > > > > City Hall
> > > > > to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It
> > > > > is great
> > > > > to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and
> > > > > taking
> > > > > control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully,
> > > > > we'll be
> > > > > seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
> > > > >
> > > > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
> > > > >
> > > > > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State
> > > > > Assembly,
> > > > > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the
> > > > > State
> > > > > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC
> > > > > licensing
> > > > > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with
> > > > > bipartisan
> > > > > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee
> > > > > last
> > > > > week.
> > > > >
> > > > > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance
> > > > > of a
> > > > > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a
> > > > > hearing
> > > > > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often
> > > > > times this
> > > > > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process
> > > > > with the
> > > > > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes
> > > > > the time
> > > > > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
> > > > >
> > > > > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues
> > > > > to show
> > > > > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for
> > > > > unreasonable
> > > > > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor
> > > > > that they
> > > > > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to
> > > > > approve
> > > > > the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this
> > > > > case, to
> > > > > ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but
> > > > > would be
> > > > > required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have
> > > > > a
> > > > > hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC
> > > > > and
> > > > > nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a
> > > > > hearing.
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> > > > >
> > > > > The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April
> > > > > 22th at 3
> > > > > PM in
> > > > > room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning
> > > > > Commission and
> > > > > is a
> > > > > request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
> > > > > Entertainment
> > > > > permit.
> > > > >
> > > > > The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the
> > > > > lounge
> > > > > contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to
> > > > > have a
> > > > > permit to
> > > > > have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in
> > > > > Bernal
> > > > > Heights.
> > > > > The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the
> > > > > permit a
> > > > > few
> > > > > neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right
> > > > > now they
> > > > > are
> > > > > doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not
> > > > > granted.
> > > > >   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar,
> > > > > are
> > > > >
> > > > === message truncated ===
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > __________________________________
> > > > Do you Yahoo!?

> > > > http://photos.yahoo.com/ph/print_splash

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS

Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> said...
> 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE

I was there, and although I was dissapointed in the outcome,
there was something that dissapointed me even more.

I suppose it is "business as usual", but while this committee
met, the individual members felt free to come and go as they
pleased. It was like watching a continual dance of musical
chairs for two hours. Almost half of that time, the number
present wasn't even enough for a chorum.

In my ideal world, I suppose, the members of the committee are
actually required to attend the committee meetings. They'd
vote on what was brought in front of them. And they wouldn't
show up for the last 5 minutes of a 50 minute presentation by
10 different people, and then vote. Or attend the whole thing,
and not vote.

If that's the way our state allows its paid assembly members
to act, then it's even more broken than I thought.

In 11 years of observing California politics, this is the
most deeply dissapointing thing I have ever seen. These
representatives sorely misused and worse, underused their
positions. They represented no one. They don't deserve to
be paid.

Sean

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> > > > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES AT STATE ASSEMBLY
> > > > >
> > > > > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> > > > >
> > > > > 5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> > > > >
> > > > > The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state
> > > > > legislation
> > > > > to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to
> > > > > make it out
> > > > > of committee
> > > > > at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of
> > > > > passage this
> > > > > year.
> > > > >
> > > > > While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the
> > > > > bill,
> > > > > statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433,
> > > > > claiming that
> > > > > it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of
> > > > > the
> > > > > State.
> > > > >
> > > > > Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last
> > > > > call in
> > > > > San
> > > > > Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that
> > > > > their
> > > > > Department
> > > > > could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those
> > > > > officers were
> > > > > speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as
> > > > > individuals,
> > > > > but
> > > > > their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
> > > > >
> > > > > In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a
> > > > > drunk
> > > > > driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting
> > > > > for the
> > > > > legislation.
> > > > > Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but
> > > > > the
> > > > > format of the assembly did not offer much chance for
> > > > > rebuttal.  Many
> > > > > democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against
> > > > > Drunk
> > > > > Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough
> > > > > votes to
> > > > > move the bill out of committee.
> > > > >
> > > > > San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with
> > > > > Assemblymembers
> > > > > Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of
> > > > > Supervisor members
> > > > > and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that
> > > > > was clearly
> > > > > not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of
> > > > > Sacramento.
> > > > > We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento
> > > > > legislative
> > > > > process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we
> > > > > more clearly
> > > > > understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next
> > > > > year.
> > > > >
> > > > > The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals
> > > > > who
> > > > > showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to
> > > > > Sacramento.  We'd
> > > > > also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for
> > > > > all
> > > > > their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.
> > > > > Make
> > > > > sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls
> > > > > Assembly
> > > > > elections.
> > > > >
> > > > > 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> > > > >
> > > > > After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events
> > > > > in San
> > > > > Francisco
> > > > > may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an
> > > > > after-hours
> > > > > permit.
> > > > > The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by
> > > > > Supervisors
> > > > > Bevan
> > > > > Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into
> > > > > law by
> > > > > Mayor
> > > > > Newsom.
> > > > >
> > > > > The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it
> > > > > was vetoed
> > > > > by
> > > > > Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored
> > > > > by the
> > > > > San
> > > > > Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's
> > > > > Liam Shy.
> > > > > Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission,
> > > > > who
> > > > > revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at
> > > > > City Hall
> > > > > to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It
> > > > > is great
> > > > > to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and
> > > > > taking
> > > > > control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully,
> > > > > we'll be
> > > > > seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
> > > > >
> > > > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
> > > > >
> > > > > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State
> > > > > Assembly,
> > > > > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the
> > > > > State
> > > > > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC
> > > > > licensing
> > > > > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with
> > > > > bipartisan
> > > > > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee
> > > > > last
> > > > > week.
> > > > >
> > > > > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance
> > > > > of a
> > > > > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a
> > > > > hearing
> > > > > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often
> > > > > times this
> > > > > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process
> > > > > with the
> > > > > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes
> > > > > the time
> > > > > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
> > > > >
> > > > > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues
> > > > > to show
> > > > > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for
> > > > > unreasonable
> > > > > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor
> > > > > that they
> > > > > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to
> > > > > approve
> > > > > the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this
> > > > > case, to
> > > > > ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but
> > > > > would be
> > > > > required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have
> > > > > a
> > > > > hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC
> > > > > and
> > > > > nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a
> > > > > hearing.
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> > > > >
> > > > > The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April
> > > > > 22th at 3
> > > > > PM in
> > > > > room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning
> > > > > Commission and
> > > > > is a
> > > > > request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
> > > > > Entertainment
> > > > > permit.
> > > > >
> > > > > The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the
> > > > > lounge
> > > > > contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to
> > > > > have a
> > > > > permit to
> > > > > have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in
> > > > > Bernal
> > > > > Heights.
> > > > > The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the
> > > > > permit a
> > > > > few
> > > > > neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right
> > > > > now they
> > > > > are
> > > > > doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not
> > > > > granted.
> > > > >   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar,
> > > > > are
> > > > >
> > > > === message truncated ===

and my mother kinda forcibly driving me home drunk, sometimes running off
the road, sometimes passing out on the side of the road. . .
stuff like that. . . I have old friends who I think are such idiots, one of
them have sideswiped several cars and driven off after driving home from
bars n such. . . On halloween, some drunk construction worker dressed guy
driving a truck just got pissed of waiting in traffic and hit 4 cars (that I
could see) on purpose while he did a bad 3pt turn and sped off down the
wrong way. . .I saw him later on the freeway, which is odd cuz I was stuck
in traffic, and if we both left at the same time then he prolly hit a lot of
other cars before he got out of the city.
