----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, April 22, 2004 10:24 AM
Subject: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS


> SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
>
> TABLE OF CONTENTS
>
> 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
>
> 2.  MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
>
> 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES AT STATE ASSEMBLY
>
> 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
>
> 5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
>
>
> 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
>
> The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state legislation
> to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to make it out
> of committee
> at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of passage this
> year.
>
> While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the bill,
> statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433, claiming that
> it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of the
> State.
>
> Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last call in
> San
> Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that their
> Department
> could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those officers were
> speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as individuals,
> but
> their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
>
> In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a drunk
> driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting for the
> legislation.
> Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but the
> format of the assembly did not offer much chance for rebuttal.  Many
> democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against Drunk
> Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough votes to
> move the bill out of committee.
>
> San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with Assemblymembers
> Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of Supervisor members
> and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that was clearly
> not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of Sacramento.
> We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento legislative
> process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we more clearly
> understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next year.
>
> The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals who
> showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to Sacramento.  We'd
> also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for all
> their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.  Make
> sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls Assembly
> elections.
>
> 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
>
> After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events in San
> Francisco
> may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an after-hours
> permit.
> The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by Supervisors
> Bevan
> Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into law by
> Mayor
> Newsom.
>
> The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it was vetoed
> by
> Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored by the
> San
> Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's Liam Shy.
> Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission, who
> revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at City Hall
> to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It is great
> to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and taking
> control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully, we'll be
> seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
>
> 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
>
> While our last call legislation was defeated at the State Assembly,
> the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the State
> Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC licensing
> hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with bipartisan
> support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee last
> week.
>
> When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance of a
> liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a hearing
> regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often times this
> hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process with the
> protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes the time
> and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
>
> AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues to show
> some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for unreasonable
> concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor that they
> find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to approve
> the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this case, to
> ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but would be
> required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have a
> hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC and
> nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a hearing.
>
>
> 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
>
> The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April 22th at 3
> PM in
> room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning Commission and
> is a
> request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
> Entertainment
> permit.
>
> The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the lounge
> contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to have a
> permit to
> have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in Bernal
> Heights.
> The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the permit a
> few
> neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right now they
> are
> doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not granted.
>   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar, are
> supportive of the permit request.
>
> This is a case where the owner has invested much money and effort in
> renovations  and soundproofing and turned  what some referred to as a
> "scary
> biker bar" into a very cool lounge.   Yet still some folks don't want
> a DJ
> to play in his small bar.
>
> That brings us to the hearing  on Thursday.  Please show your support
> of San
> Francisco Culture; tell the government to support the entertainment
> community by showing up at the hearing.   You will not be required to
> speak;
> your presence in the audience will be enough.
>
> 4.  Please join the SFLNC and help us continue our work on behalf of
> San Francisco Nightlife http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
>
>
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>
> "The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of
> tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of
> tyranny a good conscience."
> -Albert Camus
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
> "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of
> life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the
> beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club,
> party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to
that..."
> -Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves
>

>> > > >
>> > > > --- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
>> > > > > SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
>> > > > >
>> > > > > TABLE OF CONTENTS
>> > > > >
>> > > > > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
>> > > > >
>> > > > > 2.  MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
>> > > > >
>> > > > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES AT STATE ASSEMBLY
>> > > > >
>> > > > > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
>> > > > >
>> > > > > 5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
>> > > > >
>> > > > >
>> > > > > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
>> > > > >
>> > > > > The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state
>> > > > > legislation
>> > > > > to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to
>> > > > > make it out
>> > > > > of committee
>> > > > > at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of
>> > > > > passage this
>> > > > > year.
>> > > > >
>> > > > > While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the
>> > > > > bill,
>> > > > > statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433,
>> > > > > claiming that
>> > > > > it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of
>> > > > > the
>> > > > > State.
>> > > > >
>> > > > > Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last
>> > > > > call in
>> > > > > San
>> > > > > Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that
>> > > > > their
>> > > > > Department
>> > > > > could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those
>> > > > > officers were
>> > > > > speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as
>> > > > > individuals,
>> > > > > but
>> > > > > their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
>> > > > >
>> > > > > In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a
>> > > > > drunk
>> > > > > driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting
>> > > > > for the
>> > > > > legislation.
>> > > > > Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but
>> > > > > the
>> > > > > format of the assembly did not offer much chance for
>> > > > > rebuttal.  Many
>> > > > > democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against
>> > > > > Drunk
>> > > > > Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough
>> > > > > votes to
>> > > > > move the bill out of committee.
>> > > > >
>> > > > > San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with
>> > > > > Assemblymembers
>> > > > > Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of
>> > > > > Supervisor members
>> > > > > and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that
>> > > > > was clearly
>> > > > > not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of
>> > > > > Sacramento.
>> > > > > We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento
>> > > > > legislative
>> > > > > process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we
>> > > > > more clearly
>> > > > > understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next
>> > > > > year.
>> > > > >
>> > > > > The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals
>> > > > > who
>> > > > > showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to
>> > > > > Sacramento.  We'd
>> > > > > also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for
>> > > > > all
>> > > > > their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.
>> > > > > Make
>> > > > > sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls
>> > > > > Assembly
>> > > > > elections.
>> > > > >
>> > > > > 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
>> > > > >
>> > > > > After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events
>> > > > > in San
>> > > > > Francisco
>> > > > > may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an
>> > > > > after-hours
>> > > > > permit.
>> > > > > The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by
>> > > > > Supervisors
>> > > > > Bevan
>> > > > > Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into
>> > > > > law by
>> > > > > Mayor
>> > > > > Newsom.
>> > > > >
>> > > > > The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it
>> > > > > was vetoed
>> > > > > by
>> > > > > Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored
>> > > > > by the
>> > > > > San
>> > > > > Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's
>> > > > > Liam Shy.
>> > > > > Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission,
>> > > > > who
>> > > > > revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at
>> > > > > City Hall
>> > > > > to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It
>> > > > > is great
>> > > > > to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and
>> > > > > taking
>> > > > > control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully,
>> > > > > we'll be
>> > > > > seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
>> > > > >
>> > > > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
>> > > > >
>> > > > > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State
>> > > > > Assembly,
>> > > > > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the
>> > > > > State
>> > > > > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC
>> > > > > licensing
>> > > > > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with
>> > > > > bipartisan
>> > > > > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee
>> > > > > last
>> > > > > week.
>> > > > >
>> > > > > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance
>> > > > > of a
>> > > > > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a
>> > > > > hearing
>> > > > > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often
>> > > > > times this
>> > > > > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process
>> > > > > with the
>> > > > > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes
>> > > > > the time
>> > > > > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
>> > > > >
>> > > > > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues
>> > > > > to show
>> > > > > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for
>> > > > > unreasonable
>> > > > > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor
>> > > > > that they
>> > > > > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to
>> > > > > approve
>> > > > > the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this
>> > > > > case, to
>> > > > > ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but
>> > > > > would be
>> > > > > required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have
>> > > > > a
>> > > > > hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC
>> > > > > and
>> > > > > nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a
>> > > > > hearing.
>> > > > >
>> > > > >
>> > > > > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
>> > > > >
>> > > > > The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April
>> > > > > 22th at 3
>> > > > > PM in
>> > > > > room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning
>> > > > > Commission and
>> > > > > is a
>> > > > > request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
>> > > > > Entertainment
>> > > > > permit.
>> > > > >
>> > > > > The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the
>> > > > > lounge
>> > > > > contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to
>> > > > > have a
>> > > > > permit to
>> > > > > have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in
>> > > > > Bernal
>> > > > > Heights.
>> > > > > The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the
>> > > > > permit a
>> > > > > few
>> > > > > neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right
>> > > > > now they
>> > > > > are
>> > > > > doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not
>> > > > > granted.
>> > > > >   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar,
>> > > > > are
>> > > > >
>> > > > === message truncated ===
>> > > >
>> > > >
>> > > >
>> > > >
>> > > >
>> > > > __________________________________
>> > > > Do you Yahoo!?

>> > > > http://photos.yahoo.com/ph/print_splash

The sound there was phenomenal, albeit a bit loud at times depending on the 
DJ. Some of my favorite experiences were there despite the insanely guidoed 
out crowd. Jeff Mills, Sasha & Digweed circa Northern Exposure, Digweed on 
his own. All really amazing shows. Still - the place was shady overall. They 
had metal detectors and secuity with hand-held detectors on hand to pat you 
down big time - shady drug dealings, etc. Hence the shut down....

>>> > > > > we'll be

>>> > > > >
>>> > > > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
>>> > > > >
>>> > > > > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State
>>> > > > > Assembly,
>>> > > > > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the
>>> > > > > State
>>> > > > > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC
>>> > > > > licensing
>>> > > > > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with
>>> > > > > bipartisan
>>> > > > > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee
>>> > > > > last
>>> > > > > week.
>>> > > > >
>>> > > > > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance
>>> > > > > of a
>>> > > > > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a
>>> > > > > hearing
>>> > > > > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often
>>> > > > > times this
>>> > > > > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process
>>> > > > > with the
>>> > > > > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes
>>> > > > > the time
>>> > > > > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
>>> > > > >
>>> > > > > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues
>>> > > > > to show
>>> > > > > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for
>>> > > > > unreasonable
>>> > > > > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor
>>> > > > > that they
>>> > > > > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to
>>> > > > > approve

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS

What does ANY of that have to do with allowing the serving of alcohol to 
extend from 2AM to 4AM?

I'm pretty much anti-booze too. I can count the number of times I've drank 
on my fingers (no joke). But I have no problem with it. I'm pretty 
indifferent about what may or may not happen if they would allow a later 
last call time, but can see the obvious benefits of places staying open 
later. Can't really see how it would make anything worse than it already is. 
If anything, common sense tells me drunk driving casualties may go down if 
it were to change.

>----- Original Message -----
>From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
>To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Sent: Thursday, April 22, 2004 10:24 AM
>Subject: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
>
>
> > SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
> >
> > TABLE OF CONTENTS
> >
> > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> >
> > 2.  MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> >
> > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES AT STATE ASSEMBLY
> >
> > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> >
> > 5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
> >
> >
> > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> >
> > The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state legislation
> > to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to make it out
> > of committee
> > at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of passage this
> > year.
> >
> > While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the bill,
> > statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433, claiming that
> > it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of the
> > State.
> >
> > Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last call in
> > San
> > Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that their
> > Department
> > could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those officers were
> > speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as individuals,
> > but
> > their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
> >
> > In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a drunk
> > driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting for the
> > legislation.
> > Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but the
> > format of the assembly did not offer much chance for rebuttal.  Many
> > democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against Drunk
> > Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough votes to
> > move the bill out of committee.
> >
> > San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with Assemblymembers
> > Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of Supervisor members
> > and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that was clearly
> > not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of Sacramento.
> > We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento legislative
> > process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we more clearly
> > understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next year.
> >
> > The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals who
> > showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to Sacramento.  We'd
> > also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for all
> > their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.  Make
> > sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls Assembly
> > elections.
> >
> > 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> >
> > After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events in San
> > Francisco
> > may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an after-hours
> > permit.
> > The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by Supervisors
> > Bevan
> > Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into law by
> > Mayor
> > Newsom.
> >
> > The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it was vetoed
> > by
> > Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored by the
> > San
> > Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's Liam Shy.
> > Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission, who
> > revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at City Hall
> > to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It is great
> > to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and taking
> > control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully, we'll be
> > seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
> >
> > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
> >
> > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State Assembly,
> > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the State
> > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC licensing
> > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with bipartisan
> > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee last
> > week.
> >
> > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance of a
> > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a hearing
> > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often times this
> > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process with the
> > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes the time
> > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
> >
> > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues to show
> > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for unreasonable
> > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor that they
> > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to approve
> > the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this case, to
> > ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but would be
> > required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have a
> > hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC and
> > nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a hearing.
> >
> >
> > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> >
> > The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April 22th at 3
> > PM in
> > room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning Commission and
> > is a
> > request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
> > Entertainment
> > permit.
> >
> > The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the lounge
> > contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to have a
> > permit to
> > have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in Bernal
> > Heights.
> > The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the permit a
> > few
> > neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right now they
> > are
> > doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not granted.
> >   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar, are
> > supportive of the permit request.
> >
> > This is a case where the owner has invested much money and effort in
> > renovations  and soundproofing and turned  what some referred to as a
> > "scary
> > biker bar" into a very cool lounge.   Yet still some folks don't want
> > a DJ
> > to play in his small bar.
> >
> > That brings us to the hearing  on Thursday.  Please show your support
> > of San
> > Francisco Culture; tell the government to support the entertainment
> > community by showing up at the hearing.   You will not be required to
> > speak;
> > your presence in the audience will be enough.
> >
> > 4.  Please join the SFLNC and help us continue our work on behalf of
> > San Francisco Nightlife http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
> >
> >
> >
> > Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> >
> > House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> >
> >
> > "The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of
> > tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of
> > tyranny a good conscience."
> > -Albert Camus
> >
> > "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> > rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually 
>become
> > visible."
> > -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
> >
> > "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of
> > life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the
> > beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club,
> > party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to
>that..."
> > -Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

At 11:58 AM 4/22/2004, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
>The sound there was phenomenal, albeit a bit loud at times depending on 
>the DJ. Some of my favorite experiences were there despite the insanely 
>guidoed out crowd. Jeff Mills, Sasha & Digweed circa Northern Exposure, 
>Digweed on his own. All really amazing shows. Still - the place was shady 
>overall. They had metal detectors and secuity with hand-held detectors on 
>hand to pat you down big time - shady drug dealings, etc. Hence the shut 
>down....
>
>M-

1015 was a great venue back in the day -- before it became, as it were, 
"world class."  As Philip said, Come-Unity was there for many 
years.  Further, there were great events with local DJs like Product in the 
early nineties.  Gus Bean had a regular gay event there on Saturday nights.
Prior to the "1015" days, the venue was called "Das Klub."  And in the 
seventies it was a bisexual bath house called the "Sutro Baths."

Last time I was there was at Come-Unity.  Malachy moved it to Barneveld for 
a spell after that because neither the patrons of the DJs could deal with 
the invasive security and changing vibe.  Neither could I.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

At 12:00 PM 4/22/2004, Gavin Varitech wrote:
>What does ANY of that have to do with allowing the serving of alcohol to 
>extend from 2AM to 4AM?
>
>I'm pretty much anti-booze too. I can count the number of times I've drank 
>on my fingers (no joke). But I have no problem with it. I'm pretty 
>indifferent about what may or may not happen if they would allow a later 
>last call time, but can see the obvious benefits of places staying open 
>later. Can't really see how it would make anything worse than it already 
>is. If anything, common sense tells me drunk driving casualties may go 
>down if it were to change.

Now, at clubs without an afterhours permit,  the bar closes at 1:30am and 
drinkers are hurled out on the streets at 2:00 am.  I always thought this 
was unsafe and lacking in common sense.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Starchild" <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>

Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) "Assault weapon" confiscation turns violent in
Boston


> This was supposed to go out yesterday... Happy (belated) Patriots Day.
>
> <<< Starchild >>>
>
>
> "Assault weapon" confiscation turns violent in Boston
> Scores Killed, Hundreds Injured As Para-Military Extremists Riot
>
> BOSTON, April 19 - National Guard units seeking to confiscate a cache
> of recently banned assault weapons were ambushed on April 19th by
> elements of a para-military extremist faction. Military and law
> enforcement sources estimated that 72 were killed and more than 20
> injured before government forces were compelled to withdraw.
>
> Speaking after the clash, Massachusetts Governor Thomas Gage declared
> that the extremist faction, which was made up of local citizens, has
> links to the radical right-wing tax protest movement. Gage blamed the
> extremists for recent incidents of vandalism directed against internal
> revenue offices.
>
> The governor, who described the group's organizers as "criminals,"
> issued an executive order authorizing the summary arrest of any
> individual who has interfered with the government's efforts to secure
> law and order.
>
> The military raid on the extremist arsenal followed wide-spread refusal
> by the local citizenry to turn over recently outlawed assault weapons.
> Gage issued a ban on military-style assault weapons and ammunition
> earlier in the week. This decision followed a meeting in early April
> between government and military leaders at which the governor
> authorized the forcible confiscation of illegal arms. One government
> official, speaking on condition of anonymity, pointed out that "none of
> these people would have been killed had the extremists obeyed the law
> and turned their weapons over voluntarily."
>
> "Government troops initially succeeded in confiscating a large supply
> of outlawed weapons and ammunition. However, troops attempting to seize
> arms and ammunition in Lexington met with resistance from heavily-armed
> extremists who had been tipped off regarding the government's plans.
>
> During a tense standoff in Lexington's town park, National Guard
> Colonel Francis Smith, commander of the government operation, ordered
> the armed group to surrender and return to their homes. The impasse was
> broken by a single shot, which was reportedly fired by one of the
> right-wing extremists. Eight civilians were killed in the ensuing
> exchange.
>
> Ironically, the local citizenry blamed government forces rather than
> the extremists for the civilian deaths. Before order could be restored,
> armed citizens from surrounding areas had descended upon the guard
> units. Colonel Smith, finding his forces overmatched by the armed mob,
> ordered a retreat.
>
> Governor Gage has called upon citizens to support the state/national
> joint task force in its effort to restore law and order. The governor
> has also demanded the surrender of those responsible for planning and
> leading the attack against the government troops. Samuel Adams, Paul
> Revere, and John Hancock, who have been identified as "ringleaders" of
> the extremist faction, remain at large.
>
> The price of freedom is eternal vigilance."
> -- Thomas Jefferson
>
>

> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS

I don't have a problem with alcohol, I have a problem with people who can't 
handle themselves on it. I place blame where it needs placed. For every one 
person I have met who cannot conduct themselves while on it, I have met 10 
more who can. I have bartended, and worked at several nightclubs, and the 
amount of times i have had to bounce people out for being idiots, and the 
amount of times I have ever heard of any patrons having run ins w/ the law, 
or wrecking their cars, etc. is extremely LOW.

M-

>>----- Original Message -----
>>From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
>>To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>>Sent: Thursday, April 22, 2004 10:24 AM
>>Subject: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
>>
>>
>> > SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
>> >
>> > TABLE OF CONTENTS
>> >
>> > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
>> >
>> > 2.  MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
>> >
>> > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES AT STATE ASSEMBLY
>> >
>> > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
>> >
>> > 5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
>> >
>> >
>> > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
>> >
>> > The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state legislation
>> > to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to make it out
>> > of committee
>> > at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of passage this
>> > year.
>> >
>> > While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the bill,
>> > statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433, claiming that
>> > it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of the
>> > State.
>> >
>> > Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last call in
>> > San
>> > Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that their
>> > Department
>> > could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those officers were
>> > speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as individuals,
>> > but
>> > their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
>> >
>> > In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a drunk
>> > driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting for the
>> > legislation.
>> > Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but the
>> > format of the assembly did not offer much chance for rebuttal.  Many
>> > democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against Drunk
>> > Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough votes to
>> > move the bill out of committee.
>> >
>> > San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with Assemblymembers
>> > Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of Supervisor members
>> > and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that was clearly
>> > not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of Sacramento.
>> > We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento legislative
>> > process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we more clearly
>> > understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next year.
>> >
>> > The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals who
>> > showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to Sacramento.  We'd
>> > also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for all
>> > their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.  Make
>> > sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls Assembly
>> > elections.
>> >
>> > 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
>> >
>> > After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events in San
>> > Francisco
>> > may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an after-hours
>> > permit.
>> > The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by Supervisors
>> > Bevan
>> > Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into law by
>> > Mayor
>> > Newsom.
>> >
>> > The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it was vetoed
>> > by
>> > Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored by the
>> > San
>> > Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's Liam Shy.
>> > Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission, who
>> > revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at City Hall
>> > to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It is great
>> > to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and taking
>> > control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully, we'll be
>> > seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
>> >
>> > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
>> >
>> > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State Assembly,
>> > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the State
>> > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC licensing
>> > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with bipartisan
>> > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee last
>> > week.
>> >
>> > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance of a
>> > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a hearing
>> > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often times this
>> > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process with the
>> > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes the time
>> > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
>> >
>> > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues to show
>> > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for unreasonable
>> > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor that they
>> > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to approve
>> > the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this case, to
>> > ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but would be
>> > required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have a
>> > hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC and
>> > nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a hearing.
>> >
>> >
>> > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
>> >
>> > The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April 22th at 3
>> > PM in
>> > room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning Commission and
>> > is a
>> > request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
>> > Entertainment
>> > permit.
>> >
>> > The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the lounge
>> > contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to have a
>> > permit to
>> > have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in Bernal
>> > Heights.
>> > The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the permit a
>> > few
>> > neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right now they
>> > are
>> > doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not granted.
>> >   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar, are
>> > supportive of the permit request.
>> >
>> > This is a case where the owner has invested much money and effort in
>> > renovations  and soundproofing and turned  what some referred to as a
>> > "scary
>> > biker bar" into a very cool lounge.   Yet still some folks don't want
>> > a DJ
>> > to play in his small bar.
>> >
>> > That brings us to the hearing  on Thursday.  Please show your support
>> > of San
>> > Francisco Culture; tell the government to support the entertainment
>> > community by showing up at the hearing.   You will not be required to
>> > speak;
>> > your presence in the audience will be enough.
>> >
>> > 4.  Please join the SFLNC and help us continue our work on behalf of
>> > San Francisco Nightlife http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> > Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>> >
>> > House Music 101:  
>>http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>> >
>> >
>> > "The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of
>> > tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants 
>>of
>> > tyranny a good conscience."
>> > -Albert Camus
>> >

>>the
>> > rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually 
>>become
>> > visible."
>> > -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>> >
>> > "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of
>> > life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the
>> > beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club,
>> > party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to
>>that..."
>> > -Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 1015 folsom (was: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS)

Club 1015 and Ira can fall off the earth for all I care.  

I've been to 1015 about 12 times since '93. Every time I've been
there I've been searched within an inch of my life. I've been denied
entrance because I had prescription medication. I've seen employees
peering at people in the doorless bathroom stalls. I've been told I
can stand here. Can't do this.  Can't do that. Seen so many other
people hassled I wonder why they bother.

If they can't run a business without doing all that, they don't
deserve any. I've been to a lot of clubs, and 1015 has the rudest
staff I've ever seen, by far.

Let it fall. SF doesn't really need it anyway.

Sean

> >> > >
> >> > > --- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> >> > > > SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
> >> > > >
> >> > > > TABLE OF CONTENTS
> >> > > >
> >> > > > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> >> > > >
> >> > > > 2.  MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> >> > > >
> >> > > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES AT STATE ASSEMBLY
> >> > > >
> >> > > > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> >> > > >
> >> > > > 5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
> >> > > >
> >> > > >
> >> > > > 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
> >> > > >
> >> > > > The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state
> >> > > > legislation
> >> > > > to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to
> >> > > > make it out
> >> > > > of committee
> >> > > > at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of
> >> > > > passage this
> >> > > > year.
> >> > > >
> >> > > > While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the
> >> > > > bill,
> >> > > > statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433,
> >> > > > claiming that
> >> > > > it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of
> >> > > > the
> >> > > > State.
> >> > > >
> >> > > > Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last
> >> > > > call in
> >> > > > San
> >> > > > Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that
> >> > > > their
> >> > > > Department
> >> > > > could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those
> >> > > > officers were
> >> > > > speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as
> >> > > > individuals,
> >> > > > but
> >> > > > their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
> >> > > >
> >> > > > In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a
> >> > > > drunk
> >> > > > driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting
> >> > > > for the
> >> > > > legislation.
> >> > > > Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but
> >> > > > the
> >> > > > format of the assembly did not offer much chance for
> >> > > > rebuttal.  Many
> >> > > > democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against
> >> > > > Drunk
> >> > > > Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough
> >> > > > votes to
> >> > > > move the bill out of committee.
> >> > > >
> >> > > > San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with
> >> > > > Assemblymembers
> >> > > > Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of
> >> > > > Supervisor members
> >> > > > and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that
> >> > > > was clearly
> >> > > > not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of
> >> > > > Sacramento.
> >> > > > We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento
> >> > > > legislative
> >> > > > process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we
> >> > > > more clearly
> >> > > > understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next
> >> > > > year.
> >> > > >
> >> > > > The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals
> >> > > > who
> >> > > > showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to
> >> > > > Sacramento.  We'd
> >> > > > also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for
> >> > > > all
> >> > > > their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.
> >> > > > Make
> >> > > > sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls
> >> > > > Assembly
> >> > > > elections.
> >> > > >
> >> > > > 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
> >> > > >
> >> > > > After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events
> >> > > > in San
> >> > > > Francisco
> >> > > > may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an
> >> > > > after-hours
> >> > > > permit.
> >> > > > The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by
> >> > > > Supervisors
> >> > > > Bevan
> >> > > > Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into
> >> > > > law by
> >> > > > Mayor
> >> > > > Newsom.
> >> > > >
> >> > > > The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it
> >> > > > was vetoed
> >> > > > by
> >> > > > Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored
> >> > > > by the
> >> > > > San
> >> > > > Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's
> >> > > > Liam Shy.
> >> > > > Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission,
> >> > > > who
> >> > > > revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at
> >> > > > City Hall
> >> > > > to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It
> >> > > > is great
> >> > > > to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and
> >> > > > taking
> >> > > > control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully,
> >> > > > we'll be
> >> > > > seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
> >> > > >
> >> > > > 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
> >> > > >
> >> > > > While our last call legislation was defeated at the State
> >> > > > Assembly,
> >> > > > the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the
> >> > > > State
> >> > > > Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC
> >> > > > licensing
> >> > > > hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with
> >> > > > bipartisan
> >> > > > support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee
> >> > > > last
> >> > > > week.
> >> > > >
> >> > > > When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance
> >> > > > of a
> >> > > > liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a
> >> > > > hearing
> >> > > > regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often
> >> > > > times this
> >> > > > hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process
> >> > > > with the
> >> > > > protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes
> >> > > > the time
> >> > > > and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
> >> > > >
> >> > > > AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues
> >> > > > to show
> >> > > > some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for
> >> > > > unreasonable
> >> > > > concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor
> >> > > > that they
> >> > > > find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to
> >> > > > approve
> >> > > > the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this
> >> > > > case, to
> >> > > > ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but
> >> > > > would be
> >> > > > required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have
> >> > > > a
> >> > > > hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC
> >> > > > and
> >> > > > nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a
> >> > > > hearing.
> >> > > >
> >> > > >
> >> > > > 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
> >> > > >
> >> > > > The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April
> >> > > > 22th at 3
> >> > > > PM in
> >> > > > room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning
> >> > > > Commission and
> >> > > > is a
> >> > > > request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
> >> > > > Entertainment
> >> > > > permit.
> >> > > >
> >> > > > The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the
> >> > > > lounge
> >> > > > contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to
> >> > > > have a
> >> > > > permit to
> >> > > > have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in
> >> > > > Bernal
> >> > > > Heights.
> >> > > > The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the
> >> > > > permit a
> >> > > > few
> >> > > > neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right
> >> > > > now they
> >> > > > are
> >> > > > doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not
> >> > > > granted.
> >> > > >   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar,
> >> > > > are
> >> > > >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] 1015 folsom (was: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS)

Hallelujah Phillip!

On most parts I concur that the patrons are one variable that can effect a
club's environment and people's perception of club itself.

There are many others too:
There is a fine line between an event *PROMOTER* or *CREW*, how that
crew acts, throws events, how organized they are, what music and
artists they book, and how they run an event (think weekly, monthly,
etc) at a *VENUE* they might have secured but may or may not own.

versus:

The venue itself, permitting, music genres, venue ownership, layout of the
club, ventilation, security, how you are treated, cost to get in the the
door, soundsystem, bathroom cleanliness, drink cost, other available
services offered by the venue, DJ bookings, and other items which can
all effect one's experience at a club.

coupled with:

One's attitude towards it and the scene in general, one's personality,
energy, vibe, and the interactive participation of the club goer. The
patron effects the energy at a club at well. So many variables mentioned,
others not that can effect one's overall experience. It's up to you (and
other patrons) to enjoy oneself along the way.

I've been to many Spundae's at 1015, and always enjoyed each time, dancing
my booty off.

Cheerios,

Karina

--

much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

Subject: RE: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS

Just to be the minority here, Jack's digs the brew. :)

Ak, I see your point about personal problems with your family and drinking,
but that doesn't make
ALL the apples bad. Take Marco and me, we have had many pints together and I
haven't even taken a swing at him yet! I believe Ben Franklin said it best
"Beer is living proof that God loves us and wants us to be happy." - Now,
downing a 1/5th of Gin is a different story. Having shots in the morning so
you can to work is a different story. Drinking until you can't see and
pissing yourself is a different story. Everything in moderation.

When I was in Europe all the Social/Community meetings took place centered
around, or in a beer garden. These were enormous halls, or fields sometimes
holding up to 2 - 3,000 heads where people could socialize and kids could
play in the open. The hofbrauhaus Las Vegas is trying to recreate that, but
reality tells me that the US isn't mature enough for it.

I would even say I wouldn't support a later last call just for the points
mentioned above. I know I am responsible, but who knows about my fellow
brother's and sister's. I think you would see an increase in drinking
related deaths. But I am also totally against and sort of decrease in the
last call, ie moving it to midnight. Just let it be.

oh well, I got waaaay off topic, but my closing point is, like everything
else there are a few who ruin it for all. Jack out.

Oh yeah and I dig good beer!
--
DJ Jack Triumph
Minister of Infinite Progressive Onslaught

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Is there anywhere for techno?

I say we need a party *like* Alumni, Anyone here want to bring back
oldskool techno from the dead of people's crates and onto the dancefloor?
There are so many hits from back in the day (1990-1996) I'd love to hear
specifically played at an event. A series of events like this would be
nice too - bringing back all the years and couple it with the Nu-School of
Techno from then and beyond into the 21st century. I'd love to hear 8
hours of Techno like i'm listening to the 8 hours of acid house and
classic house from the Alumni set in January. I know, two seperate genres,
but I love it all baby... It was House, Acid House and Techno, along with
breaks that got my booty starting to Shake 14 years ago...

Want help planning a party? If someone doesn't have an interest.. maybe
I'll just do it... Long live Techno....

I'd love to hear these on the dancefloor for instance:

Shut Up - New York Style
Inssomniak (*I Come Back) -concrete mix - D.J.P.C.
elvis has left the building - The Castle
Paranoid - Paranoid
The Dexorcist - DeadSilence
No Sex until Marraige (pre-matrimonial climax version) - R.J.'s Rule
Float in a Dream of Ex-tc (667 Beats) - Fire on High
808 State - Excel  -  1 San Francicsco
808 State - Gorgeous - Europa, Nimbus, Sexy Dancer
Temple of Dreams - Messiah
Evapor-8 (Inciner-8 Mix) - Altern-8
Papaua New Guinea - The Future Sound of London
I know you like it - React 2 Rhythm
Digeridoo - The Aphex Twin
Incubus - The Spirit
Where is your Evidence - Frequency
Frequency - Altern 8
Sychologic P.S.P. - Nexus 21
Wave of the future - Heavyweight
Let's Do it Again - Project B12
Stream - Cyclone

Too many others to list .... For all those who say Fuck Techno, I say,
Fuck to Techno then repeat the following Mantra:

Viva Le Techno!

Paix,

Karina

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Is there anywhere for techno?

I tried to set up an event back east that showcased both old and new styles 
throught the night. Sort of an Old Skool vs. Nu Skool style event. A mixed 
batch of locals and well-knowns playing a mix of both styles. Maybe it's 
just because I do that in my own sets that the idea appeals to me so much, 
but it would be a neat way of seeing the progression of genres, styles, etc. 
The idea got sparked after seeing DJ Slipmatt (from SL2 fame) a year or so 
back. He was so amazing, and played both old and new stuff - and had the 
main room @ Buzz in DC positively hopping from beginning to end. People were 
talking about it for weeks afterwards.

Anyone up for that? I know I'd be into helping any way I could for something 
like that....

M-

>From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
>To: Gavin Varitech <nesound@hotmail.com>
>CC: st_indigo@earthlink.net, sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Is there anywhere for techno?
>Date: Thu, 22 Apr 2004 13:23:59 -0700 (PDT)
>
>I say we need a party *like* Alumni, Anyone here want to bring back
>oldskool techno from the dead of people's crates and onto the dancefloor?
>There are so many hits from back in the day (1990-1996) I'd love to hear
>specifically played at an event. A series of events like this would be
>nice too - bringing back all the years and couple it with the Nu-School of
>Techno from then and beyond into the 21st century. I'd love to hear 8
>hours of Techno like i'm listening to the 8 hours of acid house and
>classic house from the Alumni set in January. I know, two seperate genres,
>but I love it all baby... It was House, Acid House and Techno, along with
>breaks that got my booty starting to Shake 14 years ago...
>
>Want help planning a party? If someone doesn't have an interest.. maybe
>I'll just do it... Long live Techno....
>
>I'd love to hear these on the dancefloor for instance:
>
>Shut Up - New York Style
>Inssomniak (*I Come Back) -concrete mix - D.J.P.C.
>elvis has left the building - The Castle
>Paranoid - Paranoid
>The Dexorcist - DeadSilence
>No Sex until Marraige (pre-matrimonial climax version) - R.J.'s Rule
>Float in a Dream of Ex-tc (667 Beats) - Fire on High
>808 State - Excel  -  1 San Francicsco
>808 State - Gorgeous - Europa, Nimbus, Sexy Dancer
>Temple of Dreams - Messiah
>Evapor-8 (Inciner-8 Mix) - Altern-8
>Papaua New Guinea - The Future Sound of London
>I know you like it - React 2 Rhythm
>Digeridoo - The Aphex Twin
>Incubus - The Spirit
>Where is your Evidence - Frequency
>Frequency - Altern 8
>Sychologic P.S.P. - Nexus 21
>Wave of the future - Heavyweight
>Let's Do it Again - Project B12
>Stream - Cyclone
>
>Too many others to list .... For all those who say Fuck Techno, I say,
>Fuck to Techno then repeat the following Mantra:
>
>Viva Le Techno!
>
>Paix,
>
>Karina

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: tonight: SFUAS Earth Day mixer & celebration

SF Urban Alliance for Sustainability presents

------ PLANTING SEEDS OF CHANGE ------
EarthDay Mixer & Celebration

Thursday, April 22, 2004
@ Cellspace (2050 Bryant / 18th st in SF)
6:30pm-1am (details below)

$5-10 donation
No one turned away for lack of funds,
This is a NO ALCOHOL event. Bring your kids and non-drinking friends,=20
too.

www.sfuas.org
unite@sfuas.org
415.820.1456

Here is a link to the flyer: http://www.sfuas.org/uas_flyer_eday.jpg

---------------------------

SFUAS is hosting a series of mixers which are bringing together=20
sustainable
businesses, city officials and community members for an evening of=20
dialogue
and idea-building within a comfortable social atmosphere. Dynamic=20
speakers
and attendees, mixing activities,=A0 high-quality entertainment. Join us=20=

at
our special EarthDay Mixer & Celebration "Planting Seeds of Change":

MIXER PROGRAM STARTS AT 6:30pm:

-- KEYNOTE SPEAKER Kevin Danaher, Co-founder, Global Exchange
-- MC Mo Melady (Host of Planet Check Green Radio) -- Listen/Be Heard=20
via short presentations on current Sustainable
businesses/projects by various groups and individuals, (possibly YOUR
project!)
-- Network/Connect with like-minded greensters who might help YOUR=20
project
get to the next step
-- Find Out about city-sponsored Sustainability programs and=20
opportunities
-- Teach/Learn at various Learning Stations and Information tables=20
(Starting
Green Business, BioFuel, Organic Gardening, City-run Programs and=20
others)
-- Yummy Organic Food by LoveMore Gourmet

DAMN GOOD CELEBRATION: 9:30-1am

- ESTAS TONNE & FRIENDS - Gypsy Troubadours
- THE GENIE - Scratch Guitar
- Alex Theory - Live Electronica (Mystic Vibration=20
www.mysticvibration.com
<http://www.mysticvibration.com> )
- Ikarus - Phat Breaks (InfiniteKaos.com)

+ Random Performers=A0 Hula Circus & Other Suprises

If you or your organization would like to participate at the event,=20
set-up a
table, a learning station, volunteer for the event, or offer=20
sponsorship and
donations, please contact us at 415.820-1456 or unite@sfuas.org
<mailto:unite@sfuas.org>
Give a brief description of yourself and your project and any website=20
info.

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

SF Urban Alliance for Sustainability (sfUAS) is a local network=20
comprised of
green businesses and community members. Our intention is to create a=20
dynamic
model of sustainability in the City, uniting responsible business=20
practices
with community development, social equity, and ecological integrity. We=20=

wish
to develop an Eco-Industrial Park which will house office and production
facilities for sustainable businesses, artists and non-profits, an=20
organic
cafe, gallery, retail and community space. We will utilize green=20
building
techniques, renewable energy sources, and minimization of waste.


^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

We look forward to seeing you there! Pass it on!

PEACE

----- Original Message -----=20
From: Preserve Family=20
Sent: Wednesday, April 21, 2004 11:07 AM
Subject: Preserve the Vibe


Over the last year Preserve has really grown. We've taken on new =
members, tried our hands at different types of events, expanded our =
horizons and had some really spacial growing moments along the way. Now =
its time for another one of those moments....We would love to invite you =
to join us as we gather together to celebrate the oneness and the vibe, =
which has made our scene so great!

We at Preserve, would like to thank all the folks who came out to the =
Preserve 1 Yr. Birthday Celebration. With 8 stacks of J/K Sound, y'all =
had that place rumbling!! We had a great time celebrating our birthday =
with you all...seeing all your smiling faces really made our night!!!=20

It was great seeing all the variety in talent we had! It made going from =
room to room, really difficult! Who did I wanna see next? Is the other =
room more crackin?.......What would have been nice, is having all that =
energy...all that vibe...in one room. After all, celebrating =
togetherness IS what we're all about.=20

So...we bring you the next installment. We want to focus the next series =
completely on one aspect of the underground scene. We want to focus on =
THE VIBE.=20

Let's all gather together in one room.=20
Let's all gather together to dance to the same beat.=20
Let's all gather together to to create a community...under one Vibe.=20


Tickets are in stores now for only $10, and $15 tickets will be =
available at the door. Doors open at 7:30 and the music starts promptly =
at 8:00 and goes until 4:00 am. This will be an all ages event!!! As an =
added bonus, there will be an ambient chill room provided for your =
comfort, and J/K sound for your listening pleasure.

Dj's:

Morgan

Denise vs Dragn'fly

Paul the Fanman vs Dingo

Cooraw vs Fury

Michael liu vs Epsilon

Impulse vs Lukasz

Valerie sparks vs Carlos Alfonzo

Wavelength vs Apot




revive ... restore ... Preserve=20
www.PreserveProductions.com=20
Family@PreserveProductions.com

If you do not wish to receive further emails from Preserve, please reply =
with "remove" in the subject line.  Thank you.

water bottles filled with sake.  why did i do this, you ask? 
because 1: i'm a drunk, 2: fucking 1:45am last call.  club
stays open till 6am, sometimes 8am.

this was most likely in 1997-1998.  another time i brought in a
backpack full of liquor so we could make our own long island
ice teas.  full bottles of triple sec, rum, tequila, vodka.  we
bought the coke from the bar.  ;)

>From: "Van Mundegaarde" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
>To: karina@hyperreal.org, nesound@hotmail.com
>CC: st_indigo@earthlink.net, sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Is there anywhere for techno?
>Date: Thu, 22 Apr 2004 13:29:12 -0700
>
>I tried to set up an event back east that showcased both old and new styles 
>throught the night. Sort of an Old Skool vs. Nu Skool style event. A mixed 
>batch of locals and well-knowns playing a mix of both styles. Maybe it's 
>just because I do that in my own sets that the idea appeals to me so much, 
>but it would be a neat way of seeing the progression of genres, styles, 
>etc. The idea got sparked after seeing DJ Slipmatt (from SL2 fame) a year 
>or so back. He was so amazing, and played both old and new stuff - and had 
>the main room @ Buzz in DC positively hopping from beginning to end. People 
>were talking about it for weeks afterwards.
>
>Anyone up for that? I know I'd be into helping any way I could for 
>something like that....
>
>M-

>>From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>

>>CC: st_indigo@earthlink.net, sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Is there anywhere for techno?
>>Date: Thu, 22 Apr 2004 13:23:59 -0700 (PDT)
>>
>>I say we need a party *like* Alumni, Anyone here want to bring back
>>oldskool techno from the dead of people's crates and onto the dancefloor?
>>There are so many hits from back in the day (1990-1996) I'd love to hear
>>specifically played at an event. A series of events like this would be
>>nice too - bringing back all the years and couple it with the Nu-School of
>>Techno from then and beyond into the 21st century. I'd love to hear 8
>>hours of Techno like i'm listening to the 8 hours of acid house and
>>classic house from the Alumni set in January. I know, two seperate genres,
>>but I love it all baby... It was House, Acid House and Techno, along with
>>breaks that got my booty starting to Shake 14 years ago...
>>
>>Want help planning a party? If someone doesn't have an interest.. maybe
>>I'll just do it... Long live Techno....
>>
>>I'd love to hear these on the dancefloor for instance:
>>
>>Shut Up - New York Style
>>Inssomniak (*I Come Back) -concrete mix - D.J.P.C.
>>elvis has left the building - The Castle
>>Paranoid - Paranoid
>>The Dexorcist - DeadSilence
>>No Sex until Marraige (pre-matrimonial climax version) - R.J.'s Rule
>>Float in a Dream of Ex-tc (667 Beats) - Fire on High
>>808 State - Excel  -  1 San Francicsco
>>808 State - Gorgeous - Europa, Nimbus, Sexy Dancer
>>Temple of Dreams - Messiah
>>Evapor-8 (Inciner-8 Mix) - Altern-8
>>Papaua New Guinea - The Future Sound of London
>>I know you like it - React 2 Rhythm
>>Digeridoo - The Aphex Twin
>>Incubus - The Spirit
>>Where is your Evidence - Frequency
>>Frequency - Altern 8
>>Sychologic P.S.P. - Nexus 21
>>Wave of the future - Heavyweight
>>Let's Do it Again - Project B12
>>Stream - Cyclone
>>
>>Too many others to list .... For all those who say Fuck Techno, I say,

(back when it did not suck) tekno all those years ago, it really never was.

better techno jock than most I've heard on the West coast. He's got the 
skills of a dope techno deejay for sure. Just not the soul of one.

>>styles throught the night. Sort of an Old Skool vs. Nu Skool style event. 
>>A mixed batch of locals and well-knowns playing a mix of both styles.

>>new stuff - and had the main room @ Buzz in DC positively hopping from

>>>From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
>>>To: Gavin Varitech <nesound@hotmail.com>
>>>CC: st_indigo@earthlink.net, sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Is there anywhere for techno?
>>>Date: Thu, 22 Apr 2004 13:23:59 -0700 (PDT)
>>>
>>>I say we need a party *like* Alumni, Anyone here want to bring back
>>>oldskool techno from the dead of people's crates and onto the dancefloor?
>>>There are so many hits from back in the day (1990-1996) I'd love to hear
>>>specifically played at an event. A series of events like this would be
>>>nice too - bringing back all the years and couple it with the Nu-School 
>>>of
>>>Techno from then and beyond into the 21st century. I'd love to hear 8
>>>hours of Techno like i'm listening to the 8 hours of acid house and
>>>classic house from the Alumni set in January. I know, two seperate 
>>>genres,
>>>but I love it all baby... It was House, Acid House and Techno, along with
>>>breaks that got my booty starting to Shake 14 years ago...
>>>
>>>Want help planning a party? If someone doesn't have an interest.. maybe
>>>I'll just do it... Long live Techno....
>>>

>>>elvis has left the building - The Castle
>>>Paranoid - Paranoid
>>>The Dexorcist - DeadSilence

Subject: [sfraves] Protect Live Music Events on April 24th

--=====================_936186==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Here is a list of local activities in support of the DPA's day of protest 
against anti-RAVE and other legislation that threaten the music community 
in general:


California

April 24th
Brookdale Lodge
Santa Cruz, CA

Cubensis, Southern California's Grateful Dead music tribute band will be 
performing. Proceeds will benefit Drug Policy Alliance.

Thursday, April 29th
3pm-5pm
San Francisco State University
Humanities Bldg, Rm 133

San Francisco debut of "Generation E." Co-sponsored by DanceSafe and CEASE 
(Creating Empowerment through Alcohol & Substance-abuse Education) at SFSU. 
"Generation E" is a new documentary video on the passage of the RAVE Act. 
The documentary traces the recent history of publicity surrounding raves 
and "club drugs," legislative actions regarding San Francisco late-night 
recreation, key flaws in the drug war, and examples of harm reduction 
alternatives to the perceived problems of raves or other youth recreation.

In addition to these events, supporters are passing out petitions and 
holding benefits in dozens of other cities.  From NYC:

APRIL 24th
Liquid Sound Lounge-WBAI 99.5FM
7p-9:30p eastern time (New York City)
live stream 
<http://www.liquidsoundlounge.com>http://www.liquidsoundlounge.com or 
<http://www.wbai.org>http://www.wbai.org
and archived shortly after at 
<http://www.undergroundnyc.com>http://www.undergroundnyc.com

Host and producers of Liquid Sound Lounge, Jeannie Hopper brings together 
an audio collage of music and interviews with various activists and groups 
fighting to stop the federal Anti-Club Legislation.

For more information go to 
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=30230






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_936186==.ALT--

Don't know how many of you saw this when it came out...

January 2002
Sex, Drugs, and Techno Music
Why the rap against Ecstasy has a familiar ring to it
By Jacob Sullum

Last spring, the Chicago City Council decided "to crack down on wild=20
rave parties that lure youngsters into environments loaded with=20
dangerous club drugs, underage drinking and sometimes predatory sexual=20=

behavior," as the Chicago Tribune put it. The newspaper described raves=20=

as "one-night-only parties -- often held in warehouses or secret=20
locations where people pay to dance, do drugs, play loud music, and=20
engage in random sex acts." Taking a dim view of such goings-on, the=20
city council passed an ordinance threatening to jail building owners or=20=

managers who allowed raves to be held on their property. Mayor Richard=20=

Daley took the occasion to "lash out at the people who produce the huge=20=

rogue dance parties where Ecstasy and other designer drugs are widely=20
used." In Daley=92s view, rave promoters were deliberately seducing the=20=

innocent. "They are after all of our children," he warned. "Parents=20
should be outraged by this." ...

(See the rest of the article online at=20
http://www.reason.com/0201/fe.js.sex.shtml)=

--Apple-Mail-6--855092941--

>>>styles throught the night. Sort of an Old Skool vs. Nu Skool style event.

>>>new stuff - and had the main room @ Buzz in DC positively hopping from

>>>>I say we need a party *like* Alumni, Anyone here want to bring back
>>>>oldskool techno from the dead of people's crates and onto the 
>>>>dancefloor?

>>>>nice too - bringing back all the years and couple it with the Nu-School 
>>>>of
>>>>Techno from then and beyond into the 21st century. I'd love to hear 8
>>>>hours of Techno like i'm listening to the 8 hours of acid house and
>>>>classic house from the Alumni set in January. I know, two seperate 
>>>>genres,

>>>>with
>>>>breaks that got my booty starting to Shake 14 years ago...

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Banana Thieves

I just read an article that farmers in Hawaii's North Shore are having 
problems with poaching from their various fruit orchards & fish ponds. 
As a swift counter-measure for this problem, I think that we should 
offer a "ravers for hire" service-- I'm almost certain that small scale 
strategically placed 24/7 raves in the various places that are getting 
(or could be) stolen from, our partyin' presence would certainly scare 
away intruders. The dance scene in Hawaii is far too weak to support 
this kind of campaign, so we must step up & do our part, for we of the 
Bay Area are the paragon of groovers who must help our Hawaiian brothers 
& sisters to protect their lush tropical orchards & sandy beaches. [If 
any North Shore farmers are reading this, please note that I will work 
for Matsumoto shave ice & box lunches from Yummy Korean BBQ.]


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS

Aryck,

	The only thing that will probably decrease alcohol use much in the 
near future is if people switch to other drugs. We all know when it 
comes to substance use that "Just Say No" doesn't work. So if you're 
anti-alcohol, I hope that you're encouraging a substitute. Pick your 
favorite substance and promote it, i.e. don't just oppose bars selling 
alcohol past 2am -- talk about how they should be allowed to sell pot, 
ecstasy, LSD, magic mushrooms, whatever, instead. Otherwise you're just 
Nancy Reagan in raver clothing.   8)

Groove on,
					<<< Starchild >>>
