> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
> To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Thursday, April 22, 2004 10:24 AM
> Subject: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
>
>
>> SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS
>>
>> TABLE OF CONTENTS
>>
>> 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
>>
>> 2.  MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
>>
>> 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES AT STATE ASSEMBLY
>>
>> 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
>>
>> 5.  PLEASE JOIN THE SFLNC http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
>>
>>
>> 1.  AB 2433 FAILS TO GET OUT OF STATE ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE
>>
>> The SFLNC is disappointed to announce that AB 2433, state legislation
>> to allow for a later last call in San Francisco, failed to make it out
>> of committee
>> at the State Assembly, effectively killing any chance of passage this
>> year.
>>
>> While San Francisco officials were heavily in support of the bill,
>> statewide anti alcohol groups lined up against AB2433, claiming that
>> it would lead inevitably to later last call in other parts of the
>> State.
>>
>> Police Officers from Oakland also testified that later last call in
>> San
>> Francisco would create traffic accidents in Oakland that their
>> Department
>> could not fiscally handle.  It is unclear whether those officers were
>> speaking officially for the City of Oakland or just as individuals,
>> but
>> their testimony had an effect on the statewide legislators.
>>
>> In addition, testimony from a mother of a person killed by a drunk
>> driver clearly made the legislators uncomfortable in voting for the
>> legislation.
>> Assemblymember Leno attempted to contest their arguments, but the
>> format of the assembly did not offer much chance for rebuttal.  Many
>> democratic legislators left the room after the Mother Against Drunk
>> Drivers testimony and did not vote, so there were not enough votes to
>> move the bill out of committee.
>>
>> San Francisco was clearly in support of AB 2433, with Assemblymembers
>> Leno and Leland Yee, Mayor Newsom, 9 of 11 Board of Supervisor members
>> and District Attorney Kamala Harris all in favor, but that was clearly
>> not enough to overcome the more conservative politics of Sacramento.
>> We did gain valuable experience with both the Sacramento legislative
>> process and also with the claims of our opposition, so we more clearly
>> understand the challenge when  we bring back AB 2433 next year.
>>
>> The SFLNC would like to thank the 100 committed individuals who
>> showed up at the End Up at 6am to make the trip to Sacramento.  We'd
>> also like to thank Assemblymember Mark Leno and his staff for all
>> their hard work on this and other pro-nightlife legislation.  Make
>> sure to vote for Mark Leno for Assembly in this falls Assembly
>> elections.
>>
>> 2.      MAYOR GAVIN NEWSOM SIGNS 18+ AFTERHOURS LEGISLATION
>>
>> After a two year legislative process, 18+ venues and events in San
>> Francisco
>> may now apply to the Entertainment Commission for an after-hours
>> permit.
>> The legislation to allow 18+ after-hours, co-sponsored by Supervisors
>> Bevan
>> Dufty, Chris Daly and Tom Ammiano, was recently signed into law by
>> Mayor
>> Newsom.
>>
>> The SFLNC first sponsored this legislation last year but it was vetoed
>> by
>> Mayor Willie Brown.  This year the legislation was sponsored by the
>> San
>> Francisco Youth Commission, with leadership by the SFLNC's Liam Shy.
>> Congratulations to Commissioner Shy and the Youth Commission, who
>> revised the original legislation and successfully lobbied at City Hall
>> to get the legislation passed by the Board and the Mayor.  It is great
>> to see San Francisco youth fighting for their rights and taking
>> control of an element of their own destiny.   Hopefully, we'll be
>> seeing legal 18+ late night events by the summer.
>>
>> 3.  AB 2296, AN ABC REFORM BILL, PASSES IN SACRAMENTO
>>
>> While our last call legislation was defeated at the State Assembly,
>> the SFLNC and Mark Leno did score a small win recently at the State
>> Assembly.  AB 2296,  a bill designed to prevent abuse of ABC licensing
>> hearings for bars and nightclubs, passed unanimously with bipartisan
>> support out of the Assembly Government Organization Committee last
>> week.
>>
>> When an opponent of a nightclub asks to protest the issuance of a
>> liquor license, the ABC is currently required to hold a hearing
>> regardless of the merits of the opponent's complaint. Often times this
>> hearing requirement is used as a tactic to stall the process with the
>> protestor never even showing up to the hearing. This wastes the time
>> and money of nightclubs and the ABC.
>>
>> AB 2296 would allow the ABC to require protestors of venues to show
>> some responsibility. If a venue is being protested for unreasonable
>> concerns, the ABC can send a letter notifying the protestor that they
>> find their complaints to be unreasonable and they intend to approve
>> the license. The protestor could still have a hearing in this case, to
>> ensure the rights of having neighborhood concerns heard, but would be
>> required to notify the ABC that they would still like to have a
>> hearing and confirm they intend to show up. Otherwise the ABC and
>> nightclub owners can drop the protest without having a hearing.
>>
>>
>> 4.  PLANNING COMMISSION HEARING TODAY ON CHARLIE'S CLUB
>>
>> The SFLNC needs people to attend a hearing Thursday, April 22th at 3
>> PM in
>> room 400 of City Hall. The hearing is at the Planning Commission and
>> is a
>> request by the Charlie's Studio Club to receive a Place of
>> Entertainment
>> permit.
>>
>> The SFLNC became involved in this issue when the owner of the lounge
>> contacted us to find out if it was true that he needed to have a
>> permit to
>> have a DJ play music in his 49 person cocktail lounge in Bernal
>> Heights.
>> The answer was "yes" and in the process of applying for the permit a
>> few
>> neighbors got involved in opposing his application .  Right now they
>> are
>> doing everything possible to make sure that his permit is not granted.
>>   Other neighbors, including those living overtop of the bar, are
>> supportive of the permit request.
>>
>> This is a case where the owner has invested much money and effort in
>> renovations  and soundproofing and turned  what some referred to as a
>> "scary
>> biker bar" into a very cool lounge.   Yet still some folks don't want
>> a DJ
>> to play in his small bar.
>>
>> That brings us to the hearing  on Thursday.  Please show your support
>> of San
>> Francisco Culture; tell the government to support the entertainment
>> community by showing up at the hearing.   You will not be required to
>> speak;
>> your presence in the audience will be enough.
>>
>> 4.  Please join the SFLNC and help us continue our work on behalf of
>> San Francisco Nightlife http://sflnc.com/index/donate/
>>
>>
>>
>> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>>
>> House Music 101:  
>> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>>
>>
>> "The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of
>> tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants 
>> of
>> tyranny a good conscience."
>> -Albert Camus
>>
>> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of 
>> the
>> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually 
>> become
>> visible."
>> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>>
>> "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of
>> life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on 
>> the
>> beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club,
>> party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to
> that..."
>> -Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SFLNC LATE NIGHT NEWS

Sean,

	I'm sure you're right that what you witnessed is "business as usual." 
And while I probably don't know the further details of what goes on 
*behind* the scenes any more than you do, I suspect that it makes that 
hearing look good by comparison.

	Once again I think this points to the problem that government is 
simply way too big. The sheer size and complexity of it means that in 
order for the democratic process is to be upheld, there will be a huge 
number of stakeholders and an endless series of hearings and issues for 
the legislators to educate themselves about. Even if the committee 
members were all acting in good conscience -- which I don't believe for 
a minute -- it would be amazing, in a system with so many demands on 
their time and attention, if they didn't behave somewhat the way you 
describe. Except for the part about not voting, of course. That's sheer 
political cowardice.

	But until they cut way back on the number of ways that they try to run 
our lives, I suspect that none of this will change much. If there were 
fewer issues, it would be easier for the media to take a more in-depth 
look at those issues, and to educate the public on the subject matter 
and to expose any legislators who weren't taking their jobs seriously. 
It would be easier for the public to keep track of how their 
legislators were voting, and who wasn't bothering to vote at all.

	The best way to bring this about, in my view, is to start turning off 
the money tap. Vote "NO" on all taxes, bond measures, fees, etc. This 
will force lawmakers to prioritize and choose which of the things that 
they're spending resources on are things that government actually needs 
to get involved with on a routine basis.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

Aryck,

	I *strongly* recommend that you take a look at the Cato Institute  
policy analysis, "The Greatest Century That Ever Was: 25 Miraculous  
Trends of the Past 100 Years," by Stephen Moore and Julian L. Simon.

	While Moore and Simon do not focus directly on the issue of "natural"  
vs. "artificial," they do show in very concrete terms the amazing  
amount of improvement that has taken place in the United States over  
the past 100 years. And if you read between the lines, it's pretty  
obvious that much of this progress has come about as a result of  
"artificial" human advances in technology.

	Very few articles I've ever seen manage to capture the big picture of  
where we're at in terms of human civilization the way this one does. If  
you approach it with an open mind I almost guarantee it will change  
your perspective.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

P.S. -  Lots of ecstasy users (including myself) would disagree that  
the happy feeling e gives you is "fake." For me it's always felt more  
like having my blinders off; being able to see the world in an open,  
positive light.
You say nature has all the cures we need. And what about manufactured  
music? Does nature have all the sounds we need, too? Is house music  
just an unnatural symptom of a sick society? I think not! Why so much  
pessimism about human beings and their creations? Don't be a self-hater  
-- have some human pride, dammit!  8)

"We are convinced that the progress of the 20th century is not a mere  
historical blip but rather the start of a longterm trend of improved  
life on earth."
	-Stephen Moore and Julian Simon

>> Aryck,
>>
>> I'm a fan of holistic medicine and herbal cures/remedies in many
>> respects, but humans are a *part* of nature, not outside it. The
>> distinction between "natural" and "artificial" is ultimately an
>> artificial one, and trying to draw a solid line between the two makes
>> no sense. "Natural" carcinogens will cause cancer just as surely as
>> man-made carcinogens.
>>
>> To say that "any natural non processed chemical is vastly superior to
>> anything created or manufactured" is sheer ignorance, imho. Are you
>> telling me that if you knew you were going to get polio, you wouldn't
>> want the polio vaccine because it was "manufactured?" That you'd take
>> your chances on some Chinese medicine or something? That you wouldn't
>> want penicillin for any of its numerous beneficial anti-biotic
>> applications? That tobacco, a natural drug, is better than ecstasy, a
>> manufactured drug? Etcetera, etcetera...
>>
>> Groove on,

X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1106
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: My Earth Day with sea otter beads [was [sfraves] ATP: NRR: Umm Am I missing something?]

Ahh, I had a great Earth Day contributing creative talent to a worthy cause.
Last year, at a gem and mineral show, I found some adorable beads that were
painted & shaped like sea otters. I made a necklace with these small
replicas, actually had a "raft" of them strung up (5 sea otters), along with
some black beads.

While on vacation in Monterey, I visited the Friends of the Sea Otter,
www.seaotters.org, and someone noticed my necklace and asked about it. I
volunteered to make more, but work interfered and I never got around to it.

This year, in honor of Earth Day, and because I have the time & materials, I
created three additional sea otter necklaces.

I contacted the Friends of the Sea Otter last month, and they finally got
back to me. They had a grand opening celebration today (moved to the
American Tin Cannery outlet mall).

So, I drove to Monterey today and sold my necklaces to their gift shop. It
was something rewarding to do, for a small amount of money, but really just
to feel like you made a difference. Of course, I had to burn some fossil
fuel to get there! Oh well.

If you are in Monterey, be sure to stop by the store. It's a volunteer
effort (non-profit org) staffed by cool people (nature lovers).

That's it for my Earth Day activities. Now I'm off to string up some more
beads!

Greg VP

----- Original Message -----
From: "Jack Triumph" <jacktriumph@hotmail.com>
To: "SFRaves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, April 22, 2004 12:45 PM
Subject: [sfraves] ATP: NRR: Umm Am I missing something?


Isn't it earth day or something...figured I would have seen some posts from
the "diverse" community. What a beautiful day for Earth Day. that's it, I
leave the sarcasm out of this one.

On Thursday, April 22, 2004, at 07:19  PM, Starchild wrote:

> Aryck,
>
> 	I *strongly* recommend that you take a look at the Cato Institute  
> policy analysis, "The Greatest Century That Ever Was: 25 Miraculous  
> Trends of the Past 100 Years," by Stephen Moore and Julian L. Simon.
>
> 	While Moore and Simon do not focus directly on the issue of "natural"  
> vs. "artificial," they do show in very concrete terms the amazing  
> amount of improvement that has taken place in the United States over  
> the past 100 years. And if you read between the lines, it's pretty  
> obvious that much of this progress has come about as a result of  
> "artificial" human advances in technology.
>
> 	Very few articles I've ever seen manage to capture the big picture of  
> where we're at in terms of human civilization the way this one does.  
> If you approach it with an open mind I almost guarantee it will change  
> your perspective.
>
> Peace, love & liberty,

>>> Aryck,
>>>
>>> I'm a fan of holistic medicine and herbal cures/remedies in many
>>> respects, but humans are a *part* of nature, not outside it. The
>>> distinction between "natural" and "artificial" is ultimately an
>>> artificial one, and trying to draw a solid line between the two makes
>>> no sense. "Natural" carcinogens will cause cancer just as surely as
>>> man-made carcinogens.
>>>
>>> To say that "any natural non processed chemical is vastly superior to
>>> anything created or manufactured" is sheer ignorance, imho. Are you
>>> telling me that if you knew you were going to get polio, you wouldn't
>>> want the polio vaccine because it was "manufactured?" That you'd take
>>> your chances on some Chinese medicine or something? That you wouldn't
>>> want penicillin for any of its numerous beneficial anti-biotic
>>> applications? That tobacco, a natural drug, is better than ecstasy, a
>>> manufactured drug? Etcetera, etcetera...
>>>
>>> Groove on,
>>> <<< Starchild >>>
>>>
>>>
>>> On Tuesday, April 20, 2004, at 12:07  PM, aK wrote:
>>>
>>>> yknow really. . .
>>>>
>>>> if someone synthesizes anything, it may be based or similar to  
>>>> natural
>>>> compounds, but it will never be exactly the same.
>>>>
>>>> Manufactured and processed chemicals create environmental issues  
>>>> that
>>>> most
>>>> people won't even think about until years from now when it all comes
>>>> back to
>>>> bite us in the ass. . .
>>>>
>>>> and there are major diffirences between "use" and "abuse" of.
>>>>
>>>> Any natural non processed chemical is vastly superior to anything
>>>> created or
>>>> manufactured.
>>>>
>>>> Look at our medicines versus ancient medicine. . . Here in the us,
>>>> we're
>>>> wonderful at covering things up (symptoms n such), but are horrible  
>>>> at
>>>> cures. Herbalism, chinese medicine, natural medecines are the  
>>>> sources
>>>> for
>>>> actual cures/remedies, and not simply "making a headache go away",  
>>>> but
>>>> making it so you don't get headaches in the first place. (eg)
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> people who tend to argue about the natural drug thing also tend to  
>>>> be
>>>> the
>>>> same people that embrace manufactured chemicals on a daily basis.  
>>>> Which
>>>> realistically, if they changed their tune, they would be much more
>>>> likely to
>>>> find cures for the ailments that they were covering up with their  
>>>> daily
>>>> Alleve or high blood pressure meds or whatever.
>>>>
>>>> I've been thru several surgeries on my knees, feet, hands. . .mostly
>>>> from
>>>> broken things. . . after the first time, I tossed out the vicodin
>>>> crap, and
>>>> the pills they told me to take. I simply used herbs, cannabis,  
>>>> proper
>>>> eating
>>>> and diet, and spirituality, and I recieved relief that no  
>>>> manufactured
>>>> drug
>>>> has ever been able to give me, relief that lasts a lifetime,  
>>>> safely. I
>>>> used
>>>> to take zoloft, n xanax, n tried all of these other things, but
>>>> ultimately I
>>>> gave all those things up for natural remedies, and have been much  
>>>> much
>>>> better off since.
>>>>
>>>> it's not a simple as "one pill a day", but it actually works at
>>>> remedying
>>>> the cause of the issues.
>>>>

were

> replicas, actually had a "raft" of them strung up (5 sea otters), along
with
> some black beads.
>
> While on vacation in Monterey, I visited the Friends of the Sea Otter,
> www.seaotters.org, and someone noticed my necklace and asked about it. I
> volunteered to make more, but work interfered and I never got around to
it.
>
> This year, in honor of Earth Day, and because I have the time & materials,
I
> created three additional sea otter necklaces.
>
> I contacted the Friends of the Sea Otter last month, and they finally got
> back to me. They had a grand opening celebration today (moved to the
> American Tin Cannery outlet mall).
>
> So, I drove to Monterey today and sold my necklaces to their gift shop. It
> was something rewarding to do, for a small amount of money, but really
just

> fuel to get there! Oh well.

Subject: [sfraves] Davey D on Sampling and Hip Hop

--=====================_1301301==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

During Hip Hop's Golden Age Sampling Was A Creative Force
By Davey D
San Jose Mercury News

One of the most frequent complaints these days from those who've been
down with hip-hop for years is that the music has lost its creative
spark.

Today's popular rap songs are viewed as results of a record-industry
formula.  Their subject matter centers on sex and violence.  We get
song after song about macking, pimping, street life and being a playa.

Aside from the redundant themes, critics point to a lack of musical
variety.  Producers such as P.  Diddy epitomize the trend of taking
their main riffs and hooks from classic funk or disco songs and
reworking them.

Folks who've been around for a while cringe when they hear the
reworked version of a vintage Police, Prince or Rick James song.
``Wy are these rappers so lazy?'' they ask.

Actually, the rappers aren't lazy.  But keeping things ``simple''
(that is, not creative) meets today's expectations of the record
industry, and many outside it aren't aware of the creative
stranglehold on rap artists.

To fully understand, one must look back to the most creative period in
rap.  Keep in mind that, for many who came up in the inner city and
became part of the ``hip-hop generation,'' there were no such things
as glee clubs, music classes or bands at school.  Such programs had
been gutted to balance budgets.

For example, I went to one of the best public high schools in the
country, New York's Bronx High School of Science.  It was the
equivalent of today's magnet schools such as Lowell in San Francisco,
but there were no bands or music classes.

For many aspiring musicians who were trying literally to create
something out of nothing, rap music filled a void.  They were inspired
to seek out old James Brown and funk, jazz and blues albums.  In the
early dys, they simply rapped over percussion breaks in popular
songs.

When hip-hop records first came out, from Sugar Hill, backup bands
were hired to replay the old-school classics.  But by the mid-'80s,
the backup bands were disappearing, sampling had become common, and
fledging hip-hop producers were defining how that tool was used.

Producers such as the Latin Rascals, with their signature rapid-fire
cuts and edits; the legendary Marley Marl; hip-house innovator Todd
Terry; a young Teddy Riley; and the late DJ Scott La Rock were among
the first and most innovative masters of sampling.

Many rappers had rejected the formulaic disco music of the '70s and
uninspired funk of the '80s, with its drum machines and listless
singing.  The '80s sampling craze focused on resurrecting James Brown,
Sly Stone, and other funk and soul masters whose music was all but
ignored then by mainstream outlets.

As sampling became more popular, hip-hop DJs got ever more creative
with what had become the genre's premier instrument.  Tey would dig
into the crates and find a James Brown grunt, a Sly Stone drum
pattern, a George Clinton bass line, and then use them to create ``a
music collage.''

When the James Brown-inspired sound began to wane in popularity,
hip-hop artists turned to jazz, sampling Cannonball Adderley, Grover
Washington Jr. and everybody in between.

This period, from 1988 to 1993, is considered the golden age of rap,
its most creative period.  Many of the sampling techniques and
innovative approaches to creating music influenced the whole industry.

But that creative period waned overnight when what Prince has
described as the ``bean counters'' became interested in protecting
intellectual property.  I'll have more on that in my next column.
======================================

Sampling Creativity Squelched  By Record Companies
By Davey D
San Jose Mercury

My last column (Eye, April 2) dealt with the evolution of sampling
into a compelling art form; today, we look at the constraints on
sampling.

Hip-hop producers usedsampling to create intricate music collages
that reflected the artists, genres and time periods of the sampled
material but were also substantially different from them.  Landmark
albums such as the Beastie Boys' ``Paul's Boutique'' (1989) and Public
Enemy's ``Fear of a Black Planet'' (1990) showed the heights sampling
could reach.

Contrary to the beliefs of critics who longed for the ``good ol' days
of real musicianship,'' sampling stayed true in many ways to the
music-making spirit of previous generations.

Bay Area music professor, author and radio personality Ricky Vincent
explains in his book ``The History of Funk'' that sampling was not
much different from the ``riffing'' (or borrowing) and ``vamping''
(twisting) done for decades by musicians.  He points out that artists
ranging from the jazz greats to James Brown and the Average White Band
often riffed and vamped existing harmonies to make them their own.
This concept, he says, was not just a major part of black music but a
cornerstone of all music.

Over the past 20 years, it was only the tools and technologies that
changed: Instead of playing drums, musicians used drum machines.
Instead of playing piano, they used keyboards and synthesizers.
Instead of re-creating older sounds on their instruments, they copied
them directly from recordings.

Vincent goes on to argue that the evolution of music-making has been
cut short by record-industry executives who reaped an economic
windfall by enforcing copyright and intellectual property laws.

Today, no one would argue that a major sample from an earlier work
should not be paid for.  A good example of such a sample can be heard
on MC Hammer's megahit ``U Can't Touch This,'' which borrowed from
Rick James' monster hit ``Super Freak.''

What became sticky was when producers took small bits and pieces from
earlier songs.  For example, what if an artist sampled a small snippet
of ``Super Freak,'' slowed it down, played it backward and added a
fraction of a second from a Prince scream?  Then while the artist was
rappng, he brought in harmony from a popular TV tune behind him?

Although the substance and sound of the result were unique to it,
record labels wanted substantial compensation for everything they
could claim as their own.  The financial claims often were made in the
name of artists, but, as George Clinton once pointed out, he doesn't
get a dime when his music is sampled.

In the early '90s, some companies hired youngsters to work as musical
bounty hunters.  They would listen to new rap records and collect $500
if they could find an obscure drum beat or bass line that had been
sampled.

As a result of the industry response to sampling, some rap artists
were left with little or no profit after paying fees for their
samples.  And God help them if they did a spontaneous rap using a
small portion of an existing harmony or melody.

The economics dictated that sampling be reeled in.  For example, 10
years after Public Enemy introduced ``cram sampling,'' a technique
inspired by Phil Spectre's Wall of Sound recording tchnique, the
group owed about $500,000 for sounds it had borrowed.

Bay Area icons Sway and King Tech released the album ``This or That''
in 1999, and the samples cost them $300,000.  They paid roughly $3,000
each time their collaborator, DJ Revolution, did a scratch.

Some artists, including Dr.  Dre, have simply brought the rights to
old records in order to use samples from them.

But the opportunities for hip-hoppers to borrow from the past are
severely limited today, in contrast to the late '80s and early '90s,
and hip-hop is less creative now.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Davey D's hip-hop column is published biweekly in Eye. Contact him at
mrdaveyd@aol.com




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_1301301==.ALT--

ALUMNI, Saturday May 22, 2004

The sequel. Number two in a series of parties that revisit the sights and
sounds of San Francisco as it was ten years ago. Acid House, Breaks,
Techno and more. All music played is from before 1995. The line is Doc
Martin, Dutch, Spun and Markie Mark.

375 11th Street, San Francisco.  $5 before 11pm. $10 after.
9pm - Very Late :)

> > Martin, Dutch, Spun and Markie Mark.
> >

> > 9pm - Very Late :)

> > tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of
> > tyranny a good conscience."

> > rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually 
>become

> > party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to
> > that..."

> ALUMNI, Saturday May 22, 2004
>
> The sequel. Number two in a series of parties that revisit the sights and
> sounds of San Francisco as it was ten years ago. Acid House, Breaks,
> Techno and more. All music played is from before 1995. The line is Doc
> Martin, Dutch, Spun and Markie Mark.
>
> 375 11th Street, San Francisco.  $5 before 11pm. $10 after.
> 9pm - Very Late :)
>
> Check out the flyer at
> http://www.dnalounge.com/flyers/2004/05/22-alumni.html
>
>
>
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>
> "The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of
> tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of
> tyranny a good conscience."
> -Albert Camus
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
> "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of
> life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the
> beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club,
> party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to
that..."
> -Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves
>

Date: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 13:30:45 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0

	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
Message-ID: <BAY9-DAV37kTJXnGC6o0004b6ac@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 23 Apr 2004 20:30:46.0772 (UTC) FILETIME=[DBBAEB40:01C42971]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] what's Dutch gonna play?, was Re: [sfraves] BSP: Alumni Saturday May 22, 2004

Yanno I would have to say that Messiah - Temple of Dreams and Thunderdome
were hardcore-ish, but in todays terms they're basically trance. 21st
Century Jesus came out in what - 1992? The Shamen - Entact album was
pre-1995 as well. That's pretty damn trancey music right there. Move Any
Mountain anyone? My opinion is based on relative definitions of trance we
have today. Opus III - Mindfruit and Sunscreem - 03 (ozone). Both of those
are pretty fluffy. Luv U More and the eternal epic Fine Day are considered
trance(y) these days. Back then the genre didn't have a name. It wasn't as
firmly set apart from the other genres of the time. Looking back now though,
that music is definitely trance.

:: r ::

At 11:31 AM 4/23/2004, you wrote:
>i'm there.
>
>i wonder what Dutch is gonna play?  i dont' think psy trance was invented
>yet.  i could be wrong.  there may have been some goa though.
>
>i know there are some Dutch house tapes from back then.  (all the
>psy-trancers cringing right about now)
>
>Jonas

There definitely was pre-95 trance.  The genre coalesced during 91-93:  Jam 
& Spoon, MLO, Spicelab, Lords of Acid, Sven Vath, etc.  An offspring of 
acid house and techno.

Love,

Apollo



> > ALUMNI, Saturday May 22, 2004
> >

>"Boomer Love" CD series mixed by Jonas Robledo (2004): request your copies
>today:

>1: "Boomer" - hOuse
>2: "Boom-A-Saurus" - h0use

>4: "Project Boom" - h0use
>5: "Boomin' down the street in my '64" - ol skool hip-hop

>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_10368288==.ALT--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] what's Dutch gonna play?, was Re: [sfraves] BSP: Alumni Saturday
 May 22, 2004

Are we talking stuff that sounded like some form of trance here?

Because if so, there was obviously mass amounts of music pre-95 that would 
fit the bill. From years of Detroit stuff, to early progressive house (and 
progressive techno), and early German techno. And let's not forget early 
"tech-house".

I thought we were talking about "trance" as a commonly used term to describe 
the sub-genre of electronic music.

>From: "innocentchild" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>
>To: "Van Mundegaarde" 
><electrofunk138@hotmail.com>,<nesound@hotmail.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] what's Dutch gonna play?, was Re: [sfraves] BSP: 
>Alumni Saturday May 22, 2004
>Date: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 13:30:45 -0700
>
>Yanno I would have to say that Messiah - Temple of Dreams and Thunderdome
>were hardcore-ish, but in todays terms they're basically trance. 21st
>Century Jesus came out in what - 1992? The Shamen - Entact album was
>pre-1995 as well. That's pretty damn trancey music right there. Move Any
>Mountain anyone? My opinion is based on relative definitions of trance we
>have today. Opus III - Mindfruit and Sunscreem - 03 (ozone). Both of those
>are pretty fluffy. Luv U More and the eternal epic Fine Day are considered
>trance(y) these days. Back then the genre didn't have a name. It wasn't as
>firmly set apart from the other genres of the time. Looking back now 
>though,
>that music is definitely trance.
>
>:: r ::
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] what's Dutch gonna play?, was Re: [sfraves] BSP: Alumni Saturday May 22, 2004

If it looks like trance, smells like trance, and sounds like trance... it's
trance. The whole genre naming scheme is a farce anyway. This is prove with
dnb and jungle. Same thing to some and to other distinctly different.
Progressive house vs trance has the same problem. So yes, I am talking about
trance in the *commonly used term* here. The term hadn't been coined in the
pre-1995 world, but it did exist.

:: r ::

>I am talking about
>trance in the *commonly used term* here. The term hadn't been coined in the

That's what I was thinking. But I really have no frame of reference. I had 
read about trance in the mid-90's, and it was described so much like techno 
that I wanted to hear it badly, but it was not untill 98 or 99 that I 
actually heard a lot of it at a party, enough to recogize that it was 
"trance".

Subject: Re: [sfraves] what's Dutch gonna play?, was Re: [sfraves] BSP: Alumni
 Saturday May 22, 2004


Judging what Dutch threw down on the decks at the last Alumni party, I
hardly doubt you'll hear *ANY* trance this time around...unless they
decide to bust out some of the classics. Thump parties are a good place to
hear him play Trance.  I have pictures of many of Dutch's records thrown
down on the decks from the last Alumni, not one single record played in
the 8 hour set between Dutch, Jeno, Markie Mark, Galen and Solar was
"TRANCE", house, ACID house, yes, Trance at that Alumni, was, present
in spirit.... not on the decks.

Here are some samples of what Dutch played:

V.A.L.I.S. - Sunday Morning, Berlin
http://www.tribe.net/tribe/servlet/template/pub%2CViewPhoto.vm/context/pcard?page=3&currentoffset=13&parentid=361e4a03-503b-4732-98a1-707d5d7e211d

R & S Records - Order to Dance
http://www.tribe.net/tribe/servlet/template/pub%2CViewPhoto.vm/context/pcard?page=3&currentoffset=14&parentid=361e4a03-503b-4732-98a1-707d5d7e211d

Edge Records *3
http://www.tribe.net/tribe/servlet/template/pub%2CViewPhoto.vm/context/pcard?page=4&currentoffset=18&parentid=361e4a03-503b-4732-98a1-707d5d7e211d

TZ3 Sabam TM
http://www.tribe.net/tribe/servlet/template/pub%2CViewPhoto.vm/context/pcard?page=4&currentoffset=19&parentid=361e4a03-503b-4732-98a1-707d5d7e211d

O2 Records Psykotropic Hypnosis SL2 Remix
http://www.tribe.net/tribe/servlet/template/pub%2CViewPhoto.vm/context/pcard?page=4&currentoffset=20&parentid=361e4a03-503b-4732-98a1-707d5d7e211d

Moonshine Music, Transform Transformation
Ralphie D. Mix
http://www.tribe.net/tribe/servlet/template/pub%2CViewPhoto.vm/context/pcard?page=4&currentoffset=21&parentid=361e4a03-503b-4732-98a1-707d5d7e211d

OHZone Records, Orbital Belfast
http://www.tribe.net/tribe/servlet/template/pub%2CViewPhoto.vm/context/pcard?page=4&currentoffset=22&parentid=361e4a03-503b-4732-98a1-707d5d7e211d

Urban Shakedown produced by Mickey Finn
http://www.tribe.net/tribe/servlet/template/pub%2CViewPhoto.vm/context/pcard?page=4&currentoffset=23&parentid=361e4a03-503b-4732-98a1-707d5d7e211d

> If it looks like trance, smells like trance, and sounds like trance... it's
> trance. The whole genre naming scheme is a farce anyway. This is prove with
> dnb and jungle. Same thing to some and to other distinctly different.
> Progressive house vs trance has the same problem. So yes, I am talking about
> trance in the *commonly used term* here. The term hadn't been coined in the
> pre-1995 world, but it did exist.
>
> :: r ::

> > >have today. Opus III - Mindfruit and Sunscreem - 03 (ozone). Both of
> those
> > >are pretty fluffy. Luv U More and the eternal epic Fine Day are
> considered
> > >trance(y) these days. Back then the genre didn't have a name. It wasn't
> as
> > >firmly set apart from the other genres of the time. Looking back now

Subject: RE: [sfraves] nrr - what is song is most "wrong"

I have a track called "The Chicken Track". It starts out with some weird 
spoken wordintro about how irradiated chickens destroy a city. Then the best 
part  - it breaks into this SEVERELY cheesey clubby house type track, with a 
person screaming "Bawk Bawk Bawk Bawk Bawk Ba-Gawk" like a chicken. It is 
possibly the most obnoxious thing on earth, and the best "end of the night 
get the fuck out " track I have ever heard (next to the Pleasurehead remix 
of the Neverending Story theme song).

M-

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Mac Recording help

Well, the Media Access Control address is how Microsoft deals with DRM 
at the Data-Link layer. Obviously his problem in this case is that he 
hasn't registered his MAC address with MS and the authorities. He should 
run Windows Update hourly to remedy this.

- Nic.

John B. wrote:

> I don't get it.  What does your friend's network adaptor's MAC address 
> have to do with audio recording?
>
>
> cya,
> john
>
>

is=20
possibly the most obnoxious thing on earth, and the best "end of the =
night=20
get the fuck out " track I have ever heard (next to the Pleasurehead =
remix=20
of the Neverending Story theme song).

-----Original Message-----
From: Buzz [mailto:buzz@sonic.net] 
Sent: Friday, April 23, 2004 3:43 PM
To: John B.
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Mac Recording help

Well, the Media Access Control address is how Microsoft deals with DRM 
at the Data-Link layer. Obviously his problem in this case is that he 
hasn't registered his MAC address with MS and the authorities. He should

run Windows Update hourly to remedy this.

- Nic.

John B. wrote:

> I don't get it.  What does your friend's network adaptor's MAC address

> have to do with audio recording?
>
>
> cya,
> john
>
>
> On Apr 23, 2004, at 12:12 PM, Jason wrote:
>
>> I have a good friend recording in MAC and needs to find a simple
program
>> to record multiple tracks in. He has an afternoon to learn it. He has
>> two or more wav files he has already recorded and needs to retain the
>> stereo properties and mix them al together being able to shift the
start
>> and end points of each piece as needed. He is currently using Amadeus
>> and Bias Peak. So if you have any help it would be great. Thanks
>>
>>
>>
>> Jason

>>
>>
>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] what's Dutch gonna play?, was Re: [sfraves] BSP: Alumni Saturday May 22, 2004

Not to beat a dead horse, but everyone here should know that the first =
"trance" song was "Giorgio Moroder - The chase" from the Midnight =
Express soundtrack in 1978.

It has these trance elements:
4/4 beat
arp with filter cut-off sweeps
massive delayed sound effects (just like todays prog)
Written by a German
Remixed by Oakenfold AND Jam and Spoon

If that isn't the first trance song ever then kick me in the face.

the best dance tracks ever, in my opinion.

> Yanno I would have to say that Messiah - Temple of Dreams and =20
> Thunderdome
> were hardcore-ish, but in todays terms they're basically trance. 21st
> Century Jesus came out in what - 1992? The Shamen - Entact album was
> pre-1995 as well. That's pretty damn trancey music right there. Move =20
> Any
> Mountain anyone? My opinion is based on relative definitions of trance =
=20
> we
> have today. Opus III - Mindfruit and Sunscreem - 03 (ozone). Both of =20
> those
> are pretty fluffy. Luv U More and the eternal epic Fine Day are =20
> considered
> trance(y) these days. Back then the genre didn't have a name. It =20
> wasn't as
> firmly set apart from the other genres of the time. Looking back now =20
> though,
> that music is definitely trance.

Friday, April 23, 2004 ** SOMA Sessions: D&B w/DJ FLIGHT + ROHAN **

SOMA Sessions
Drum & Bass Fourth Fridays @ AsiaSF

Friday April 23, 2004

DJ FLIGHT (BBC 1Xtra, Metalheadz - UK)

Nathalie Wright aka DJ Flight's accomplishments speak for themselves; a res=
ident at the legendary Metalheadz Sunday Sessions and at Fabio's Swerve nig=
ht in London, host of her own radio show, "Next Chapter" on BBC's 1Xtra and=
, most recently, a co-producer with Breakage as "Alias" for 31 Records. All=
 this plus a heavy DJ touring schedule showcasing the latest cuts from all =
flavors of upfront D&B adds up to a knockout Bay Area debut.

ROHAN (Bassbin Recordings - Dublin)

At the heart of Ireland's Drum 'n Bass scene lies Bassbin Recordings in Dub=
lin. Co-founded by Rohan and Naphta in 1996, the organization has grown to =
include sublabels, Breakin, Solas and Looney Toonz and is home to such tale=
nts as Beta 2, Zero Tolerance, Equinox and Breakage. SOMA Sessions welcomes=
 the return of the Bassbin don for another rolling set of dubbed-out floor =
smashers.

Resident support:
DJ M
SOUND:BOY

Discount $8 presale tickets available now via PayPal!!  To purchase or sign=
 up on our mailing list, visit
http://somasessions.com

Hours: 10:30pm - 3am
Entry: 21+ with photo ID
Tickets: $8 presale
Bar: $3 drink specials all night!

AsiaSF serves 3-Star Cal-Asian cuisine in a festive and stylish atmosphere.=
 For Sun-Thurs dinner reservations, please call 415.255.ASIA(2742) between =
the hours of 1pm and 8pm.

y Lounge in Oakland, CA**

May Day Trivia:

=95 Traditional May Day celebrations were pre-Christian agricultural festiv=
als. Eventually the significance was lost and the practices survived merely=
 as popular festivities. (Which can also be said about other holidays: Hall=
oween, Christmas, Easter.)

=95 A widespread superstition held that washing the face in the May Day mor=
ning dew would beautify the skin.

=95 In Hawaii, May Day is Lei Day. Everyone gives the gift of a lei to anot=
her, putting it around the receiver's neck and accompanying the gift with t=
he traditional kiss. Observing practices of the islanders for centuries, Le=
i Day began to be observed officially in 1928. Some Hawaiian celebrations a=
re complete with pageants, a Lei Queen and her court.

=95 In 1889, a congress of world Socialist parties held in Paris voted to s=
upport the U.S. labor movement's demand for an 8-hour day. It chose May 1, =
1890, as a day of demonstrations in favor of the 8-hour day. Afterward, May=
 1 became a holiday called Labor Day in many nations. It resembles the Sept=
ember holiday in the U.S. The holiday is especially important in socialist =
and Communist countries--when political demonstrations are held.


http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1241

Friday, May 7, 2004 ** Melon : Josh Wink **

Red Melon is proud to finally be able to showcase one of the biggest succes=
s stories in the underground house movement. Ask yourself how many globally=
 respected, underground artist-producer-DJs have turned-down offers to tour=
 with U2, and you will likely draw a short list. Josh Wink is such an artis=
t -- one who is unassuming, yet enjoys a cult following and who places arti=
stic integrity above all else. Owner of Ovum Recordings and remixer of mega=
-talents such as Sting, Depeche Mode and Ladytron, Josh has made only rare =
appearences in San Francisco, so don't miss out.

Supporting Josh will be Dano, Dj and tech house producer from San Francisco=
=2E  After a long winter touring Australia, New Zealand, and Eastern Europe=
, Dano is back in town working in the studio for a few months.  Dano has th=
ree new releases coming out simultaneously on Silicone Soul's Darkroom Dubs=
 imprint, Honchos Music, and Red Melon.  He will be spinning fresh techy gr=
ooves along with red melon biz partner JZ.  No stranger to the Melon experi=
ence, JZ is responsible for some of the most memorable sets in the seven ye=
ars of parties Red Melon has produced.  It will be just like old times!

If you are serious about your Red Melon parties, this Melon is not to be mi=
ssed! Get there before 11:00pm to take advantage of an earlybird cover char=
ge of $10 at San Francisco's newest venue, Mighty, located at 119 Utah St a=
t 15th Street. Mighty is a beautiful renovated warehouse with a touch of te=
chnology and art and the massive sound system that made Club Townsend a San=
 Francisco favorite. All of that plus cheap drinks too! You can't go wrong.=
 Trust us.
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1225
San Francisco California, USA

Saturday, May 8, 2004 ** (Atmosfere) is Back! **

ATMOSFERE

After a brief hiatus Fatsouls is proud to present a very special Atmosfere =
session

As some of you may know, we have made changes to the event's schedule. Atmo=
sfere is now held intermittently as opposed to its usual monthly schedule.

Following the first two highly successful Deep and Sexy albums, Wave Music =
proudly presents the third installment in the series. This time Matthias "M=
atty" Heilbronn continues the legacy established by Francois K. and Ron Tre=
nt, crafting another masterful mix of sultry soul that keeps the pulse pump=
ing from start to finish.


Join us for the San Francisco Release party in support of the Deep & Sexy 3=
 album on Wave Music.

              Atmosfere

        (A Fatsouls Production)

     Saturday, May 8, 2004

     Club Six - 60 6 Street

     (between Market & Mission @ Jessie)

                with resident DJ Said

         (Performing "To Motherland" Live)

&

  special guest

Matthias "Matty" Heilbronn

(Wave Music, Soulflower Production, NY)

Throughout his illustrious career, Matthias has steadily achieved internati=
onal acclaim for his trademark sophisticated soulful sound: a glorious blen=
d of soulful, jazz-inflected deep house, percussive Afro-Latin rhythms and =
infectious progressive tribal beats.  He has rocked parties and festivals a=
ll over the world with his spellbinding DJ sets and seamless musical journe=
ys, not to mention receiving the #1 of the decade spot by DJ Magazine for h=
is Wave/Chez/Naked compilation CD.

+

Mauricio Aviles

(Naked Music, Loveslap Records)

&

Rasaki Aladokun

(Performing Live)

Rasaki is a miracle percussionist with over 25 years of experience.  He has=
 been a featured artist in the recording of many notable musicians such as =
King Sunny Ade, Stevie Wonder and Babatunde Olatunji to name a few. Don't m=
iss his extraordinary fusion of talking drum, conga, bongo and house music.

         Doors Open / 10pm -4am / 21+  with ID

        Cover Charge $10 before Midnight.

         www.fatsouls.com, www.wavemusic.com,
                       www.clubsix1.com

With the third DJ series installment from the sages of soulful house - =ADW=
ave Music - =ADcomes legendary Matty Heilbronn to the decks, for a sultry a=
nd soulful ride worth every drop of sweat.   - XLR8R

Matty comes correct with this sublime mix for Wave.  And it's really rather=
 damn special, including as yet unreleased material as well as some you wil=
l already know and love... Great label, great guy!  I really can't fault th=
is.  - M8

Following on from Francois K. and Ron Trent who mixed the first two albums =
in this series is a daunting task, but Matty rides this "Wave" with gusto. =
 - Keep On

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.

To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or
sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Where Have All the Divas Gone?

Sat Apr 24, 5:35 PM ET

By Michael Paoletta
NEW YORK (Billboard) - It's 2004. Do you know where today's crossover dance 
divas are?

Since the mid-'90s, female dance artists -- not to be confused with female 
"electronic" artists or those featured on a track -- have experienced 
difficulty in crossing over their rhythmic sounds from dancefloors to the 
more lucrative mainstream.

http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&cid=769&e=2&u=/nm/20040424/music_nm/music_dance_dc






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: [sfraves] [SRR?] Digital Music Education Foundation -- Update

--0-1515243452-1082908320=:60412
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Id: 
Content-Disposition: inline

Hi All, 

Some of you may remember my posting of a few months
back reporting on the non-profit I'm trying to get
going. The Digital Music Education Foundation's goal
is to use DJing, electronic music produciton tools,
and other music software to teach math and science to
middle and high school students. I wanted to share
some very early feedback with you. 

I recently completed my first class entitled "DJ
Algebra" at a San Francisco public school and it went
over really well. DJ Algebra is a program that uses
beat matching (specifically the pitch adjustments on
the turtables) to teach techniques of solving simple
algebraic equations. The kids learn a little math, get
an idea of what DJing is, and get a brief chance to
try it out themselves. I bring a prepared presentation
and some simple worksheets for them to do. I'm
currently reworking the materials based on some great
feedback I got in the first class in order to make it
more accessible to a variety of students. 

I hope to bring the class to more kids in the fall but
my financial resources are extremely limited so it
looks like maybe I'll be able to afford to do this
once or twice next school year. I'm still looking for
some way to fund this venture and expand it to more
schools and other districts. Any suggestions are
welcome.  We are also in need of equipment, computers,
mixers, decks, etc. to enable a more in depth program
to be available to an intitial group kids next year. 
So if you have somethign you don't need anymore and
can afford to donate let me know.

I've also attached two pics for your viewing pleasure.


Peace, 

Peter

Subject: [sfraves] Riding BAssWaves Saturday night =)

OK.. so like ya know, Basswaves was so Fuckin' Totally Mondo Dope Saturday night... I literally had a smile on my face nearly the whole time I was there lastnight... so trippy!!

OK.. so like my Favorite DJ of the night was oooh Gosh.. what was his name... Jeff Richmond!!  Good Shit man... I Loved it!!  He totally started out spinning this like House at 1st, ya know, but like progressively got kida faster & yummier during his set!  Then he mixed alota Acid Trance & Acid Techno like nearly all throughout the rest of his set & slipped in some Booty Vocal House in between parts and also some yummy Breakbeats here and there... Oh mY Goodness man.. Hello 2Day, that sert fuckin' Rocked!!! YAY!  I mean... musically I"m not tryin' 2 B like biased or whatever, but that set did fill me up!  I danced soooooooo hard!

BUt I mean... I Loved all the sets that I was there 4! So like me & Jaze went out 2 this party 2gether and as soon as we got in there, there was this OK.. I don't remember who was spinning in the front room when we got there 'cause I was like kinda overwhelmed w/ the site of like hella Family there chillin' under the parachute... LoL... & I kinda paid more attention 2 all of them instead of the music @ that point... LoL

Anywaze, went 2 the back room & Wow... Origami was spinning this Bad Ass House set w/ his bass guitar & fuck man... that was Sick as always!!!

Oh Oh Oh... OK... I remember now, the DJ in the front was spinning Break Beats!!! It was Dope!!I mean... the crowd in the party was like still kinda small during that point, so there was some room on the floor 2 Groove!!  Yeah, OK..I remember now 'cause while i was talkin' 2 Shane, I was like dancing @ the same time!  LoL

Jeff Richmond spun next in the front room & in the back... Sticky spun this Groovy like funky Hip Hop, Break Beaty set & @ 1 point, he was playing MJ's "Billie Jean" over this track & it was Sick!!  I was was totally diggin' it man!

After JR's set, Konkers went on... OK... so yeah, I was totally ready 2 hear like bangin' Break Beats comin' from his set, but Hello 2Day, he spun fuckin' Techno!!  Good Shit man.. I Loved it!!!  I Loved alota the songs he played 'cause alot of them had like these funky breakdowns in them... So Dope!  Oh Yeah... I was totally feelin' this set also on the floor!  OK... yeah... this had 2 B 1 of my other favorite sets 'cause well.. I was dancing to every set i was there for, but Konkers was Dope!

The party itself was Groovy!  It was totally Family filled, Oh Wow... so many Groovers showed up who I haven't seen in a hella long time, Awesome vibe throughout the venue, decorations were sorta minimal, but there were a few.  There was some discomfort I was feeling 'cause well, the chain(s) on my wallet fell off & 4 some reason, I thought i should put my wallet in my back left pocket.  So whenever I sat down, it felt so odd on my ass with my wallet on the wrong side!  But I did change it 2 the right back pocket, so all was Groovy w/ that situation =)  LoL

So like yeah, Jaze kinda had an early day on Sunday, but was very tempted 2 stay 'til Sun up.  BUt he didn't give in and made sure we left @ a decent time, no matter how hard it was.  I mean, I think we were both fulfilled with the amount of time we spent there & were hyper lil' Ravers on the way home! LoL

I just want 2 say Mondo Thanks 2 the Crew behind that Sat NIght Shindig!  LoL... I was a Mondo Happy Camper! =)

Take Care,
Peace =-> O§bY {8O)

Coming in April on Cobalt Radio: Unit 21 live. 
Gravy FM

Unit 21 Bio : 

Stanislav "Slam" Vdovin and Eugene Martynov began making music and writing 
songs at the tender age of 13. Slam's love of dance and electronic music grew 
from listening to late night radio programs over the past three years. Eugene 
has a deep interest in guitar music, and prides himself on focusing on the 
world's best guitarists. Slam and Eugene became close friends in 2002 and formed 
Unit 21 in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia in February 2003. 

With Slam on keyboards and electronic software and Eugene on guitar and bass, 
Unit 21's goal is to become well-known professionals in electronic music 
without a concrete style specialization. With diverse abilities and passion for 
their work, the music of Unit 21 will continually progress on the leading edge 
of electronic music." 

biography by Cobalt Recordings. 

Tracklisting for April : 

01. Josh! 
02. Fallen 
03. Kids 
03A. Just Say Stop 
04. Sleepy 
05. Theory Two 
06. Affect 
07. Fit 
08. Omen 3 
09. Omen 2 
10. Omen 1 
11. Oncoming 
*recorded live* 

Speacial Treat at the end of the show from Cobalt Recordings a speacial 
speacial sneak peak but ya must tune in in order to find out what the bonus is.     

www.cobaltrecordings.net 
www.gravyfm.net



Tony Russo 
Cobalt Recordings and PMR Records
Co-owner, Promotions, Bookings
E-mail: monk7923@aol.com 

www.cobaltrecordings.net 
www.spins.us 
www.gravyfm.net

Just thought I'd let you know that Canada and Mexico are now no longer
options due to the "Smart Border Declaration" signed a few years back -
you're gonna need to go a lot further now.=20

Also, college will no longer provide a haven from being drafted - the
way the current bills are being written, you will be allowed to finish
the semester you are currently enrolled in and that's the only deferment
you will receive.

Bleh,

-Aaron

X-MIMEOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1106
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Friday night: D&B at AsiaSF (drunks and barefeet but pounding bass music)

------=_NextPart_000_0073_01C42BD1.DBF8EE60
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

OK, I just had to post a message about my fun time on Friday night.

Originally, I had wanted to go to the element party (three fifteen), =
because Jack T. was spinning, but something happened when they were =
setting up (the 5-0 got 'em).

So instead I headed to AsiaSF really late (around midnight) for the SOMA =
Sessions (Drum 'n Bass Fourth Fridays), since I have never been to this =
party.

My first impression, after paying 12 bucks, was uh-oh, these aren't my =
kind of party people. It was a bunch of drunks upstairs in the =
restaurant, behind the bar area, acting nasty with each other (and no =
D&B to be heard). I could have sworn that I saw a flesh flash, like =
naked asses, or strip-tease scenarios, but the people standing around =
were blocking my view.

Actually, for a minute there I thought it was Michael the Red Stickman, =
cause I know he likes to "moon" occassionally.  But it wasn't him, just =
some male strippers (or drunk guys) and drunk girlies.

Then I heard the pounding bass and saw the stairs to the basement, which =
I bounded down, checked my long-sleeve SFLNC shirt, and got into the =
music for the rest of the night (until closing).

Just danced really hard, got sweaty, had a great time, although I didn't =
know anybody and no one spoke to me (the music was loud, after all).

The only annoyance was a very drunk Asian girl on the dance floor, who =
was dancing barefoot, a dangerous thing to do in a bar. I made sure to =
keep an eye on my feet and dance movements so as not to hurt her, but =
she kept getting closer (and following me on the floor somewhat).

Girls: Please don't do this--it's not wise to be in a close space where =
people are moving fast and you have no foot protection!
(duh--common sense, please).

I am surprised that the bouncer did not say anything to her. Anyways, it =
was still a great time, I just hope my pretty Asian girlfriend made it =
home OK (she was wasted).

Greg VP

Subject: [sfraves] Orbital disbands....

Orbital to Disband After Next LP

Joshua Sharp reports:
In 15 years, techno mainstays Phil and Paul Hartnoll have covered a lot
of ground. All Melvilles aside, hailing Orbital to be the most
successful crossover group of the electronic persuasion would not be an
inordinate boast. With six full-length releases under their belt, as
well as an incalculable number of singles, soundtrack offerings, remixes
and collaborations, the boys are finally ready to end it all.

"I think we feel that Orbital has run its course," said Paul Hartnoll
via the official Orbital site. "We're both pursuing different avenues
with our music. And we've been sat, as brothers, in the same room for 15
years now-- and studios are always confined spaces-- I think it's time
for a change."

Before closing the curtain on their decade-and-a-half discography, the
duo is set to release their final record, entitled The Blue Album
(Weezer mash-up comment withheld for the sake of humanity) on June 21st.
Says Paul of the swan song's sound: "It's closer in character to our
first album than our later ones, if only because we made it in our own
time and for ourselves." Confirmed titles so far include "You Lot",
"Acid Pants", "Bath Time", "Easy Serve", and "One Perfect Sunrise", the
latter featuring Dead Can Dance vocalist Lisa Gerrard. The album will be
followed by two final British concerts, showcasing the duo's legendary
finesse. As follows:

06-25 London, England - Brixton Academy
06-27 Glastonbury, England - Glastonbury

www.pitchformedia.com

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) GOP Senator joins Democrats in calling for military draft

--Apple-Mail-2--475243398
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=ISO-8859-1;
	format=flowed

	A friend of mine recently described how he believes the military =
draft=20
will be introduced. Elaborating on his basic idea, I've come up with=20
the following scenario:

	For starters, they won't call it a "draft." Instead it will be =
called=20
"national service" or something like that. And just so people don't get=20=

alarmed, it won't involve the military at all, or if it does only=20
civilian jobs in veterans hospitals and things like that. The program=20
will be sold as a way to give young people pride in their communities=20
by doing things like cleaning up local streets, helping conduct the=20
census, or doing environmental protection work on government land --=20
you know, the stuff we supposedly pay taxes for. (This additional=20
low-pay grunt labor will allow politicians to take money they would=20
have spent on these services and give it back to the taxpayers? Ha ha,=20=

that's a good one. No, they'll spend it on other things that are more=20
popular with the special interests who write them checks.)

	The "national service" program probably won't be mandatory at =
first.=20
You'll only be required to participate if you *want* certain things,=20
like a government loan for college. Perhaps universities and school=20
districts will find that some of their government funding is made=20
conditional upon a certain percentage of their students signing up for=20=

the program -- this will give school personnel an incentive to get=20
students to sign up.

	Participation may also be used as an alternative to things you =
*don't*=20
want. Imagine being told, "Here are your options -- you can either pay=20=

all these traffic tickets now (sorry, cash or credit card only!), lose=20=

your driver's license permanently, or sign up for national service."=20
What would you do? Or, "You're probably facing several months behind=20
bars on this misdemeanor charge, but if you sign up for national=20
service you can avoid any jail time and they'll even remove the offense=20=

from your record."

	Once the initial program is in place and the public has relaxed =
about=20
it, it will slowly become mandatory for more and more people and the=20
requirements will become more and more onerous. That's exactly what=20
happened with Social Security. The Social Security Act was passed in=20
1935. In 1936, the federal government published an informational=20
pamphlet about it which stated:

=A0"And finally, beginning in 1949, 12 years from now, you and your=20
employer will each pay 3 cents on each dollar you earn, up to $3,000 a=20=

year. That is the most you will ever pay."

	Of course it was a lie. According to a site with a whole lot of=20=

revealing info about Social Security=20
(http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm), the maximum=20
inflation-adjusted SS tax per person in the year 2000 was more than 5=20
times that amount. For workers with average incomes, the government now=20=

collects the equivalent of 6 weeks worth of their salary in Social=20
Security taxes every year.

	When it got started, Social Security was also optional for most=20=

Americans. But over time, more and more people were forced into it. A=20
1999 Reason magazine article=20
(http://reason.com/9908/fe.rm.forced.shtml) describes how this happened:

"When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in 1935,=20=

the stated goal was to guarantee that industrial workers would have=20
secure pensions. With the Great Depression threatening the life of so=20
many enterprises, it seemed like a good idea to provide these workers=20
with an independent, guaranteed retirement plan. Public employees were=20=

specifically excluded because Congress recognized that they were=20
already safe from the swing of private sector fortunes.

"Then President Roosevelt made a promise that revealed his=20
administration's redistributionist aims. FDR allowed workers who=20
retired after 1936--no matter how little they paid in--to collect full=20=

benefits immediately. That meant that the system had to expand to cover=20=

the costs of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners,=20
farmers, doctors, and others who traditionally funded their own=20
retirements were gradually forced into the system. Today, more than 148=20=

million workers pay into a system that was just supposed to protect the=20=

working poor from poverty in old age.

"After most private sector workers were absorbed, the federal=20
government targeted other government workers--even though their=20
retirements were secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social Security=20
Act to let states and municipalities voluntarily cover their public=20
employees under Social Security. Some opted in, others stayed outside=20
the system. This voluntary agreement was revoked in 1983, when Congress=20=

made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set up=20
alternative retirement plans for their employees; only pension plans=20
pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new employees.

"At the same time, all new federal employees were forced into Social=20
Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would ensure=20
Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere 16=20
years later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In 1990, the=20=

Social Security Act was amended again to force any public employee not=20=

already enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton proposes to=20=

close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers=20
into the Social Security system."

	Anyway, getting back to the draft. As the "national service" =
program=20
grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more options --=20
including the option of serving regular military duty. Of course they=20
won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor adjustments=20
that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But=20
gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option by=20
making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing enlistment will=20=

get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually national=20
service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting government=20
money or having trouble with the law. Not to worry, it will be easy to=20=

get an exemption, at least at first. Having a regular job, having kids,=20=

being in school, writing a "hardship" letter, etc., will all get you=20
out of national service. As well as lots of more narrowly tailored=20
exemptions designed to win the support of various interest groups for=20
the program. But over time, these exemptions will start to be called=20
"loopholes," and Congress will go about "tightening" them. Just like=20
they do with taxes.

	Sometime around this point, most people will start to realize =
the=20
country has a full-on military draft. Of course if they'd been asked=20
whether they wanted a draft, they would've said "Hell no!" But it=20
happened so slowly. None of the changes were alarming. They all seemed=20=

to make sense at the time. And by now National Service is an=20
established program. All kinds of groups have strong financial and=20
emotional investments in it. Kind of late to blow the whistle, isn't it?

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

When I read this on their site last week I was emotionally disturbed to say the least. I've been listening to this band for about 10 years now and it's dishearthening, but I feel that they did run their course and I'm eager to hear the brothers go at it with their solo sound.

Thanks for posting this by the way...

Sascha
XTORT: http://www.xtortproductions.cjb.net

"anti.tim" <iamgod@dementim.com> wrote:
Orbital to Disband After Next LP

Joshua Sharp reports:
In 15 years, techno mainstays Phil and Paul Hartnoll have covered a lot
of ground. All Melvilles aside, hailing Orbital to be the most
successful crossover group of the electronic persuasion would not be an
inordinate boast. With six full-length releases under their belt, as
well as an incalculable number of singles, soundtrack offerings, remixes
and collaborations, the boys are finally ready to end it all.

"I think we feel that Orbital has run its course," said Paul Hartnoll
via the official Orbital site. "We're both pursuing different avenues
with our music. And we've been sat, as brothers, in the same room for 15
years now-- and studios are always confined spaces-- I think it's time
for a change."

Before closing the curtain on their decade-and-a-half discography, the
duo is set to release their final record, entitled The Blue Album
(Weezer mash-up comment withheld for the sake of humanity) on June 21st.
Says Paul of the swan song's sound: "It's closer in character to our
first album than our later ones, if only because we made it in our own
time and for ourselves." Confirmed titles so far include "You Lot",
"Acid Pants", "Bath Time", "Easy Serve", and "One Perfect Sunrise", the
latter featuring Dead Can Dance vocalist Lisa Gerrard. The album will be
followed by two final British concerts, showcasing the duo's legendary
finesse. As follows:

06-25 London, England - Brixton Academy
06-27 Glastonbury, England - Glastonbury

www.pitchformedia.com
