At 02:37 AM 4/27/2004, Starchild wrote:

>         A friend of mine recently described how he believes the military 
> draft will be introduced. Elaborating on his basic idea, I've come up 
> with the following scenario:
>
>         For starters, they won't call it a "draft." Instead it will be 
> called "national service" or something like that. And just so people 
> don't get alarmed, it won't involve the military at all, or if it does 
> only civilian jobs in veterans hospitals and things like that. The 
> program will be sold as a way to give young people pride in their 
> communities by doing things like cleaning up local streets, helping 
> conduct the census, or doing environmental protection work on government 
> land -- you know, the stuff we supposedly pay taxes for. (This additional 
> low-pay grunt labor will allow politicians to take money they would have 
> spent on these services and give it back to the taxpayers? Ha ha, that's 
> a good one. No, they'll spend it on other things that are more popular 
> with the special interests who write them checks.)
>
>         The "national service" program probably won't be mandatory at 
> first. You'll only be required to participate if you *want* certain 
> things, like a government loan for college. Perhaps universities and 
> school districts will find that some of their government funding is made 
> conditional upon a certain percentage of their students signing up for 
> the program -- this will give school personnel an incentive to get 
> students to sign up.
>
>         Participation may also be used as an alternative to things you 
> *don't* want. Imagine being told, "Here are your options -- you can 
> either pay all these traffic tickets now (sorry, cash or credit card 
> only!), lose your driver's license permanently, or sign up for national 
> service." What would you do? Or, "You're probably facing several months 
> behind bars on this misdemeanor charge, but if you sign up for national 
> service you can avoid any jail time and they'll even remove the offense 
> from your record."
>
>         Once the initial program is in place and the public has relaxed 
> about it, it will slowly become mandatory for more and more people and 
> the requirements will become more and more onerous. That's exactly what 
> happened with Social Security. The Social Security Act was passed in 
> 1935. In 1936, the federal government published an informational pamphlet 
> about it which stated:
>
>  "And finally, beginning in 1949, 12 years from now, you and your 
> employer will each pay 3 cents on each dollar you earn, up to $3,000 a 
> year. That is the most you will ever pay."
>
>         Of course it was a lie. According to a site with a whole lot of 
> revealing info about Social Security 
> (http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm), the maximum 
> inflation-adjusted SS tax per person in the year 2000 was more than 5 
> times that amount. For workers with average incomes, the government now 
> collects the equivalent of 6 weeks worth of their salary in Social 
> Security taxes every year.
>
>         When it got started, Social Security was also optional for most 
> Americans. But over time, more and more people were forced into it. A 
> 1999 Reason magazine article (http://reason.com/9908/fe.rm.forced.shtml) 
> describes how this happened:
>
>"When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in 1935, the 
>stated goal was to guarantee that industrial workers would have secure 
>pensions. With the Great Depression threatening the life of so many 
>enterprises, it seemed like a good idea to provide these workers with an 
>independent, guaranteed retirement plan. Public employees were 
>specifically excluded because Congress recognized that they were already 
>safe from the swing of private sector fortunes.
>
>"Then President Roosevelt made a promise that revealed his 
>administration's redistributionist aims. FDR allowed workers who retired 
>after 1936--no matter how little they paid in--to collect full benefits 
>immediately. That meant that the system had to expand to cover the costs 
>of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners, farmers, doctors, 
>and others who traditionally funded their own retirements were gradually 
>forced into the system. Today, more than 148 million workers pay into a 
>system that was just supposed to protect the working poor from poverty in 
>old age.
>
>"After most private sector workers were absorbed, the federal government 
>targeted other government workers--even though their retirements were 
>secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social Security Act to let states and 
>municipalities voluntarily cover their public employees under Social 
>Security. Some opted in, others stayed outside the system. This voluntary 
>agreement was revoked in 1983, when Congress made it illegal for states 
>and municipalities to continue to set up alternative retirement plans for 
>their employees; only pension plans pre-dating the 1983 amendments were 
>allowed to enroll new employees.
>
>"At the same time, all new federal employees were forced into Social 
>Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would ensure 
>Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere 16 years 
>later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In 1990, the Social 
>Security Act was amended again to force any public employee not already 
>enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton proposes to close this 
>last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers into the Social 
>Security system."
>
>         Anyway, getting back to the draft. As the "national service" 
> program grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more 
> options -- including the option of serving regular military duty. Of 
> course they won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor 
> adjustments that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. 
> But gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option by 
> making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing enlistment will 
> get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually national 
> service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting government 
> money or having trouble with the law. Not to worry, it will be easy to 
> get an exemption, at least at first. Having a regular job, having kids, 
> being in school, writing a "hardship" letter, etc., will all get you out 
> of national service. As well as lots of more narrowly tailored exemptions 
> designed to win the support of various interest groups for the program. 
> But over time, these exemptions will start to be called "loopholes," and 
> Congress will go about "tightening" them. Just like they do with taxes.
>
>         Sometime around this point, most people will start to realize the 
> country has a full-on military draft. Of course if they'd been asked 
> whether they wanted a draft, they would've said "Hell no!" But it 
> happened so slowly. None of the changes were alarming. They all seemed to 
> make sense at the time. And by now National Service is an established 
> program. All kinds of groups have strong financial and emotional 
> investments in it. Kind of late to blow the whistle, isn't it?
>
>Peace, love & liberty,
>                                         <<< Starchild >>>
>
>
>On Monday, April 26, 2004, at 08:35  PM, JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:

>>ravers didn't join the military is because we're scared. We're afraid of 
>>fighting and we're afraid of dying, while everyone who did join is very 
>>brave and strong... I thought the whole reason why we didn't join is 
>>because we don't agree with it morally. It's not so much that we're 
>>afraid of dying but we don't WANT to die or kill for the wrong reasons. 
>>In fact the MILLITARY should FEAR drafting US because for one we wouldn't 
>>know what the fuck we were doing in there, nor would we try very hard to 
>>learn & for two people like me would do everything in they're power to 
>>make sure no one at all got killed on either side. Besides what about 
>>crazy ass anarchy believing mother fuckers who get drafted and wreck 
>>havoc on the US from the inside that they never wished to be a part of? 
>>what about that? they could be drafting potential spys and terrorist for 
>>all they know. remember that story about the middle eastern guy who 
>>killed soldiers on his own side with a granade? I think they better stick 
>>to the soldiers who actually opted to join. no?
>>   - jaze
>>
>>In a message dated 4/20/04 4:50:51 PM, newstylesound@yahoo.com writes:
>>
>>Everybody aged 18-24 had better be eyeing prices for apartments in
>>Canada right now.  I had MAJOR major fears about the draft when I was a
>>kid..  Luckily I'm in my late 20s now so I've neatly missed it (unless
>>we *really* get f-ed up).  However pie-in-the-sky the possibility of
>>the draft seems at current, it couldn't hurt to look into the
>>particulars behind obtaining Conncientious Objector status or the
>>logistics of a temporary out-of-country move.

>=20
> "When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in 1935,

> made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set up

> pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new employees.
>=20

> Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would ensure
> Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere 16
> years later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In 1990, the
> Social Security Act was amended again to force any public employee not
> already enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton proposes to
> close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers
> into the Social Security system."

am

> that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But

From sfraves-return-112165-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Apr 27 17:29:03 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-112165-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 54450 invoked by uid 1103); 27 Apr 2004 17:29:01 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Received: (qmail 54102 invoked from network); 27 Apr 2004 17:28:57 -0000
Date: Tue, 27 Apr 2004 10:28:51 -0700
From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@atari.saturn5.com>
To: JBlaze112@aol.com
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20040427172851.GE16713@atari.saturn5.com>
References: <1ed.1f076b4a.2dbfe968@aol.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=unknown-8bit

In-Reply-To: <1ed.1f076b4a.2dbfe968@aol.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.3.28i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) GOP Senator joins Democrats in calling for military draft



It all smells of slave labor to me.  We are going to give the rich massive
tax cuts... Oh, and to pay for it, we are going to ask young people to work
for free.

Why not ask the wealthy of this nation to chip in their fair share, that
way we can actually *pay* young people to do this work, and maybe even
set them off on a real career in civil service.

Otherwise, if we can't afford to go to war, we shouldn't.

-troy

On Tue, Apr 27, 2004 at 12:50:48PM -0400, JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:
> Now that explination makes sense. It really shouldn't be about the fear of 
> it, people act like they're gonna drop you somewhere in the dessert from a plane 
> with a parashoot and put a gun in your hand. It's just a matter of weather or 
> not it's morrally right to force responsibility to citizens in a war that not 
> everyone agrees with.
> 
> In a message dated 4/27/04 2:37:05 AM, sfdreamer@earthlink.net writes:
> 
> 
> >     A friend of mine recently described how he believes the military draft
> > will be introduced. Elaborating on his basic idea, I've come up with
> > the following scenario:
> > 
> >     For starters, they won't call it a "draft." Instead it will be called
> > "national service" or something like that. And just so people don't get
> > alarmed, it won't involve the military at all, or if it does only
> > civilian jobs in veterans hospitals and things like that. The program
> > will be sold as a way to give young people pride in their communities
> > by doing things like cleaning up local streets, helping conduct the
> > census, or doing environmental protection work on government land --
> > you know, the stuff we supposedly pay taxes for. (This additional
> > low-pay grunt labor will allow politicians to take money they would
> > have spent on these services and give it back to the taxpayers? Ha ha,
> > that's a good one. No, they'll spend it on other things that are more
> > popular with the special interests who write them checks.)
> > 
> >     The "national service" program probably won't be mandatory at first.
> > You'll only be required to participate if you *want* certain things,
> > like a government loan for college. Perhaps universities and school
> > districts will find that some of their government funding is made
> > conditional upon a certain percentage of their students signing up for
> > the program -- this will give school personnel an incentive to get
> > students to sign up.
> > 
> >     Participation may also be used as an alternative to things you *don't*
> > want. Imagine being told, "Here are your options -- you can either pay
> > all these traffic tickets now (sorry, cash or credit card only!), lose
> > your driver's license permanently, or sign up for national service."
> > What would you do? Or, "You're probably facing several months behind
> > bars on this misdemeanor charge, but if you sign up for national
> > service you can avoid any jail time and they'll even remove the offense
> > from your record."
> > 
> >     Once the initial program is in place and the public has relaxed about
> > it, it will slowly become mandatory for more and more people and the
> > requirements will become more and more onerous. That's exactly what
> > happened with Social Security. The Social Security Act was passed in
> > 1935. In 1936, the federal government published an informational
> > pamphlet about it which stated:
> > 
> >  "And finally, beginning in 1949, 12 years from now, you and your
> > employer will each pay 3 cents on each dollar you earn, up to $3,000 a
> > year. That is the most you will ever pay."
> > 
> >     Of course it was a lie. According to a site with a whole lot of
> > revealing info about Social Security
> > (http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm), the maximum
> > inflation-adjusted SS tax per person in the year 2000 was more than 5
> > times that amount. For workers with average incomes, the government now
> > collects the equivalent of 6 weeks worth of their salary in Social
> > Security taxes every year.
> > 
> >     When it got started, Social Security was also optional for most
> > Americans. But over time, more and more people were forced into it. A
> > 1999 Reason magazine article
> > (http://reason.com/9908/fe.rm.forced.shtml) describes how this happened:
> > 
> > "When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in 1935,
> > the stated goal was to guarantee that industrial workers would have
> > secure pensions. With the Great Depression threatening the life of so
> > many enterprises, it seemed like a good idea to provide these workers
> > with an independent, guaranteed retirement plan. Public employees were
> > specifically excluded because Congress recognized that they were
> > already safe from the swing of private sector fortunes.
> > 
> > "Then President Roosevelt made a promise that revealed his
> > administration's redistributionist aims. FDR allowed workers who
> > retired after 1936--no matter how little they paid in--to collect full
> > benefits immediately. That meant that the system had to expand to cover
> > the costs of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners,
> > farmers, doctors, and others who traditionally funded their own
> > retirements were gradually forced into the system. Today, more than 148
> > million workers pay into a system that was just supposed to protect the
> > working poor from poverty in old age.
> > 
> > "After most private sector workers were absorbed, the federal
> > government targeted other government workers--even though their
> > retirements were secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social Security
> > Act to let states and municipalities voluntarily cover their public
> > employees under Social Security. Some opted in, others stayed outside
> > the system. This voluntary agreement was revoked in 1983, when Congress
> > made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set up
> > alternative retirement plans for their employees; only pension plans
> > pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new employees.
> > 
> > "At the same time, all new federal employees were forced into Social
> > Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would ensure
> > Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere 16
> > years later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In 1990, the
> > Social Security Act was amended again to force any public employee not
> > already enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton proposes to
> > close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers
> > into the Social Security system."
> > 
> >     Anyway, getting back to the draft. As the "national service" program
> > grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more options --
> > including the option of serving regular military duty. Of course they
> > won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor adjustments
> > that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But
> > gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option by
> > making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing enlistment will
> > get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually national
> > service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting government
> > money or having trouble with the law. Not to worry, it will be easy to
> > get an exemption, at least at first. Having a regular job, having kids,
> > being in school, writing a "hardship" letter, etc., will all get you
> > out of national service. As well as lots of more narrowly tailored
> > exemptions designed to win the support of various interest groups for
> > the program. But over time, these exemptions will start to be called
> > "loopholes," and Congress will go about "tightening" them. Just like
> > they do with taxes.
> > 
> >     Sometime around this point, most people will start to realize the
> > country has a full-on military draft. Of course if they'd been asked
> > whether they wanted a draft, they would've said "Hell no!" But it
> > happened so slowly. None of the changes were alarming. They all seemed
> > to make sense at the time. And by now National Service is an
> > established program. All kinds of groups have strong financial and
> > emotional investments in it. Kind of late to blow the whistle, isn't it?
> > 
> > Peace, love & liberty,
> >                     <<< Starchild >>>
> > 
> > 
> 

--

I think it's BS too. You're basicly on point with what you're saying.

But many other countries have the same thing. Hedo Turkuglo of the San 
Antonio Spurs has to go back to Turkey this Summer to complete his 6 month 
civil service (millitary) required of all young men by a certian age. And 
this guy is a millionaire in America that anyone can see on TV on a daily 
basis. He's still doing it.

To be honest, a 6 month type of thing doesn't seem all that bad. Anything 
longer is where people might start to have real problems with it. I know I 
would...

>cover
> > > the costs of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners,

> > > million workers pay into a system that was just supposed to protect 
>the
> > > working poor from poverty in old age.

> > > government targeted other government workers--even though their
> > > retirements were secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social Security
> > > Act to let states and municipalities voluntarily cover their public
> > > employees under Social Security. Some opted in, others stayed outside
> > > the system. This voluntary agreement was revoked in 1983, when 
>Congress
> > > made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set up
> > > alternative retirement plans for their employees; only pension plans
> > > pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new employees.
> > >

>to
> > > close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers

>program
> > > grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more options --
> > > including the option of serving regular military duty. Of course they
> > > won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor adjustments
> > > that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But
> > > gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option by
> > > making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing enlistment 
>will
> > > get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually national
> > > service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting government
> > > money or having trouble with the law. Not to worry, it will be easy to
> > > get an exemption, at least at first. Having a regular job, having 
>kids,
> > > being in school, writing a "hardship" letter, etc., will all get you

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) GOP Senator joins Democrats in calling for

here's the thing with the other countries that have mandatory service.
they have socialized medicine and many other social programs that this
country does not have in return for service.

i would never go to war in some other country.  if someone invaded the
U.S. then maybe, but to goto another country and fight is like me going on
to someone else's property and imposing my agenda.

it's always wrong.  i won't be fooled by fear and propaganda.

"war is stupid" --boy george

Jonas

>> > >     For starters, they won't call it a "draft." Instead it will be
>>called
>> > > "national service" or something like that. And just so people don't
>>get
>> > > alarmed, it won't involve the military at all, or if it does only
>> > > civilian jobs in veterans hospitals and things like that. The
>> program
>> > > will be sold as a way to give young people pride in their
>> communities
>> > > by doing things like cleaning up local streets, helping conduct the
>> > > census, or doing environmental protection work on government land --
>> > > you know, the stuff we supposedly pay taxes for. (This additional
>> > > low-pay grunt labor will allow politicians to take money they would
>> > > have spent on these services and give it back to the taxpayers? Ha
>> ha,
>> > > that's a good one. No, they'll spend it on other things that are
>> more
>> > > popular with the special interests who write them checks.)
>> > >
>> > >     The "national service" program probably won't be mandatory at
>>first.
>> > > You'll only be required to participate if you *want* certain things,
>> > > like a government loan for college. Perhaps universities and school
>> > > districts will find that some of their government funding is made
>> > > conditional upon a certain percentage of their students signing up
>> for
>> > > the program -- this will give school personnel an incentive to get
>> > > students to sign up.
>> > >
>> > >     Participation may also be used as an alternative to things you
>>*don't*
>> > > want. Imagine being told, "Here are your options -- you can either
>> pay
>> > > all these traffic tickets now (sorry, cash or credit card only!),
>> lose
>> > > your driver's license permanently, or sign up for national service."
>> > > What would you do? Or, "You're probably facing several months behind
>> > > bars on this misdemeanor charge, but if you sign up for national
>> > > service you can avoid any jail time and they'll even remove the
>>offense
>> > > from your record."
>> > >
>> > >     Once the initial program is in place and the public has relaxed
>>about
>> > > it, it will slowly become mandatory for more and more people and the
>> > > requirements will become more and more onerous. That's exactly what
>> > > happened with Social Security. The Social Security Act was passed in
>> > > 1935. In 1936, the federal government published an informational
>> > > pamphlet about it which stated:
>> > >
>> > >  "And finally, beginning in 1949, 12 years from now, you and your
>> > > employer will each pay 3 cents on each dollar you earn, up to $3,000
>> a
>> > > year. That is the most you will ever pay."
>> > >
>> > >     Of course it was a lie. According to a site with a whole lot of
>> > > revealing info about Social Security
>> > > (http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm), the maximum
>> > > inflation-adjusted SS tax per person in the year 2000 was more than
>> 5
>> > > times that amount. For workers with average incomes, the government
>>now
>> > > collects the equivalent of 6 weeks worth of their salary in Social
>> > > Security taxes every year.
>> > >
>> > >     When it got started, Social Security was also optional for most
>> > > Americans. But over time, more and more people were forced into it.
>> A
>> > > 1999 Reason magazine article
>> > > (http://reason.com/9908/fe.rm.forced.shtml) describes how this
>>happened:
>> > >
>> > > "When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in
>> 1935,
>> > > the stated goal was to guarantee that industrial workers would have
>> > > secure pensions. With the Great Depression threatening the life of
>> so
>> > > many enterprises, it seemed like a good idea to provide these
>> workers
>> > > with an independent, guaranteed retirement plan. Public employees
>> were
>> > > specifically excluded because Congress recognized that they were
>> > > already safe from the swing of private sector fortunes.
>> > >
>> > > "Then President Roosevelt made a promise that revealed his
>> > > administration's redistributionist aims. FDR allowed workers who
>> > > retired after 1936--no matter how little they paid in--to collect
>> full
>> > > benefits immediately. That meant that the system had to expand to
>>cover
>> > > the costs of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners,
>> > > farmers, doctors, and others who traditionally funded their own
>> > > retirements were gradually forced into the system. Today, more than
>>148
>> > > million workers pay into a system that was just supposed to protect
>>the
>> > > working poor from poverty in old age.
>> > >
>> > > "After most private sector workers were absorbed, the federal
>> > > government targeted other government workers--even though their
>> > > retirements were secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social
>> Security
>> > > Act to let states and municipalities voluntarily cover their public
>> > > employees under Social Security. Some opted in, others stayed
>> outside
>> > > the system. This voluntary agreement was revoked in 1983, when
>>Congress
>> > > made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set up
>> > > alternative retirement plans for their employees; only pension plans
>> > > pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new employees.
>> > >
>> > > "At the same time, all new federal employees were forced into Social
>> > > Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would ensure
>> > > Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere 16
>> > > years later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In 1990,
>> the
>> > > Social Security Act was amended again to force any public employee
>> not
>> > > already enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton proposes
>>to
>> > > close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers
>> > > into the Social Security system."
>> > >
>> > >     Anyway, getting back to the draft. As the "national service"
>>program
>> > > grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more options
>> --
>> > > including the option of serving regular military duty. Of course
>> they
>> > > won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor adjustments
>> > > that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But
>> > > gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option by
>> > > making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing enlistment
>>will
>> > > get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually national
>> > > service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting
>> government
>> > > money or having trouble with the law. Not to worry, it will be easy
>> to
>> > > get an exemption, at least at first. Having a regular job, having
>>kids,
>> > > being in school, writing a "hardship" letter, etc., will all get you
>> > > out of national service. As well as lots of more narrowly tailored
>> > > exemptions designed to win the support of various interest groups
>> for
>> > > the program. But over time, these exemptions will start to be called
>> > > "loopholes," and Congress will go about "tightening" them. Just like
>> > > they do with taxes.
>> > >
>> > >     Sometime around this point, most people will start to realize
>> the
>> > > country has a full-on military draft. Of course if they'd been asked
>> > > whether they wanted a draft, they would've said "Hell no!" But it
>> > > happened so slowly. None of the changes were alarming. They all
>> seemed
>> > > to make sense at the time. And by now National Service is an
>> > > established program. All kinds of groups have strong financial and
>> > > emotional investments in it. Kind of late to blow the whistle, isn't
>>it?
>> > >
>> > > Peace, love & liberty,
>> > >                     <<< Starchild >>>
>> > >
>> > >
>> >
>>
>>--

>> > > it, it will slowly become mandatory for more and more people and =
the
>> > > requirements will become more and more onerous. That's exactly =
what
>> > > happened with Social Security. The Social Security Act was passed =
in
>> > > 1935. In 1936, the federal government published an informational
>> > > pamphlet about it which stated:
>> > >
>> > > =A0"And finally, beginning in 1949, 12 years from now, you and =
your
>> > > employer will each pay 3 cents on each dollar you earn, up to =
$3,000
>> a
>> > > year. That is the most you will ever pay."
>> > >
>> > > =A0 =A0 Of course it was a lie. According to a site with a whole =
lot of
>> > > revealing info about Social Security
>> > > (http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm), the maximum
>> > > inflation-adjusted SS tax per person in the year 2000 was more =
than
>> 5
>> > > times that amount. For workers with average incomes, the =
government
>>now
>> > > collects the equivalent of 6 weeks worth of their salary in =
Social
>> > > Security taxes every year.
>> > >
>> > > =A0 =A0 When it got started, Social Security was also optional =
for most
>> > > Americans. But over time, more and more people were forced into =
it.
>> A
>> > > 1999 Reason magazine article
>> > > (http://reason.com/9908/fe.rm.forced.shtml) describes how this
>>happened:
>> > >
>> > > "When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in
>> 1935,
>> > > the stated goal was to guarantee that industrial workers would =
have
>> > > secure pensions. With the Great Depression threatening the life =
of
>> so
>> > > many enterprises, it seemed like a good idea to provide these
>> workers
>> > > with an independent, guaranteed retirement plan. Public employees
>> were
>> > > specifically excluded because Congress recognized that they were
>> > > already safe from the swing of private sector fortunes.
>> > >
>> > > "Then President Roosevelt made a promise that revealed his
>> > > administration's redistributionist aims. FDR allowed workers who
>> > > retired after 1936--no matter how little they paid in--to collect
>> full
>> > > benefits immediately. That meant that the system had to expand to
>>cover
>> > > the costs of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners,
>> > > farmers, doctors, and others who traditionally funded their own
>> > > retirements were gradually forced into the system. Today, more =
than
>>148
>> > > million workers pay into a system that was just supposed to =
protect
>>the
>> > > working poor from poverty in old age.
>> > >
>> > > "After most private sector workers were absorbed, the federal
>> > > government targeted other government workers--even though their
>> > > retirements were secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social
>> Security
>> > > Act to let states and municipalities voluntarily cover their =
public
>> > > employees under Social Security. Some opted in, others stayed
>> outside
>> > > the system. This voluntary agreement was revoked in 1983, when
>>Congress
>> > > made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set =
up
>> > > alternative retirement plans for their employees; only pension =
plans
>> > > pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new =
employees.
>> > >
>> > > "At the same time, all new federal employees were forced into =
Social
>> > > Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would =
ensure
>> > > Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere =
16
>> > > years later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In =
1990,
>> the
>> > > Social Security Act was amended again to force any public =
employee
>> not
>> > > already enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton =
proposes
>>to
>> > > close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt =
workers
>> > > into the Social Security system."
>> > >
>> > > =A0 =A0 Anyway, getting back to the draft. As the "national =
service"
>>program
>> > > grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more =
options
>> --
>> > > including the option of serving regular military duty. Of course
>> they
>> > > won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor =
adjustments
>> > > that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But
>> > > gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option =
by
>> > > making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing =
enlistment
>>will
>> > > get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually =
national
>> > > service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting
>> government
>> > > money or having trouble with the law. Not to worry, it will be =
easy
>> to
>> > > get an exemption, at least at first. Having a regular job, having
>>kids,
>> > > being in school, writing a "hardship" letter, etc., will all get =
you
>> > > out of national service. As well as lots of more narrowly =
tailored
>> > > exemptions designed to win the support of various interest groups
>> for
>> > > the program. But over time, these exemptions will start to be =
called
>> > > "loopholes," and Congress will go about "tightening" them. Just =
like
>> > > they do with taxes.
>> > >
>> > > =A0 =A0 Sometime around this point, most people will start to =
realize
>> the
>> > > country has a full-on military draft. Of course if they'd been =
asked
>> > > whether they wanted a draft, they would've said "Hell no!" But it
>> > > happened so slowly. None of the changes were alarming. They all
>> seemed
>> > > to make sense at the time. And by now National Service is an
>> > > established program. All kinds of groups have strong financial =
and
>> > > emotional investments in it. Kind of late to blow the whistle, =
isn't
>>it?
>> > >

> > >

> > > 1935. In 1936, the federal government published an informational
> > > pamphlet about it which stated:

> > > employer will each pay 3 cents on each dollar you earn, up to $3,000 =
a

> > >

of
> > > revealing info about Social Security

> > > inflation-adjusted SS tax per person in the year 2000 was more than 5
> > > times that amount. For workers with average incomes, the government n=
ow
> > > collects the equivalent of 6 weeks worth of their salary in Social
> > > Security taxes every year.
> > >
> > > =A0 =A0 When it got started, Social Security was also optional for mo=
st
> > > Americans. But over time, more and more people were forced into it. A
> > > 1999 Reason magazine article
> > > (http://reason.com/9908/fe.rm.forced.shtml) describes how this happen=

> > >
> > > "When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in 1935=
,
> > > the stated goal was to guarantee that industrial workers would have
> > > secure pensions. With the Great Depression threatening the life of so
> > > many enterprises, it seemed like a good idea to provide these workers
> > > with an independent, guaranteed retirement plan. Public employees wer=
e
> > > specifically excluded because Congress recognized that they were
> > > already safe from the swing of private sector fortunes.
> > >
> > > "Then President Roosevelt made a promise that revealed his
> > > administration's redistributionist aims. FDR allowed workers who
> > > retired after 1936--no matter how little they paid in--to collect ful=
l
> > > benefits immediately. That meant that the system had to expand to cov=
er
> > > the costs of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners,
> > > farmers, doctors, and others who traditionally funded their own
> > > retirements were gradually forced into the system. Today, more than 1=
48
> > > million workers pay into a system that was just supposed to protect t=
he
> > > working poor from poverty in old age.
> > >

> > > government targeted other government workers--even though their
> > > retirements were secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social Security
> > > Act to let states and municipalities voluntarily cover their public
> > > employees under Social Security. Some opted in, others stayed outside
> > > the system. This voluntary agreement was revoked in 1983, when Congre=
ss
> > > made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set up
> > > alternative retirement plans for their employees; only pension plans
> > > pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new employees.
> > >
> > > "At the same time, all new federal employees were forced into Social
> > > Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would ensure
> > > Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere 16
> > > years later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In 1990, th=
e
> > > Social Security Act was amended again to force any public employee no=
t
> > > already enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton proposes =
to
> > > close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers
> > > into the Social Security system."
> > >

program
> > > grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more options --
> > > including the option of serving regular military duty. Of course they
> > > won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor adjustments
> > > that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But
> > > gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option by
> > > making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing enlistment wi=
ll
> > > get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually national
> > > service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting government

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) GOP Senator joins Democrats in calling for military draft

> Um, does someone want to chime in here and inform Troy that the wealthy DO 
> pay their fair share, in fact they pay way more in taxes then the poor. Ryan?

"fair share" is all relative.  Personally, I would rather see fewer people
suffering in the world, instead of being able to afford that new Porche or
Hummer.... or a 3rd vacation home in Aspen.

But, that is all for the voters to decide.  If the struggling families
of America want to keep voting (not not voting) to give people like me 
even more disposable income, well, I guess thats just the way Democracy
works.  Its pretty funny how they get suckered.  I guess they deserve it.

-troy

> Steve Osteen
> Progressive DJ/Producer
> www.tussinspace.com

> On Tue, Apr 27, 2004 at 12:50:48PM -0400, JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:
> > Now that explination makes sense. It really shouldn't be about the fear of 
> > it, people act like they're gonna drop you somewhere in the dessert from a plane 
> > with a parashoot and put a gun in your hand. It's just a matter of weather or 
> > not it's morrally right to force responsibility to citizens in a war that not 
> > everyone agrees with.
> > 
> > In a message dated 4/27/04 2:37:05 AM, sfdreamer@earthlink.net writes:
> > 
> > 
> > >     A friend of mine recently described how he believes the military draft
> > > will be introduced. Elaborating on his basic idea, I've come up with
> > > the following scenario:
> > > 
> > >     For starters, they won't call it a "draft." Instead it will be called
> > > "national service" or something like that. And just so people don't get
> > > alarmed, it won't involve the military at all, or if it does only
> > > civilian jobs in veterans hospitals and things like that. The program
> > > will be sold as a way to give young people pride in their communities
> > > by doing things like cleaning up local streets, helping conduct the
> > > census, or doing environmental protection work on government land --
> > > you know, the stuff we supposedly pay taxes for. (This additional
> > > low-pay grunt labor will allow politicians to take money they would
> > > have spent on these services and give it back to the taxpayers? Ha ha,
> > > that's a good one. No, they'll spend it on other things that are more
> > > popular with the special interests who write them checks.)
> > > 
> > >     The "national service" program probably won't be mandatory at first.
> > > You'll only be required to participate if you *want* certain things,
> > > like a government loan for college. Perhaps universities and school
> > > districts will find that some of their government funding is made
> > > conditional upon a certain percentage of their students signing up for
> > > the program -- this will give school personnel an incentive to get
> > > students to sign up.
> > > 
> > >     Participation may also be used as an alternative to things you *don't*
> > > want. Imagine being told, "Here are your options -- you can either pay
> > > all these traffic tickets now (sorry, cash or credit card only!), lose
> > > your driver's license permanently, or sign up for national service."
> > > What would you do? Or, "You're probably facing several months behind
> > > bars on this misdemeanor charge, but if you sign up for national
> > > service you can avoid any jail time and they'll even remove the offense
> > > from your record."
> > > 
> > >     Once the initial program is in place and the public has relaxed about
> > > it, it will slowly become mandatory for more and more people and the
> > > requirements will become more and more onerous. That's exactly what
> > > happened with Social Security. The Social Security Act was passed in
> > > 1935. In 1936, the federal government published an informational
> > > pamphlet about it which stated:
> > > 
> > >  "And finally, beginning in 1949, 12 years from now, you and your
> > > employer will each pay 3 cents on each dollar you earn, up to $3,000 a
> > > year. That is the most you will ever pay."
> > > 
> > >     Of course it was a lie. According to a site with a whole lot of
> > > revealing info about Social Security
> > > (http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm), the maximum
> > > inflation-adjusted SS tax per person in the year 2000 was more than 5
> > > times that amount. For workers with average incomes, the government now
> > > collects the equivalent of 6 weeks worth of their salary in Social
> > > Security taxes every year.
> > > 
> > >     When it got started, Social Security was also optional for most
> > > Americans. But over time, more and more people were forced into it. A
> > > 1999 Reason magazine article
> > > (http://reason.com/9908/fe.rm.forced.shtml) describes how this happened:
> > > 
> > > "When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in 1935,
> > > the stated goal was to guarantee that industrial workers would have
> > > secure pensions. With the Great Depression threatening the life of so
> > > many enterprises, it seemed like a good idea to provide these workers
> > > with an independent, guaranteed retirement plan. Public employees were
> > > specifically excluded because Congress recognized that they were
> > > already safe from the swing of private sector fortunes.
> > > 
> > > "Then President Roosevelt made a promise that revealed his
> > > administration's redistributionist aims. FDR allowed workers who
> > > retired after 1936--no matter how little they paid in--to collect full
> > > benefits immediately. That meant that the system had to expand to cover
> > > the costs of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners,
> > > farmers, doctors, and others who traditionally funded their own
> > > retirements were gradually forced into the system. Today, more than 148
> > > million workers pay into a system that was just supposed to protect the
> > > working poor from poverty in old age.
> > > 
> > > "After most private sector workers were absorbed, the federal
> > > government targeted other government workers--even though their
> > > retirements were secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social Security
> > > Act to let states and municipalities voluntarily cover their public
> > > employees under Social Security. Some opted in, others stayed outside
> > > the system. This voluntary agreement was revoked in 1983, when Congress
> > > made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set up
> > > alternative retirement plans for their employees; only pension plans
> > > pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new employees.
> > > 
> > > "At the same time, all new federal employees were forced into Social
> > > Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would ensure
> > > Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere 16
> > > years later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In 1990, the
> > > Social Security Act was amended again to force any public employee not
> > > already enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton proposes to
> > > close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers
> > > into the Social Security system."
> > > 
> > >     Anyway, getting back to the draft. As the "national service" program
> > > grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more options --
> > > including the option of serving regular military duty. Of course they
> > > won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor adjustments
> > > that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But
> > > gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option by
> > > making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing enlistment will
> > > get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually national
> > > service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting government
> > > money or having trouble with the law. Not to worry, it will be easy to
> > > get an exemption, at least at first. Having a regular job, having kids,
> > > being in school, writing a "hardship" letter, etc., will all get you
> > > out of national service. As well as lots of more narrowly tailored
> > > exemptions designed to win the support of various interest groups for
> > > the program. But over time, these exemptions will start to be called
> > > "loopholes," and Congress will go about "tightening" them. Just like
> > > they do with taxes.
> > > 
> > >     Sometime around this point, most people will start to realize the
> > > country has a full-on military draft. Of course if they'd been asked
> > > whether they wanted a draft, they would've said "Hell no!" But it
> > > happened so slowly. None of the changes were alarming. They all seemed
> > > to make sense at the time. And by now National Service is an
> > > established program. All kinds of groups have strong financial and
> > > emotional investments in it. Kind of late to blow the whistle, isn't it?
> > > 
> > > Peace, love & liberty,
> > >                     <<< Starchild >>>
> > > 
> > > 
> > 
> 
> -- 
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> tsheets@saturn5.com                                  <- You have found me   
> http://www.saturn5.com/tsheets/audio                 <- my .mp3 tracks
> "I just don't have the discipline to be a hippie"    <- Homer J. Simpson

Subject: [sfraves] || MAY DAY! || *THIS SATURDAY MAY 1ST** 8pm-4am / ALL AGES / LUNA-C!  bsp

Liquidvinyldjs.com is very proud to present..


• MAY DAY! •
Saturday, May 1st 2004
8:00pm - 4:00am
500 Person Capacity
1 ROOM VIRGIN LOCATION - Centrally located in the East Bay!
ALL RESPONSIBLE AGES WELCOME!


With MAY DAY!, we would like to celebrate the beginnings of Summer with a 
very intimate 1 room experience! Join us as we kick the summer of just right 
in a brand new location, close to everyone here in the Bay Area!


DJ's for the night:


|| DJ LUNA-C
[Kniteforce North American Tour || KFA/Kniteforce, UK] - SPECIAL BIRTHDAY 
SET!!
We are very proud to bring DJ LUNA-C to the Bay for his special Birthday 
Set. This will be the last stop on his very exclusive Kniteforce North 
American Tour, and this night just happens to be on his birthday! He's 
coming prepared to showcase a very special set exclusive to us here in San 
Francisco, which is sure to absolutely blow you away. If you've seen LUNA-C 
at any of our past events, you know he will completely take the roof off the 
place and have you moving, from the first record to the last! Please allow 
us to wish our good friend a very Happy Birthday here in the Bay!

|| CLOUDSKIPPER vs. THE NICE GUYS
[Raw Elements/Kniteforce/Liquidvinyldjs.com vs. Liquidvinyldjs.com/K-12] - 
3X6 INSANITY SET!
In what is sure to be one of the more talked about sets this year, 
Cloudskipper faces off against The Nice Guys. Relatively little is known 
about The Nice Guys, except, well, they're nice. In any case, be prepared 
for in your face up front hardcore, a lot of unreleased music, as well as 
onstage antics that can only be described as pure madness!

|| DJ TRONIC
[Resistance Recordings/Liquidvinyldjs.com/CHR]
In preparation for his anticipated European tour, Tronic's set is going to 
be chalked full of brand new hard hittin material! This will be his last 
local appearance before he heads off to Europe for 2 weeks, so be ready for 
the Hard Beats!

|| MAJERE
[Elektrosorcery, DJMajere.com] - SPECIAL TRANCECORE/FREEFORM SET!
In a rare appearance playing trancecore/freeform, Majere is taking a bit of 
a step back into his roots. Expect a set of fast and hard mind melting 
music, which can only be appreciated by those ready to move!

|| THE DOCTOR & MC FADER
[Liquidvinyldjs.com/Bayraves.com || Gravitycrew.com/Emceeds]
Quite possibly one of the best DnB/Jungle DJ's in Northern California, The 
Doctor has become a household name. You can catch him almost every weekend 
droppin those hard hittin tracks all over! In tow is the MC called Fader, in 
which really needs no introduction. These two go together like steak and 
eggs, like butter on toast, like.. well you get the idea!

|| DJ J-MARR
[Liquidvinyldjs.com/Bayraves.com] - FAREWELL SET!
The man, the myth, the legend. Need we say more? Known from up and down the 
West Coast for not only his music, but also his energetic charisma, J-Marr 
is a legend in the scene. This will be his last set behind the decks, ending 
a tenure other DJ's can only dream about. Be there to witness J-Marr rocking 
in his usual manner, for the last time!

|| CARLOS ALFONZO vs. RECLIPSE
[Resistance Recordings/Soop Recordings vs. D&A Music/Bayraves]
The battle of the BBQ Iron Chef Carlos and the Maddest Mad DJ around, this 
will be a treat to all those who appreciated hard techno... and we do mean 
HARD. These two will come out swingin' with pure dancefloor driven 
material.. get ready to rock!

|| LEON COOK vs. PETER GO-ZANIA!
[Hardscience/Logik Pro Audio]
These two have been rapidly rising among the Hardcore faithful here in the 
Bay, and with their crowd rockin performances and talent behind the decks, 
it's really no wonder why. Expect a set full of freeform and upfront 
Hardcore material only these guys bring to the table.

|| DJ DMS
[Oakland Bounce/Dream Crew]


>From the same people who brought you HAPPY TOGETHER 1 & 2, OVERLOAD 1, 2, & 
3, SUMMER ROCKIN, and GET UP!. MAY DAY will be an extremely special night to 
us, where we are celebrating the coming of summer, as well as our good 
friend LUNA-C's birthday. If you've loved the vibe and sharing of the music 
we've had at past events, this will be no different!!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes

quoth Steve Osteen:
> Um, does someone want to chime in here and inform Troy that the
> wealthy DO pay their fair share, in fact they pay way more in taxes
> then the poor. Ryan?

It's anyone's guess what a "fair share" would constitute. I tend to
think that as long as there are children starving, millions without
health care, and an entire class of working poor in this country that
NOBODY is paying their fair share.

People want affordable health care and safer streets, decent radio
stations and support for the arts, but they're unwilling to pay the
price. Public services cost money, and as long as we remain greedy and
selfish, nobody will benefit from even the slightest distribution of
wealth in the world's richest nation.

concept, but horrible in practice, here's why:

capitalism:

freedom

rewards innovation
Man WAS NOT created equal, but shall be given equal oppurtunity
survival of the fitest
Man is inherrently selfish and greedy, why deny it.
No hope for the weak or disabled
realist perspective

Communism/Marxism(socialism):

conformity
one for the good of the community
weakest link is a broken leg for the whole community
desirable for countries ruined by war that need hope
why strive to be the best if there is no reward
Loss of individualism and self expression
Idealist perspective

the first page and start of the second page.

> On Tue, Apr 27, 2004 at 12:50:48PM -0400, JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:
> 
>>Now that explination makes sense. It really shouldn't be about the fear of 
>>it, people act like they're gonna drop you somewhere in the dessert from a plane 
>>with a parashoot and put a gun in your hand. It's just a matter of weather or 
>>not it's morrally right to force responsibility to citizens in a war that not 
>>everyone agrees with.
>>
>>In a message dated 4/27/04 2:37:05 AM, sfdreamer@earthlink.net writes:
>>
>>
>>
>>>    A friend of mine recently described how he believes the military draft
>>>will be introduced. Elaborating on his basic idea, I've come up with
>>>the following scenario:
>>>
>>>    For starters, they won't call it a "draft." Instead it will be called
>>>"national service" or something like that. And just so people don't get
>>>alarmed, it won't involve the military at all, or if it does only
>>>civilian jobs in veterans hospitals and things like that. The program
>>>will be sold as a way to give young people pride in their communities
>>>by doing things like cleaning up local streets, helping conduct the
>>>census, or doing environmental protection work on government land --
>>>you know, the stuff we supposedly pay taxes for. (This additional
>>>low-pay grunt labor will allow politicians to take money they would
>>>have spent on these services and give it back to the taxpayers? Ha ha,
>>>that's a good one. No, they'll spend it on other things that are more
>>>popular with the special interests who write them checks.)
>>>
>>>    The "national service" program probably won't be mandatory at first.
>>>You'll only be required to participate if you *want* certain things,
>>>like a government loan for college. Perhaps universities and school
>>>districts will find that some of their government funding is made
>>>conditional upon a certain percentage of their students signing up for
>>>the program -- this will give school personnel an incentive to get
>>>students to sign up.
>>>
>>>    Participation may also be used as an alternative to things you *don't*
>>>want. Imagine being told, "Here are your options -- you can either pay
>>>all these traffic tickets now (sorry, cash or credit card only!), lose
>>>your driver's license permanently, or sign up for national service."
>>>What would you do? Or, "You're probably facing several months behind
>>>bars on this misdemeanor charge, but if you sign up for national
>>>service you can avoid any jail time and they'll even remove the offense
>>>from your record."
>>>
>>>    Once the initial program is in place and the public has relaxed about
>>>it, it will slowly become mandatory for more and more people and the
>>>requirements will become more and more onerous. That's exactly what
>>>happened with Social Security. The Social Security Act was passed in
>>>1935. In 1936, the federal government published an informational
>>>pamphlet about it which stated:
>>>
>>> "And finally, beginning in 1949, 12 years from now, you and your
>>>employer will each pay 3 cents on each dollar you earn, up to $3,000 a
>>>year. That is the most you will ever pay."
>>>
>>>    Of course it was a lie. According to a site with a whole lot of
>>>revealing info about Social Security
>>>(http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm), the maximum
>>>inflation-adjusted SS tax per person in the year 2000 was more than 5
>>>times that amount. For workers with average incomes, the government now
>>>collects the equivalent of 6 weeks worth of their salary in Social
>>>Security taxes every year.
>>>
>>>    When it got started, Social Security was also optional for most
>>>Americans. But over time, more and more people were forced into it. A
>>>1999 Reason magazine article
>>>(http://reason.com/9908/fe.rm.forced.shtml) describes how this happened:
>>>
>>>"When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in 1935,
>>>the stated goal was to guarantee that industrial workers would have
>>>secure pensions. With the Great Depression threatening the life of so
>>>many enterprises, it seemed like a good idea to provide these workers
>>>with an independent, guaranteed retirement plan. Public employees were
>>>specifically excluded because Congress recognized that they were
>>>already safe from the swing of private sector fortunes.
>>>
>>>"Then President Roosevelt made a promise that revealed his
>>>administration's redistributionist aims. FDR allowed workers who
>>>retired after 1936--no matter how little they paid in--to collect full
>>>benefits immediately. That meant that the system had to expand to cover
>>>the costs of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners,
>>>farmers, doctors, and others who traditionally funded their own
>>>retirements were gradually forced into the system. Today, more than 148
>>>million workers pay into a system that was just supposed to protect the
>>>working poor from poverty in old age.
>>>
>>>"After most private sector workers were absorbed, the federal
>>>government targeted other government workers--even though their
>>>retirements were secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social Security
>>>Act to let states and municipalities voluntarily cover their public
>>>employees under Social Security. Some opted in, others stayed outside
>>>the system. This voluntary agreement was revoked in 1983, when Congress
>>>made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set up
>>>alternative retirement plans for their employees; only pension plans
>>>pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new employees.
>>>
>>>"At the same time, all new federal employees were forced into Social
>>>Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would ensure
>>>Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere 16
>>>years later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In 1990, the
>>>Social Security Act was amended again to force any public employee not
>>>already enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton proposes to
>>>close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers
>>>into the Social Security system."
>>>
>>>    Anyway, getting back to the draft. As the "national service" program
>>>grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more options --
>>>including the option of serving regular military duty. Of course they
>>>won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor adjustments
>>>that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But
>>>gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option by
>>>making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing enlistment will
>>>get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually national
>>>service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting government
>>>money or having trouble with the law. Not to worry, it will be easy to
>>>get an exemption, at least at first. Having a regular job, having kids,
>>>being in school, writing a "hardship" letter, etc., will all get you
>>>out of national service. As well as lots of more narrowly tailored
>>>exemptions designed to win the support of various interest groups for
>>>the program. But over time, these exemptions will start to be called
>>>"loopholes," and Congress will go about "tightening" them. Just like
>>>they do with taxes.
>>>
>>>    Sometime around this point, most people will start to realize the
>>>country has a full-on military draft. Of course if they'd been asked
>>>whether they wanted a draft, they would've said "Hell no!" But it
>>>happened so slowly. None of the changes were alarming. They all seemed
>>>to make sense at the time. And by now National Service is an
>>>established program. All kinds of groups have strong financial and
>>>emotional investments in it. Kind of late to blow the whistle, isn't it?
>>>
>>>Peace, love & liberty,
>>>                    <<< Starchild >>>
>>>
>>>
> 

---------------------------------------------------------------------

>>On Tue, Apr 27, 2004 at 12:50:48PM -0400, JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:
>>
>>>Now that explination makes sense. It really shouldn't be about the fear 
>>>of it, people act like they're gonna drop you somewhere in the dessert 
>>>from a plane with a parashoot and put a gun in your hand. It's just a 
>>>matter of weather or not it's morrally right to force responsibility to 
>>>citizens in a war that not everyone agrees with.

>>>In a message dated 4/27/04 2:37:05 AM, sfdreamer@earthlink.net writes:
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>>    A friend of mine recently described how he believes the military draft
>>>>will be introduced. Elaborating on his basic idea, I've come up with
>>>>the following scenario:
>>>>
>>>>    For starters, they won't call it a "draft." Instead it will be called
>>>>"national service" or something like that. And just so people don't get
>>>>alarmed, it won't involve the military at all, or if it does only
>>>>civilian jobs in veterans hospitals and things like that. The program
>>>>will be sold as a way to give young people pride in their communities
>>>>by doing things like cleaning up local streets, helping conduct the
>>>>census, or doing environmental protection work on government land --
>>>>you know, the stuff we supposedly pay taxes for. (This additional
>>>>low-pay grunt labor will allow politicians to take money they would
>>>>have spent on these services and give it back to the taxpayers? Ha ha,
>>>>that's a good one. No, they'll spend it on other things that are more
>>>>popular with the special interests who write them checks.)
>>>>
>>>>    The "national service" program probably won't be mandatory at first.
>>>>You'll only be required to participate if you *want* certain things,
>>>>like a government loan for college. Perhaps universities and school
>>>>districts will find that some of their government funding is made
>>>>conditional upon a certain percentage of their students signing up for
>>>>the program -- this will give school personnel an incentive to get
>>>>students to sign up.
>>>>
>>>>    Participation may also be used as an alternative to things you *don't*
>>>>want. Imagine being told, "Here are your options -- you can either pay
>>>>all these traffic tickets now (sorry, cash or credit card only!), lose
>>>>your driver's license permanently, or sign up for national service."
>>>>What would you do? Or, "You're probably facing several months behind
>>>>bars on this misdemeanor charge, but if you sign up for national
>>>>service you can avoid any jail time and they'll even remove the offense
>>>>from your record."
>>>>
>>>>    Once the initial program is in place and the public has relaxed about
>>>>it, it will slowly become mandatory for more and more people and the
>>>>requirements will become more and more onerous. That's exactly what
>>>>happened with Social Security. The Social Security Act was passed in
>>>>1935. In 1936, the federal government published an informational
>>>>pamphlet about it which stated:
>>>>
>>>>"And finally, beginning in 1949, 12 years from now, you and your
>>>>employer will each pay 3 cents on each dollar you earn, up to $3,000 a
>>>>year. That is the most you will ever pay."
>>>>
>>>>    Of course it was a lie. According to a site with a whole lot of
>>>>revealing info about Social Security
>>>>(http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm), the maximum
>>>>inflation-adjusted SS tax per person in the year 2000 was more than 5
>>>>times that amount. For workers with average incomes, the government now
>>>>collects the equivalent of 6 weeks worth of their salary in Social
>>>>Security taxes every year.
>>>>
>>>>    When it got started, Social Security was also optional for most
>>>>Americans. But over time, more and more people were forced into it. A
>>>>1999 Reason magazine article
>>>>(http://reason.com/9908/fe.rm.forced.shtml) describes how this happened:
>>>>
>>>>"When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in 1935,
>>>>the stated goal was to guarantee that industrial workers would have
>>>>secure pensions. With the Great Depression threatening the life of so
>>>>many enterprises, it seemed like a good idea to provide these workers
>>>>with an independent, guaranteed retirement plan. Public employees were
>>>>specifically excluded because Congress recognized that they were
>>>>already safe from the swing of private sector fortunes.
>>>>
>>>>"Then President Roosevelt made a promise that revealed his
>>>>administration's redistributionist aims. FDR allowed workers who
>>>>retired after 1936--no matter how little they paid in--to collect full
>>>>benefits immediately. That meant that the system had to expand to cover
>>>>the costs of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners,
>>>>farmers, doctors, and others who traditionally funded their own
>>>>retirements were gradually forced into the system. Today, more than 148
>>>>million workers pay into a system that was just supposed to protect the
>>>>working poor from poverty in old age.
>>>>
>>>>"After most private sector workers were absorbed, the federal
>>>>government targeted other government workers--even though their
>>>>retirements were secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social Security
>>>>Act to let states and municipalities voluntarily cover their public
>>>>employees under Social Security. Some opted in, others stayed outside
>>>>the system. This voluntary agreement was revoked in 1983, when Congress
>>>>made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set up
>>>>alternative retirement plans for their employees; only pension plans
>>>>pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new employees.
>>>>
>>>>"At the same time, all new federal employees were forced into Social
>>>>Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would ensure
>>>>Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere 16
>>>>years later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In 1990, the
>>>>Social Security Act was amended again to force any public employee not
>>>>already enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton proposes to
>>>>close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers
>>>>into the Social Security system."
>>>>
>>>>    Anyway, getting back to the draft. As the "national service" program
>>>>grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more options --
>>>>including the option of serving regular military duty. Of course they
>>>>won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor adjustments
>>>>that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But
>>>>gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option by
>>>>making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing enlistment will
>>>>get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually national
>>>>service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting government
>>>>money or having trouble with the law. Not to worry, it will be easy to
>>>>get an exemption, at least at first. Having a regular job, having kids,
>>>>being in school, writing a "hardship" letter, etc., will all get you
>>>>out of national service. As well as lots of more narrowly tailored
>>>>exemptions designed to win the support of various interest groups for
>>>>the program. But over time, these exemptions will start to be called
>>>>"loopholes," and Congress will go about "tightening" them. Just like
>>>>they do with taxes.
>>>>
>>>>    Sometime around this point, most people will start to realize the
>>>>country has a full-on military draft. Of course if they'd been asked
>>>>whether they wanted a draft, they would've said "Hell no!" But it
>>>>happened so slowly. None of the changes were alarming. They all seemed
>>>>to make sense at the time. And by now National Service is an
>>>>established program. All kinds of groups have strong financial and
>>>>emotional investments in it. Kind of late to blow the whistle, isn't it?
>>>>
>>>>Peace, love & liberty,
>>>>                    <<< Starchild >>>
>>>>
>

If they're smart they do :)

And they're not "loopholes" so to say- it's more that business/personal 
tax law is so incredibly complex that it's *way* beyond the grasp of 
anyone not studying it as their profession.

The legal and accountant costs are the same regardless of the dollar 
values involved-
A pizza delivery boy isn't going to spend 10k on consultants for the end 
result of cutting his taxable income by 30%, but for an exec making 100k 
per year, it makes sense...

>>>> In a message dated 4/27/04 2:37:05 AM, sfdreamer@earthlink.net writes:
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>>    A friend of mine recently described how he believes the military 
>>>>> draft
>>>>> will be introduced. Elaborating on his basic idea, I've come up with
>>>>> the following scenario:
>>>>>
>>>>>    For starters, they won't call it a "draft." Instead it will be 
>>>>> called
>>>>> "national service" or something like that. And just so people don't 
>>>>> get
>>>>> alarmed, it won't involve the military at all, or if it does only
>>>>> civilian jobs in veterans hospitals and things like that. The program
>>>>> will be sold as a way to give young people pride in their communities
>>>>> by doing things like cleaning up local streets, helping conduct the
>>>>> census, or doing environmental protection work on government land --
>>>>> you know, the stuff we supposedly pay taxes for. (This additional
>>>>> low-pay grunt labor will allow politicians to take money they would
>>>>> have spent on these services and give it back to the taxpayers? Ha ha,
>>>>> that's a good one. No, they'll spend it on other things that are more
>>>>> popular with the special interests who write them checks.)
>>>>>
>>>>>    The "national service" program probably won't be mandatory at 
>>>>> first.
>>>>> You'll only be required to participate if you *want* certain things,
>>>>> like a government loan for college. Perhaps universities and school
>>>>> districts will find that some of their government funding is made
>>>>> conditional upon a certain percentage of their students signing up for
>>>>> the program -- this will give school personnel an incentive to get
>>>>> students to sign up.
>>>>>
>>>>>    Participation may also be used as an alternative to things you 
>>>>> *don't*
>>>>> want. Imagine being told, "Here are your options -- you can either pay
>>>>> all these traffic tickets now (sorry, cash or credit card only!), lose
>>>>> your driver's license permanently, or sign up for national service."
>>>>> What would you do? Or, "You're probably facing several months behind
>>>>> bars on this misdemeanor charge, but if you sign up for national
>>>>> service you can avoid any jail time and they'll even remove the 
>>>>> offense
>>>>> from your record."
>>>>>
>>>>>    Once the initial program is in place and the public has relaxed 
>>>>> about
>>>>> it, it will slowly become mandatory for more and more people and the
>>>>> requirements will become more and more onerous. That's exactly what
>>>>> happened with Social Security. The Social Security Act was passed in
>>>>> 1935. In 1936, the federal government published an informational
>>>>> pamphlet about it which stated:
>>>>>
>>>>> "And finally, beginning in 1949, 12 years from now, you and your
>>>>> employer will each pay 3 cents on each dollar you earn, up to $3,000 a
>>>>> year. That is the most you will ever pay."
>>>>>
>>>>>    Of course it was a lie. According to a site with a whole lot of
>>>>> revealing info about Social Security
>>>>> (http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm), the maximum
>>>>> inflation-adjusted SS tax per person in the year 2000 was more than 5
>>>>> times that amount. For workers with average incomes, the government 
>>>>> now
>>>>> collects the equivalent of 6 weeks worth of their salary in Social
>>>>> Security taxes every year.
>>>>>
>>>>>    When it got started, Social Security was also optional for most
>>>>> Americans. But over time, more and more people were forced into it. A
>>>>> 1999 Reason magazine article
>>>>> (http://reason.com/9908/fe.rm.forced.shtml) describes how this 
>>>>> happened:
>>>>>
>>>>> "When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in 1935,
>>>>> the stated goal was to guarantee that industrial workers would have
>>>>> secure pensions. With the Great Depression threatening the life of so
>>>>> many enterprises, it seemed like a good idea to provide these workers
>>>>> with an independent, guaranteed retirement plan. Public employees were
>>>>> specifically excluded because Congress recognized that they were
>>>>> already safe from the swing of private sector fortunes.
>>>>>
>>>>> "Then President Roosevelt made a promise that revealed his
>>>>> administration's redistributionist aims. FDR allowed workers who
>>>>> retired after 1936--no matter how little they paid in--to collect full
>>>>> benefits immediately. That meant that the system had to expand to 
>>>>> cover
>>>>> the costs of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners,
>>>>> farmers, doctors, and others who traditionally funded their own
>>>>> retirements were gradually forced into the system. Today, more than 
>>>>> 148
>>>>> million workers pay into a system that was just supposed to protect 
>>>>> the
>>>>> working poor from poverty in old age.
>>>>>
>>>>> "After most private sector workers were absorbed, the federal
>>>>> government targeted other government workers--even though their
>>>>> retirements were secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social Security
>>>>> Act to let states and municipalities voluntarily cover their public
>>>>> employees under Social Security. Some opted in, others stayed outside
>>>>> the system. This voluntary agreement was revoked in 1983, when 
>>>>> Congress
>>>>> made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set up
>>>>> alternative retirement plans for their employees; only pension plans
>>>>> pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new employees.
>>>>>
>>>>> "At the same time, all new federal employees were forced into Social
>>>>> Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would ensure
>>>>> Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere 16
>>>>> years later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In 1990, the
>>>>> Social Security Act was amended again to force any public employee not
>>>>> already enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton 
>>>>> proposes to
>>>>> close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers
>>>>> into the Social Security system."
>>>>>
>>>>>    Anyway, getting back to the draft. As the "national service" 
>>>>> program
>>>>> grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more options --
>>>>> including the option of serving regular military duty. Of course they
>>>>> won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor adjustments
>>>>> that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But
>>>>> gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option by
>>>>> making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing enlistment 
>>>>> will
>>>>> get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually national
>>>>> service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting government
>>>>> money or having trouble with the law. Not to worry, it will be easy to
>>>>> get an exemption, at least at first. Having a regular job, having 
>>>>> kids,
>>>>> being in school, writing a "hardship" letter, etc., will all get you
>>>>> out of national service. As well as lots of more narrowly tailored
>>>>> exemptions designed to win the support of various interest groups for
>>>>> the program. But over time, these exemptions will start to be called
>>>>> "loopholes," and Congress will go about "tightening" them. Just like
>>>>> they do with taxes.
>>>>>
>>>>>    Sometime around this point, most people will start to realize the
>>>>> country has a full-on military draft. Of course if they'd been asked
>>>>> whether they wanted a draft, they would've said "Hell no!" But it
>>>>> happened so slowly. None of the changes were alarming. They all seemed
>>>>> to make sense at the time. And by now National Service is an
>>>>> established program. All kinds of groups have strong financial and
>>>>> emotional investments in it. Kind of late to blow the whistle, 
>>>>> isn't it?
>>>>>
>>>>> Peace, love & liberty,

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes



Actually, the United States in the 1950s had a very small gap between the
rich and poor.  CEOs might have made 5x more than the average worker, not
500x.  The "rich" drove Cadillacs, and the "poor" drove Fords.  That was
just about the extent of the income gap. 

I would like to see a return to those days in America.  Seems like the
right-wing is always talking about going back to the "good 'ol days of
America"... I hardly think any of them would call America in the 1950s
communist.

-troy
