Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes

On 27 April 2004, Troy Sheets wrote:

>
>
> Actually, the United States in the 1950s had a very small gap between the
> rich and poor.  CEOs might have made 5x more than the average worker, not
> 500x.  The "rich" drove Cadillacs, and the "poor" drove Fords.  That was
> just about the extent of the income gap.

THIS is really the root of most all of the "evils" in the US, IMHO.
Track the expansion of the income gap vs. the rate of crime, as well as
the overall quality of life and I'll bet you find some enlightenment.

I believe that the changes in the tax code (tax cuts) have severely
affected this in a negative way (facilitated the increase in the gap.)
This is where change needs to happen first if there's a desire to reduce
the gap.

>
> I would like to see a return to those days in America.  Seems like the
> right-wing is always talking about going back to the "good 'ol days of
> America"... I hardly think any of them would call America in the 1950s
> communist.

Subject: [sfraves] Interesting experience

Something to get off the subject of politics, especially since I suck at =
debating:

"This was back in 2000, i remeber the experience vividly, i wanted to =
talk about it so here it goes.

I have never seen a DJ do this so I don't know if it was a DJ in the =
general sense.=20
I had never been in such a place before, met a girl on line and took the =
bus SF to meet her and hang out for the weekend.

Her boyfriend took me out around town at 2 am that night walkd about 5 =
blocks from 3rd and Bryant. Where she was living. Came to this shady =
club with people standing outside, lots of weed inside and people =
crowded togtether talking and smoking. He introduced me to people and i =
got a hug instead of a hand-shake from girls and guys ( hey man how are =
you doing where are you from? etc)

The place ( I dont remeber the name of it except that it had green sign =
and looked kind of like a hole in the wall joint but inside it was =
different) had 3 rooms One main one with a bar accross from it. The bar =
was packed no free stools. DJ was up on a pretty high deck mixing some =
loud jungle. Started to look pretty dead on the main floor so the =
bouncer at the door yells Yo' FUCK IT UP!" so the guy brings in some =
other crazy jungle track about twice as eratic as the first. (Turns up =
the volume a bit to).

The other room had another jungle dj and so we hung around I was =
introduced to people all most of whom work for yahoo and other tech =
companies, a lot look like they just got off the bus from work and had =
been danceing with their bags/backpacks with them. Obviously to unwind.

It was like THE place they came to unwind. One girl letting loose on the =
floor looked like she was a totally different person before she walked =
into that place.

Later on that night we walked into the way back room and saw everyone =
standing around this guy setting up sound equipment on a table. People =
were standing around watching intently and the club staff looked at this =
guy like hes gonna turn the place upside down and they were standing =
back looking at him like he was in control now.

It was this guy with 2 laptops on a table along with a dat and a bunch =
of other sound modules and tone generators of some kind. He didn't play =
anyting anyone could dance to. - he would start with a sound - from some =
kind of sound box, turn the knobs and make it build and buld - then some =
flange sounds nad vibrating swishes and stuf very loud and mixed it with =
other sounds. - everyone was just crowded around the table watching this =
guy do this - i had never seen anything like that before - would you =
call that djing? or what do you call it?=20

It was amaizing - I think it was more to cater to those who were drugged =
up - I wasn't nor did I drink at all and I was really curious about it =
all. What does anyone give as a take on this experience

If anyone else knows what this is called or categorized as please share =
it. I mean where I've been to places in general - no one woudl take =
interest in a guy on a table with a bunch of gadgets just creating =
sounds like that.=20

I felt like this is someting I'd love to do if a crowd loved it.
Some how I feel like it really was an event to be tripping off of while =
on the weed. I bet I got some kind of contact high being in there either =
way. "

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) GOP Senator joins Democrats in calling for military draft

	Don't get me wrong, I think a draft is a *terrible* idea, no =
matter=20
what they call it. People should be free to live their lives as they=20
choose so long as they don't hurt others, not be forced into the=20
service of some government. Social Security is bad for similar reasons.=20=

I'm just trying to give people the heads-up that a draft may not come=20
in the obvious form that it has in the past. I hope my sarcasm wasn't=20
widely interpreted as support for any of what I described below!

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>


On Tuesday, April 27, 2004, at 09:50  AM, JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:

> Now that explination makes sense. It really shouldn't be about the=20
> fear of
> it, people act like they're gonna drop you somewhere in the dessert=20
> from a plane
> with a parashoot and put a gun in your hand. It's just a matter of=20
> weather or
> not it's morrally right to force responsibility to citizens in a war=20=

> that not
> everyone agrees with.
>
> In a message dated 4/27/04 2:37:05 AM, sfdreamer@earthlink.net writes:
>
>
>> =A0 =A0 A friend of mine recently described how he believes the =
military=20
>> draft
>> will be introduced. Elaborating on his basic idea, I've come up with
>> the following scenario:
>>
>> =A0 =A0 For starters, they won't call it a "draft." Instead it will =
be=20
>> called
>> "national service" or something like that. And just so people don't=20=

>> get
>> alarmed, it won't involve the military at all, or if it does only
>> civilian jobs in veterans hospitals and things like that. The program
>> will be sold as a way to give young people pride in their communities
>> by doing things like cleaning up local streets, helping conduct the
>> census, or doing environmental protection work on government land --
>> you know, the stuff we supposedly pay taxes for. (This additional
>> low-pay grunt labor will allow politicians to take money they would
>> have spent on these services and give it back to the taxpayers? Ha =
ha,
>> that's a good one. No, they'll spend it on other things that are more
>> popular with the special interests who write them checks.)
>>
>> =A0 =A0 The "national service" program probably won't be mandatory at=20=

>> first.
>> You'll only be required to participate if you *want* certain things,
>> like a government loan for college. Perhaps universities and school
>> districts will find that some of their government funding is made
>> conditional upon a certain percentage of their students signing up =
for
>> the program -- this will give school personnel an incentive to get
>> students to sign up.
>>
>> =A0 =A0 Participation may also be used as an alternative to things =
you=20
>> *don't*
>> want. Imagine being told, "Here are your options -- you can either =
pay
>> all these traffic tickets now (sorry, cash or credit card only!), =
lose
>> your driver's license permanently, or sign up for national service."
>> What would you do? Or, "You're probably facing several months behind
>> bars on this misdemeanor charge, but if you sign up for national
>> service you can avoid any jail time and they'll even remove the=20
>> offense
>> from your record."
>>
>> =A0 =A0 Once the initial program is in place and the public has =
relaxed=20
>> about
>> it, it will slowly become mandatory for more and more people and the
>> requirements will become more and more onerous. That's exactly what
>> happened with Social Security. The Social Security Act was passed in
>> 1935. In 1936, the federal government published an informational
>> pamphlet about it which stated:
>>
>> =A0"And finally, beginning in 1949, 12 years from now, you and your
>> employer will each pay 3 cents on each dollar you earn, up to $3,000 =
a
>> year. That is the most you will ever pay."
>>
>> =A0 =A0 Of course it was a lie. According to a site with a whole lot =
of
>> revealing info about Social Security
>> (http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm), the maximum
>> inflation-adjusted SS tax per person in the year 2000 was more than 5
>> times that amount. For workers with average incomes, the government=20=

>> now
>> collects the equivalent of 6 weeks worth of their salary in Social
>> Security taxes every year.
>>
>> =A0 =A0 When it got started, Social Security was also optional for =
most
>> Americans. But over time, more and more people were forced into it. A
>> 1999 Reason magazine article
>> (http://reason.com/9908/fe.rm.forced.shtml) describes how this=20
>> happened:
>>
>> "When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in =
1935,
>> the stated goal was to guarantee that industrial workers would have
>> secure pensions. With the Great Depression threatening the life of so
>> many enterprises, it seemed like a good idea to provide these workers
>> with an independent, guaranteed retirement plan. Public employees =
were
>> specifically excluded because Congress recognized that they were
>> already safe from the swing of private sector fortunes.
>>
>> "Then President Roosevelt made a promise that revealed his
>> administration's redistributionist aims. FDR allowed workers who
>> retired after 1936--no matter how little they paid in--to collect =
full
>> benefits immediately. That meant that the system had to expand to=20
>> cover
>> the costs of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners,
>> farmers, doctors, and others who traditionally funded their own
>> retirements were gradually forced into the system. Today, more than=20=

>> 148
>> million workers pay into a system that was just supposed to protect=20=

>> the
>> working poor from poverty in old age.
>>
>> "After most private sector workers were absorbed, the federal
>> government targeted other government workers--even though their
>> retirements were secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social Security
>> Act to let states and municipalities voluntarily cover their public
>> employees under Social Security. Some opted in, others stayed outside
>> the system. This voluntary agreement was revoked in 1983, when=20
>> Congress
>> made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set up
>> alternative retirement plans for their employees; only pension plans
>> pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new employees.
>>
>> "At the same time, all new federal employees were forced into Social
>> Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would ensure
>> Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere 16
>> years later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In 1990, =
the
>> Social Security Act was amended again to force any public employee =
not
>> already enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton proposes=20=

>> to
>> close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers
>> into the Social Security system."
>>
>> =A0 =A0 Anyway, getting back to the draft. As the "national service"=20=

>> program
>> grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more options --
>> including the option of serving regular military duty. Of course they
>> won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor adjustments
>> that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But
>> gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option by
>> making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing enlistment=20
>> will
>> get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually national
>> service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting government
>> money or having trouble with the law. Not to worry, it will be easy =
to
>> get an exemption, at least at first. Having a regular job, having=20
>> kids,
>> being in school, writing a "hardship" letter, etc., will all get you
>> out of national service. As well as lots of more narrowly tailored
>> exemptions designed to win the support of various interest groups for
>> the program. But over time, these exemptions will start to be called
>> "loopholes," and Congress will go about "tightening" them. Just like
>> they do with taxes.
>>
>> =A0 =A0 Sometime around this point, most people will start to realize =
the
>> country has a full-on military draft. Of course if they'd been asked
>> whether they wanted a draft, they would've said "Hell no!" But it
>> happened so slowly. None of the changes were alarming. They all =
seemed
>> to make sense at the time. And by now National Service is an
>> established program. All kinds of groups have strong financial and
>> emotional investments in it. Kind of late to blow the whistle, isn't=20=

>> it?
>>
>> Peace, love & liberty,
>> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0 <<< Starchild >>>
>>
>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes

On 27 April 2004, Troy Sheets wrote:

>
>
> Actually, the United States in the 1950s had a very small gap between the
> rich and poor.  CEOs might have made 5x more than the average worker, not
> 500x.  The "rich" drove Cadillacs, and the "poor" drove Fords.  That was
> just about the extent of the income gap.

Want details???  Plug the data from this page into excel:
http://www.census.gov/hhes/income/histinc/f03.html
or use this one for a wider range of data:
http://www.census.gov/hhes/income/histinc/f01.html

A study of the results of the 80's and 90's is here:
http://www.cbpp.org/5-31-01tax.htm
It's the after tax results that are important in this discussion.  (A
graph that shows this, for 1979-1997, is here:
http://www.cbpp.org/5-31-01tax-pr-f1.jpg)

As an aside, this often times seems to boil down to an "us" vs. "them"
argument.  Well, there's a tribe for us "others":
http://liturl.com/93

>
> I would like to see a return to those days in America.  Seems like the
> right-wing is always talking about going back to the "good 'ol days of
> America"... I hardly think any of them would call America in the 1950s
> communist.
>
> -troy
>


http://www.jcthedj.com

Subject: RE: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes



just a couple of quick points and i'll go back to
lurking --

to use an over-simplified model, there are two factors
that make a nation work - politics and economics.  in
the US, politically we're federalized dmocratic and
economically capitalist.  they are tied together in
the nation's operations, but are in fact mutually
exclusive.

communism and socialism, likewise, have been seen
together in political/economic setups, but much like
capitalism and democracy, are mutually exclusive.  

most of all, communism and socialism are by far and
away not the same thing -- your first clue on this is
that there are different words for them.  

as UC alumni, it's distressing to hear that Cal's
poly-sci department presents them as the same.  i'd
expect that kind of academic laziness at a high school
level, but not at the flagship campus of the UC.  ah
well.  next time i'm up at Cal i'll have a talk with
Dr. Chhibber about that.

finally, we here in the US enjoy *a lot* of socialist
products and services.  these include things like
highways, sanitation/sewer systems, utility
infrastructure and so on.  

the position that the US completely rejects socialism
and that socialism cannot work at all, no matter what,
is flawed at best.  and again, it's a point that i'd
hope the poli-sci department at Cal wouldn't be
promoting to it's students.  not because i think Cal
should be promoting some ultra-liberal-USA-hating
philosophy, but because the argument is fallacious and
can be debated off immediately.

okay, back to lurk mode.  if anyone wants to hear some
breaks tracks at their parties and wants to fly me up
from SoCal, drop me a note and i'll get a demo CD out
to you.  of course, i'll have to charge you for the
gig -- if i did it for free, i wouldn't be a
capitalist, now would i?

> Idealist perspective

At 09:13 PM 4/26/2004, Aaron W wrote:
>Just thought I'd let you know that Canada and Mexico are now no longer
>options due to the "Smart Border Declaration" signed a few years back -
>you're gonna need to go a lot further now.
>
>Also, college will no longer provide a haven from being drafted - the
>way the current bills are being written, you will be allowed to finish
>the semester you are currently enrolled in and that's the only deferment
>you will receive.

I never thought I would support a return to the draft, but recent events 
have made me rethink this position.  This generation's relationship to the 
brutal realities of war is pretty abstract:  video games;  censored 
news;  and some jackass in borrowed flight gear who had never seen battle 
himself shouting "bring it on."

Folks who have actually been in battle are very reluctant to support 
grandiose worldwide military interventions.  They understand the actual 
costs of war.  It's quite easy right now to sit in one's armchair, wave a 
flag, and let others do the dirty work in Iraq and elsewhere.  When you are 
about to be placed in harm's way, however, a certain clarification of 
thought occurs.

This happened during the Vietnam war.  Many had to ask the 
question:  "...is it worth my life to support some abstract domino theory 
of politics?"  Good to be forced to ask such questions, I think.

Further, unless you had some rich daddy who would buy you an aircraft and 
flight suit in the National Guard, people from various backgrounds, 
ethnicities, and social strata were forced to work and live together.  Now 
it seems we have increasing stratification of society and concomitant 
tension and lack of empathy with those who are different from those with 
whom you associate.

I don't wish the draft on anyone, however.  What I would prefer to see is 
"mandatory" public service:  say, two years of military or other service to 
the country.   "Mandatory" in that after completion of this service you 
would "vest" in certain rights and privileges accorded to full citizens, 
like voting, reasonable access to health care, ability to hold elected 
office; priority in hiring, and other valuable benefits like the ability to 
serve on a board of directors.  Thus, one could "choose" to give to the 
country or not.  The selfish would pay.

Love,

Apollo

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."

life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

>>> =A0 =A0 A friend of mine recently described how he believes the =
military =20
>>> draft
>>> will be introduced. Elaborating on his basic idea, I've come up with
>>> the following scenario:
>>>
>>> =A0 =A0 For starters, they won't call it a "draft." Instead it will =
be =20
>>> called
>>> "national service" or something like that. And just so people don't =20=

>>> get
>>> alarmed, it won't involve the military at all, or if it does only
>>> civilian jobs in veterans hospitals and things like that. The =
program
>>> will be sold as a way to give young people pride in their =
communities
>>> by doing things like cleaning up local streets, helping conduct the
>>> census, or doing environmental protection work on government land --
>>> you know, the stuff we supposedly pay taxes for. (This additional
>>> low-pay grunt labor will allow politicians to take money they would
>>> have spent on these services and give it back to the taxpayers? Ha =20=

>>> ha,
>>> that's a good one. No, they'll spend it on other things that are =
more
>>> popular with the special interests who write them checks.)
>>>
>>> =A0 =A0 The "national service" program probably won't be mandatory =
at =20
>>> first.
>>> You'll only be required to participate if you *want* certain things,
>>> like a government loan for college. Perhaps universities and school
>>> districts will find that some of their government funding is made
>>> conditional upon a certain percentage of their students signing up =20=

>>> for
>>> the program -- this will give school personnel an incentive to get
>>> students to sign up.
>>>
>>> =A0 =A0 Participation may also be used as an alternative to things =
you =20
>>> *don't*
>>> want. Imagine being told, "Here are your options -- you can either =20=

>>> pay
>>> all these traffic tickets now (sorry, cash or credit card only!), =20=

>>> lose
>>> your driver's license permanently, or sign up for national service."
>>> What would you do? Or, "You're probably facing several months behind
>>> bars on this misdemeanor charge, but if you sign up for national
>>> service you can avoid any jail time and they'll even remove the =20
>>> offense
>>> from your record."
>>>
>>> =A0 =A0 Once the initial program is in place and the public has =
relaxed =20
>>> about
>>> it, it will slowly become mandatory for more and more people and the
>>> requirements will become more and more onerous. That's exactly what
>>> happened with Social Security. The Social Security Act was passed in
>>> 1935. In 1936, the federal government published an informational
>>> pamphlet about it which stated:
>>>
>>> =A0"And finally, beginning in 1949, 12 years from now, you and your
>>> employer will each pay 3 cents on each dollar you earn, up to $3,000 =
=20
>>> a
>>> year. That is the most you will ever pay."
>>>
>>> =A0 =A0 Of course it was a lie. According to a site with a whole lot =
of
>>> revealing info about Social Security
>>> (http://www.justfacts.com/socialsecurity.htm), the maximum
>>> inflation-adjusted SS tax per person in the year 2000 was more than =
5
>>> times that amount. For workers with average incomes, the government =20=

>>> now
>>> collects the equivalent of 6 weeks worth of their salary in Social
>>> Security taxes every year.
>>>
>>> =A0 =A0 When it got started, Social Security was also optional for =
most
>>> Americans. But over time, more and more people were forced into it. =
A
>>> 1999 Reason magazine article
>>> (http://reason.com/9908/fe.rm.forced.shtml) describes how this =20
>>> happened:
>>>
>>> "When the Roosevelt administration dreamed up Social Security in =20
>>> 1935,
>>> the stated goal was to guarantee that industrial workers would have
>>> secure pensions. With the Great Depression threatening the life of =
so
>>> many enterprises, it seemed like a good idea to provide these =
workers
>>> with an independent, guaranteed retirement plan. Public employees =20=

>>> were
>>> specifically excluded because Congress recognized that they were
>>> already safe from the swing of private sector fortunes.
>>>
>>> "Then President Roosevelt made a promise that revealed his
>>> administration's redistributionist aims. FDR allowed workers who
>>> retired after 1936--no matter how little they paid in--to collect =20=

>>> full
>>> benefits immediately. That meant that the system had to expand to =20=

>>> cover
>>> the costs of these unfunded liabilities. Small-business owners,
>>> farmers, doctors, and others who traditionally funded their own
>>> retirements were gradually forced into the system. Today, more than =20=

>>> 148
>>> million workers pay into a system that was just supposed to protect =20=

>>> the
>>> working poor from poverty in old age.
>>>
>>> "After most private sector workers were absorbed, the federal
>>> government targeted other government workers--even though their
>>> retirements were secure. In 1954 Congress amended the Social =
Security
>>> Act to let states and municipalities voluntarily cover their public
>>> employees under Social Security. Some opted in, others stayed =
outside
>>> the system. This voluntary agreement was revoked in 1983, when =20
>>> Congress
>>> made it illegal for states and municipalities to continue to set up
>>> alternative retirement plans for their employees; only pension plans
>>> pre-dating the 1983 amendments were allowed to enroll new employees.
>>>
>>> "At the same time, all new federal employees were forced into Social
>>> Security. (Congress maintained that the 1983 amendments would ensure
>>> Social Security's solvency for at least another 75 years; a mere 16
>>> years later, Social Security is again facing bankruptcy.) In 1990, =20=

>>> the
>>> Social Security Act was amended again to force any public employee =20=

>>> not
>>> already enrolled in an exempt plan into the system. Clinton proposes =
=20
>>> to
>>> close this last loophole, forcing the last handful of exempt workers
>>> into the Social Security system."
>>>
>>> =A0 =A0 Anyway, getting back to the draft. As the "national service" =
=20
>>> program
>>> grows, it will be "improved" by offering participants more options =
--
>>> including the option of serving regular military duty. Of course =
they
>>> won't make a big deal about this. Just one of the minor adjustments
>>> that bureaucrats are always making in government programs. But
>>> gradually, more participants will be steered toward this option by
>>> making the alternatives less attractive. Those choosing enlistment =20=

>>> will
>>> get better pay and shorter service requirements. Eventually national
>>> service will be opened to everyone, not just those wanting =
government
>>> money or having trouble with the law. Not to worry, it will be easy =20=

>>> to
>>> get an exemption, at least at first. Having a regular job, having =20=

>>> kids,
>>> being in school, writing a "hardship" letter, etc., will all get you
>>> out of national service. As well as lots of more narrowly tailored
>>> exemptions designed to win the support of various interest groups =
for
>>> the program. But over time, these exemptions will start to be called
>>> "loopholes," and Congress will go about "tightening" them. Just like
>>> they do with taxes.
>>>
>>> =A0 =A0 Sometime around this point, most people will start to =
realize the
>>> country has a full-on military draft. Of course if they'd been asked
>>> whether they wanted a draft, they would've said "Hell no!" But it
>>> happened so slowly. None of the changes were alarming. They all =20
>>> seemed
>>> to make sense at the time. And by now National Service is an
>>> established program. All kinds of groups have strong financial and
>>> emotional investments in it. Kind of late to blow the whistle, isn't =
=20
>>> it?
>>>
>>> Peace, love & liberty,

just a couple of quick points and i'll go back to
lurking --

to use an over-simplified model, there are two factors
that make a nation work - politics and economics.  in
the US, politically we're federalized dmocratic and
economically capitalist.  they are tied together in
the nation's operations, but are in fact mutually
exclusive.

communism and socialism, likewise, have been seen
together in political/economic setups, but much like
capitalism and democracy, are mutually exclusive. =20

most of all, communism and socialism are by far and
away not the same thing -- your first clue on this is
that there are different words for them. =20

as UC alumni, it's distressing to hear that Cal's
poly-sci department presents them as the same.  i'd
expect that kind of academic laziness at a high school
level, but not at the flagship campus of the UC.  ah
well.  next time i'm up at Cal i'll have a talk with
Dr. Chhibber about that.

finally, we here in the US enjoy *a lot* of socialist
products and services.  these include things like
highways, sanitation/sewer systems, utility
infrastructure and so on. =20

the position that the US completely rejects socialism
and that socialism cannot work at all, no matter what,
is flawed at best.  and again, it's a point that i'd
hope the poli-sci department at Cal wouldn't be
promoting to it's students.  not because i think Cal
should be promoting some ultra-liberal-USA-hating
philosophy, but because the argument is fallacious and
can be debated off immediately.

okay, back to lurk mode.  if anyone wants to hear some
breaks tracks at their parties and wants to fly me up
from SoCal, drop me a note and i'll get a demo CD out
to you.  of course, i'll have to charge you for the
gig -- if i did it for free, i wouldn't be a
capitalist, now would i?

Some interesting words from someone who'd I'd call a conspiracy
theorist:

You can't fight city hall.
Death and taxes.

line. Lay down GI... Lay down GI...
We saw it all through the 20th century. And now with the 21st century
its time to stand up and realize that we should not allow ourselves to
be crammed into this rat maze.
We should not submit to dehumanization.
I don't know about you but I'm concerned with what's happening in this
world. I'm concerned with the structure. I'm concerned with the systems
of control. Those that control my life and those that seek to control it
EVEN MORE!

I want freedom!
That's what I want!
And that's what you should want!
Its up to each and every one of us to turn loose of just some of the
greed, the hatred, the envy, and yes the insecurities. Because that is
the central mode of control - to make us feel pathetic, small - so we'll
give up our sovereignty, our liberty, our destiny.

We have got to realize that we are being conditioned on a mass scale.
Start challenging this corporate slave state.
The 21st century's gonna be a new century. Not the century of slavery,
not the century of lies and issues of no significance, and classism, and
statism, and all of the rest of the modes of control.
Its gonna be the age of human kind standing up for something good, for
something pure and something right.

What a bunch of garbage - liberal, democrat, conservative, republican.
Its all there to control you.
Two sides of the same coin.
Two management teams bidding for control of the CEO job of Slavery
Incorporated. The truth is out there in front of you but they lay out
this buffet of lies.

I'm sick of it!
And I'm not gonna take a bite out of it!
Do ya got me?!?!!

Resistance is not futile.
We're gonna win this thing.
Human kind is too good.
We're not a bunch of underachievers.
We're gonna stand up and we're gonna be human beings.
We're gonna get fired up about the real things !
The things that matter !
Creativity and the dynamic human spirit that refuses to submit!
Well, that's it. That's all I got to say.

User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes

quoth Steve Osteen:
> It sounds like you guys are all promoting socialism.

If by socialism you mean a system that uses our vast collective wealth
to benefit people without the means to help themselves, then yes.

> It's lovely in concept, but horrible in practice,

Horrible in practice? Canada and western European nations have been
doing quite well with socialist policies for a while now. *No*
implementation is perfect, but I (and, I imagine, many people with
limited means) would much prefer some socialist policies in key areas
(healthcare, for one) to our all-or-nothing capitalist caste system.

Some of this stuff below is just ridiculous...

> capitalism:
> 
> freedom
> emphasis on personal acheivement
> rewards innovation
> Man WAS NOT created equal, but shall be given equal oppurtunity

"Equal opportunity"? LOL.

> survival of the fitest

You're confusing evolution with capitalism here. Do you really think
that (for instance) people who were born into poor families are
inherently weak, and therefore undeserving of life? That somehow the
wealthy are an evolved species of human more fit for survival? The poor
aren't poor because they were born uneducated or disabled. It's the lack
of equal opportunity [see above] (in education, in the workplace, and in
society as a whole) that keeps them where they are.

> Man is inherrently selfish and greedy, why deny it.

I don't believe that at all. You may be selfish and greedy. Americans,
for the most part, may be selfish and greedy. But people in the rest of
the world really aren't. Humanism and captitalism aren't mutually
exclusive.

> No hope for the weak or disabled
> realist perspective

Realist? There's nothing inherently "realistic" about capitalism. In
fact, it's more realistic to say that capitalism simply isn't the
be-all, end-all of economics. A self-proclaimed "realist" might say that
some socialist policies could potentially *compliment* a capitalist
society.

> Communism/Marxism(socialism):
> 
> conformity
> one for the good of the community
> weakest link is a broken leg for the whole community
> desirable for countries ruined by war that need hope
> why strive to be the best if there is no reward
> Loss of individualism and self expression
> Idealist perspective

You're thinking of communism specifically. Socialism isn't an
all-or-nothing deal, it's just a term used to describe any system
whereby a good or service is owned and distributed collectively. In
Marxist-Leninist theory, socialism was a stepping stone from capitalism
to communism... Nowadays though, socialized services tend to work
hand-in-hand with capitalist economies. And FWIW, Canadians haven't
exactly had to sacrifice their individualism or self-expression for
public healthcare.

> Btw, I took a great poly-sci class at Berkeley, taught by a professor
> that also teaches at Ohlone community college, for the life of me I
> can't remember her name, I'll try to find it, it was an excellent
> class that I highly recommend.

She couldn't have been that great if her students are still using the
terms "communism" and "socialism" interchangably. Or weren't you paying
attention?

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) GOP Senator joins Democrats in calling for military draft

Troy,

	You don't mean voting to *give* people like you more disposable income 
-- you mean not voting to *take* as much of the disposable income you 
have. It's funny how we forget that the money belongs to the person who 
earns it in the first place.

	Of course if you *don't* think you earned your money, or believe that 
it more properly belongs to someone else, you're free to give more of 
it away. But please, let's not pass any more laws confiscating more 
money from *other* people based on *your* sense of guilt.

	I'm all for reducing suffering in the world. And by that I mean the 
*world*, not just American families. Most American families have it 
relatively good compared to people in places like India and Sudan. But 
whether rich or poor, people suffer when they are *compelled* by force 
to do things they don't want to do. Instead of encouraging more 
government aggression, why not look for ways to end poverty *without* 
the use of force?

					<<< Starchild >>>

"When robbing Peter to pay Paul, government can usually count on the 
support of Paul."

Thread-Topic: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes
Thread-Index: AcQsnpA8G41AF7Z4QaGVordOS3lrRwAAKbLw
From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 27 Apr 2004 21:43:02.0312 (UTC) FILETIME=[9D90D280:01C42CA0]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes

Ok fine! I suck at debating, never was good at it.

I am just sick of paying tons of taxes for people that don't work hard =
or try their best. I don't want to end up like Canada or Europe because =
they pay a LOT more in taxes then we do.

I also believe this:

The American system of government (although far from perfect) is the =
best government to ever be created.



-----Original Message-----
From: shawn allen [mailto:shawn@alterior.net]
Sent: Tuesday, April 27, 2004 2:28 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes


quoth Steve Osteen:
> It sounds like you guys are all promoting socialism.

If by socialism you mean a system that uses our vast collective wealth
to benefit people without the means to help themselves, then yes.

> It's lovely in concept, but horrible in practice,

Horrible in practice? Canada and western European nations have been
doing quite well with socialist policies for a while now. *No*
implementation is perfect, but I (and, I imagine, many people with
limited means) would much prefer some socialist policies in key areas
(healthcare, for one) to our all-or-nothing capitalist caste system.

Some of this stuff below is just ridiculous...

> capitalism:
>=20
> freedom
> emphasis on personal acheivement
> rewards innovation
> Man WAS NOT created equal, but shall be given equal oppurtunity

"Equal opportunity"? LOL.

> survival of the fitest

You're confusing evolution with capitalism here. Do you really think
that (for instance) people who were born into poor families are
inherently weak, and therefore undeserving of life? That somehow the
wealthy are an evolved species of human more fit for survival? The poor
aren't poor because they were born uneducated or disabled. It's the lack
of equal opportunity [see above] (in education, in the workplace, and in
society as a whole) that keeps them where they are.

> Man is inherrently selfish and greedy, why deny it.

I don't believe that at all. You may be selfish and greedy. Americans,
for the most part, may be selfish and greedy. But people in the rest of
the world really aren't. Humanism and captitalism aren't mutually
exclusive.

> No hope for the weak or disabled
> realist perspective

Realist? There's nothing inherently "realistic" about capitalism. In
fact, it's more realistic to say that capitalism simply isn't the
be-all, end-all of economics. A self-proclaimed "realist" might say that
some socialist policies could potentially *compliment* a capitalist
society.

> Communism/Marxism(socialism):
>=20
> conformity
> one for the good of the community
> weakest link is a broken leg for the whole community
> desirable for countries ruined by war that need hope
> why strive to be the best if there is no reward
> Loss of individualism and self expression
> Idealist perspective

You're thinking of communism specifically. Socialism isn't an
all-or-nothing deal, it's just a term used to describe any system
whereby a good or service is owned and distributed collectively. In
Marxist-Leninist theory, socialism was a stepping stone from capitalism
to communism... Nowadays though, socialized services tend to work
hand-in-hand with capitalist economies. And FWIW, Canadians haven't
exactly had to sacrifice their individualism or self-expression for
public healthcare.

> Btw, I took a great poly-sci class at Berkeley, taught by a professor
> that also teaches at Ohlone community college, for the life of me I
> can't remember her name, I'll try to find it, it was an excellent
> class that I highly recommend.

She couldn't have been that great if her students are still using the
terms "communism" and "socialism" interchangably. Or weren't you paying
attention?

Cheers,
--=20
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

> >
> >Orbital to Disband After Next LP
> >
> >Joshua Sharp reports:
> >In 15 years, techno mainstays Phil and Paul Hartnoll have covered a lot
> >of ground. All Melvilles aside, hailing Orbital to be the most
> >successful crossover group of the electronic persuasion would not be an
> >inordinate boast. With six full-length releases under their belt, as
> >well as an incalculable number of singles, soundtrack offerings, remixes
> >and collaborations, the boys are finally ready to end it all.
> >
> >"I think we feel that Orbital has run its course," said Paul Hartnoll
> >via the official Orbital site. "We're both pursuing different avenues
> >with our music. And we've been sat, as brothers, in the same room for 15
> >years now-- and studios are always confined spaces-- I think it's time
> >for a change."
> >
> >Before closing the curtain on their decade-and-a-half discography, the
> >duo is set to release their final record, entitled The Blue Album
> >(Weezer mash-up comment withheld for the sake of humanity) on June 21st.
> >Says Paul of the swan song's sound: "It's closer in character to our
> >first album than our later ones, if only because we made it in our own
> >time and for ourselves." Confirmed titles so far include "You Lot",
> >"Acid Pants", "Bath Time", "Easy Serve", and "One Perfect Sunrise", the
> >latter featuring Dead Can Dance vocalist Lisa Gerrard. The album will be
> >followed by two final British concerts, showcasing the duo's legendary
> >finesse. As follows:
> >
> >06-25 London, England - Brixton Academy
> >06-27 Glastonbury, England - Glastonbury
> >
> >www.pitchformedia.com
> >

At 02:28 PM 4/27/2004, shawn allen wrote:
>quoth Steve Osteen:
>
>You're thinking of communism specifically. Socialism isn't an
>all-or-nothing deal, it's just a term used to describe any system
>whereby a good or service is owned and distributed collectively. In
>Marxist-Leninist theory, socialism was a stepping stone from capitalism
>to communism... Nowadays though, socialized services tend to work
>hand-in-hand with capitalist economies. And FWIW, Canadians haven't
>exactly had to sacrifice their individualism or self-expression for
>public healthcare.
>
> > Btw, I took a great poly-sci class at Berkeley, taught by a professor
> > that also teaches at Ohlone community college, for the life of me I
> > can't remember her name, I'll try to find it, it was an excellent
> > class that I highly recommend.
>
>She couldn't have been that great if her students are still using the
>terms "communism" and "socialism" interchangably. Or weren't you paying
>attention?

Excellent post, Shawn.  One might add that equating democracy and freedom 
with capitalism is another fallacy.  It is quite possible to have "freedom" 
and democracy in a socialist system.  Many seem to equate "freedom" with 
the ability to practice unfettered consumerism in a world with limited 
resources.  Freedom of thought and expression is, to me, far more important 
than the ability to buy fifty different kinds of underwear with the salary 
I earn working as a serf in some hierarchical corporation where most of 
one's life is spent in an environment that is antithetical to democracy and 
freedom.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

-----Original Message-----
From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org]
Sent: Tuesday, April 27, 2004 2:50 PM
To: shawn allen; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes


At 02:28 PM 4/27/2004, shawn allen wrote:
>quoth Steve Osteen:
>
>You're thinking of communism specifically. Socialism isn't an
>all-or-nothing deal, it's just a term used to describe any system
>whereby a good or service is owned and distributed collectively. In
>Marxist-Leninist theory, socialism was a stepping stone from capitalism
>to communism... Nowadays though, socialized services tend to work
>hand-in-hand with capitalist economies. And FWIW, Canadians haven't
>exactly had to sacrifice their individualism or self-expression for
>public healthcare.
>
> > Btw, I took a great poly-sci class at Berkeley, taught by a =
professor
> > that also teaches at Ohlone community college, for the life of me I
> > can't remember her name, I'll try to find it, it was an excellent
> > class that I highly recommend.
>
>She couldn't have been that great if her students are still using the
>terms "communism" and "socialism" interchangably. Or weren't you paying
>attention?

Excellent post, Shawn.  One might add that equating democracy and =
freedom=20
with capitalism is another fallacy.  It is quite possible to have =
"freedom"=20
and democracy in a socialist system.  Many seem to equate "freedom" with =

the ability to practice unfettered consumerism in a world with limited=20
resources.  Freedom of thought and expression is, to me, far more =
important=20
than the ability to buy fifty different kinds of underwear with the =
salary=20
I earn working as a serf in some hierarchical corporation where most of=20
one's life is spent in an environment that is antithetical to democracy =
and=20
freedom.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of=20
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of =

tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the =

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually =
become=20
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of=20
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the=20
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club,=20
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to =
that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Yes, as do I.  When the place opened there was some "dress code" I 
heard.  Athletic shoes, t-shirts, and jeans were prohibited.  One thing I 
will not do is dance in leather dress shoes -- boots are OK:)  But now I 
believe there is no dress code.  Correct?

Love,

Apollo

"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: [sfraves] nrr: wise words for a beautiful day



Instructions for Life in the new millennium from the
Dalai Lama:

1. Take into account that great love and great
achievements involve great risk.

2. When you lose, don't lose the lesson.

3. Follow the three Rs: Respect for self, respect for
others and responsibility for all your actions.

4. Remember that not getting what you want is
sometimes a wonderful stroke of luck.

5. Learn the rules so you know how to break them
properly.

6. Don't let a little dispute injure a great
friendship.

7. When you realize you've made a mistake, take
immediate steps to correct it.

8. Spend some time alone every day.

9. Open your arms to change, but don't let go of your
values.

10. Remember that silence is sometimes the best
answer.

11. Live a good, honorable life. Then when you get
older and think back,you'll be able to enjoy it a second time.

12. A loving atmosphere in your home is the
foundation for your life.

13. In disagreements with loved ones, deal only with
the current situation.Don't bring up the past.

14. Share your knowledge. It's a way to achieve
immortality.

15. Be gentle with the earth.

16. Once a year, go some place you've never been
before.

17. Remember that the best relationship is one in
which your love for each other exceeds your need
for each other.

18. Judge your success by what you had to give up in
order to get it.

19. Approach love and cooking with reckless abandon



"Øder tis moodle in der noggin tu smacken der ouchey und vinger-slingers ur 
to smacken-backen und fix de morkin, yøobetcha! "
-The Swedish Chef

Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY1-F89dDW6lCPx33E0000a89b@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 27 Apr 2004 22:14:24.0226 (UTC) FILETIME=[FF461C20:01C42CA4]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] RR: LTJ Bukem @ Ruby Skye?


Wow that sucks. The place is off the hook. NOTHING like 1015. Nothing at 
all.

If someone you like comes to Ruby Skye, check it out... It's worth one try. 
Not to say I've partied all over the world or anything but have in SF, LA, & 
New York... Ruby Skye is the best experience by far. Although I've only gone 
on nights that I wanted to hear someone play. Thats probably because I'm 
living in Sacramento now. If I was back on the peninsula again, it would 
probably be a regualr stop for me. Even on nights that the music was 
probably not going to be my thing.

Plus it's pretty easy to get on the guest list through thier web site. And 
once you do, GO that night, they'll keep sending you free list spots on a 
regular basis if you continue to go on the nights they offer to comp your 
cover.

AUDi,
Gavin

Subject: RE: [sfraves] RR: LTJ Bukem @ Ruby Skye?

i went last year to see BT.  i don't think i'll ever go back to Ruby Skye 
unless there was someone i really, really want to see.

the vibe is very much into the "look at me, i'm stylin', let's get drunk and 
dry hump on the dancefloor."  the place is nice...but to me it's nice in a 
cheesy way.  no doubt, they put a lot of money into it and they get great 
talent.

it's just not my bag.  in my opinion, i'd rather go to 1015.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR: LTJ Bukem @ Ruby Skye?

I like"d" Ruby Skye. As fate would have it, I used to live with a bartender
who worked at Ruby Skye...so when I turned 21, truth be told, Ruby Skye was
my first "club" experience. It is an extremely nice place. Very well thought
out in terms of the interiors. But geez this was like back in 2000/01, and I
certainly wasn't paying the $20 cover.

Now there are certainly some that say RS isn't underground enough, well no
shit. It is a "put on your nice shoes, pants, smelly cologne" and have your
lady get all dolled up. It's a socialite club. Most people are there to be
"seen". Residents usually pump out the funky/deep SF house and they get some
decent names in there. In fact, I heard that Chub & Ceballos showed up one
night, which is a huge thing. However, I can't say I have been there in
almost 2.5 years, so who knows...maybe it's shite.

The one thing I will say, and this may be jaded because I was always guest
list, but the security was always cool to me and the people I was with.
--
DJ Jack Triumph

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR: LTJ Bukem @ Ruby Skye?

I dunno about a pick up environment. Maybe because I only go on nights where 
like-minded party people make an effort to be there... Yes, there's always 
plenty of well dressed people. But it's not out of control. My experience 
has ALWAYS been, these well-dressed people are down as fcuk! I always hear 
how it's a bunch of stuck up, coke head girls trying to get the biggest 
baller to take them home. Thats never been the thing on nights when I've 
gone. It's always been just a whole lot of people there to party and party 
they do. Nothing like any "rave" I've been to in a number of years. I can't 
remember the last time there was a vibe at a rave like the last few times 
I've been to Ruby Skye. I'd even say it's more like a rave USED to be. Way 
back when. Not exactly, but more like it that any rave you'll see today in 
the Bay.

As far as 1015 being a drinking environment???

HAHAHAHAHAHA!!! yes, it might have a liquor licene, but the main room there 
is like a medium-sized warehouse party with the same amount of illicit 
drugs, better lights, and better sound (as well as talent). Somehow they've 
managed to kill the vibe it once had though. Save for certian nights.

AUDi,
Gavin

was pretty happy about that.

i like finding records for cheap.  mostly because i'm unemployed and still 
have to feed my vinyl habit.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR: LTJ Bukem @ Ruby Skye?

I don't think there is much of a dress code right now. If anything, it's a 
code made by the club's patrons. But it's all good. The other Saturday I was 
probably the most under-dressed male in the club. Had on a T-shirt. It was a 
nice T-shirt, brand new "insert label-whore brand here____" T-shirt. But 
still a T-shirt. Some denim jeans I payed waaaayyyyy too much for. But still 
jeans. And some all white K-Swiss. Way below the bar.

They did not even care as I went in even though I was obviously underdressed 
by thier clubber's in attendance standard. Better than that, the people 
themselves did not care. I partied with more well-dressed ladies, and 
partied hard, than at any other place I've been. Partied harder than you see 
people partying at raves anymore too. People were just there to dance, so 
what if they wanted to look good at the same time?

The dress code is kind of self-imposed. But I pulled it (not following the 
code) off and did not feel one bit uncomfortable doing it.

AUDi,
Gavin

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes

quoth Steve Osteen:
> Ok fine! I suck at debating, never was good at it.

You probably shouldn't get involved in debates then ;)

> I am just sick of paying tons of taxes for people that don't work hard
> or try their best. I don't want to end up like Canada or Europe
> because they pay a LOT more in taxes then we do.

We have one of the lowest effective tax rates in the world as a
percentage of GDP... but we also have the highest GDP. So yes, on a
large scalle we pay quite a bit less in taxes than the rest of the
world. Why is everyone complaining then?

I wouldn't mind paying more taxes if I knew that they were being put to
good use (thanks for pointing that out, Sarilion). I also know that if I
were a multi-millionaire, I wouldn't mind paying a great deal more taxes
if I knew that it would make everyones' lives better. You're not just
paying taxes for "people that don't work hard or try their best". Your
tax dollars pay for the law enforcement, fire departments, roads,
education, and a wide variety of other services you probably can't
imagine living without. It's no wonder that most of these services are
poor when compared to those of other countries with higher effective tax
rates.

> I also believe this:
> 
> The American system of government (although far from perfect) is the
> best government to ever be created.

I think the Constitution and the Bill of Rights are wonderful. The
system itself isn't all that great though.

Cheers,
--

Subject: RE: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes

I'm totally lost here.  Who else are you paying taxes for?  Have you ever 
considered that some people that are wealthy are earning their money and 
paying taxes on it too?  Do you really think CEO's are rewarded routinely 
for not trying their best?  Sure, there are shiesty people out there (ie 
Enron), but they're bad apples in the bushel.


sarilion

At 02:43 PM 4/27/2004, Steve Osteen wrote:

>Ok fine! I suck at debating, never was good at it.
>
>I am just sick of paying tons of taxes for people that don't work hard or 
>try their best. I don't want to end up like Canada or Europe because they 
>pay a LOT more in taxes then we do.
>
>I also believe this:
>
>The American system of government (although far from perfect) is the best 
>government to ever be created.
>
>
>
>-----Original Message-----
>From: shawn allen [mailto:shawn@alterior.net]
>Sent: Tuesday, April 27, 2004 2:28 PM
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes
>
>
>quoth Steve Osteen:
> > It sounds like you guys are all promoting socialism.
>
>If by socialism you mean a system that uses our vast collective wealth
>to benefit people without the means to help themselves, then yes.
>
> > It's lovely in concept, but horrible in practice,
>
>Horrible in practice? Canada and western European nations have been
>doing quite well with socialist policies for a while now. *No*
>implementation is perfect, but I (and, I imagine, many people with
>limited means) would much prefer some socialist policies in key areas
>(healthcare, for one) to our all-or-nothing capitalist caste system.
>
>Some of this stuff below is just ridiculous...
>
> > capitalism:
> >
> > freedom
> > emphasis on personal acheivement
> > rewards innovation
> > Man WAS NOT created equal, but shall be given equal oppurtunity
>
>"Equal opportunity"? LOL.
>
> > survival of the fitest
>
>You're confusing evolution with capitalism here. Do you really think
>that (for instance) people who were born into poor families are
>inherently weak, and therefore undeserving of life? That somehow the
>wealthy are an evolved species of human more fit for survival? The poor
>aren't poor because they were born uneducated or disabled. It's the lack
>of equal opportunity [see above] (in education, in the workplace, and in
>society as a whole) that keeps them where they are.
>
> > Man is inherrently selfish and greedy, why deny it.
>
>I don't believe that at all. You may be selfish and greedy. Americans,
>for the most part, may be selfish and greedy. But people in the rest of
>the world really aren't. Humanism and captitalism aren't mutually
>exclusive.
>
> > No hope for the weak or disabled
> > realist perspective
>
>Realist? There's nothing inherently "realistic" about capitalism. In
>fact, it's more realistic to say that capitalism simply isn't the
>be-all, end-all of economics. A self-proclaimed "realist" might say that
>some socialist policies could potentially *compliment* a capitalist
>society.
>
> > Communism/Marxism(socialism):
> >
> > conformity
> > one for the good of the community
> > weakest link is a broken leg for the whole community
> > desirable for countries ruined by war that need hope
> > why strive to be the best if there is no reward
> > Loss of individualism and self expression
> > Idealist perspective
>
>You're thinking of communism specifically. Socialism isn't an
>all-or-nothing deal, it's just a term used to describe any system
>whereby a good or service is owned and distributed collectively. In
>Marxist-Leninist theory, socialism was a stepping stone from capitalism
>to communism... Nowadays though, socialized services tend to work
>hand-in-hand with capitalist economies. And FWIW, Canadians haven't
>exactly had to sacrifice their individualism or self-expression for
>public healthcare.
>
> > Btw, I took a great poly-sci class at Berkeley, taught by a professor
> > that also teaches at Ohlone community college, for the life of me I
> > can't remember her name, I'll try to find it, it was an excellent
> > class that I highly recommend.
>
>She couldn't have been that great if her students are still using the
>terms "communism" and "socialism" interchangably. Or weren't you paying
>attention?
>
>Cheers,
>--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR: LTJ Bukem @ Ruby Skye?

I wouldn't go so far as to say that I hate it.  I've never actually =20
made it past the door.... only even tried that one time actually.

I choose not to go, though, because for a place that books all kind of =20=

DJs who play *dance* music, they have an incredibly bass-ackwards dress =20=

code that makes it impossible to go there in anything that would be =20
comfortable to DANCE in!  What's worse than the dress code, though, is =20=

the fact that it extends to your SHOES as well; which is even worse for =20=

a place that plays DANCE music.

I found all this out the hard way, back when I had my dotcom job, and a =20=

bunch of us decided to go to see $some_big_dj_or_another.  Hell, we =20
KNEW it was a "dress to impress" place, and even dressed fairly clubby =20=

and glossy.  But we were going there for the DJ, not to play the club =20=

game, to "see and be seen", or to "hook up".  So all but one of us got =20=

turned away at the door because we were not wearing =20
hard-ass-uncomfortable-can't-dance-for-shit-in-them-leather shoes.

I'm not totally unwilling to dress up on occasion.  But I wear =20
uncomfortable shoes for no one.

So I don't go to Ruby Skye.


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR: LTJ Bukem @ Ruby Skye?

i'm ever amazed how much people on this list like to
moan on and on about nothing!!!

i went to the show.  bukem played his usual well-mixed
set of tame liquidy d&b and conrad was exactly like
he's been for years.  enjoyable but exactly what i
expected.

there was no dress code, the club was nice, the sound
& lights were great, the crowd was having it and the
security was forgiving- they confiscated my flyers but
at least they didn't kick me out as 1015 did last time
bukem played.  the drinks were expensive but stiff as
a board.  all in all i had a good time!!!

dave

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR: LTJ Bukem @ Ruby Skye?

Yeah- it's a totally different place on club nights versus special events.
No doubt its a really cool venue, and like others have said, the dress 
code and the crowd really make me ill on "normal" nights- but Blasthaus 
pulls in some good people for shows there- and when you've bought tix 
ahead of time for special events like that, there's no dress code and 
the crowd reflects the performer.


dj m wrote:
> i'm ever amazed how much people on this list like to
> moan on and on about nothing!!!
> 
> i went to the show.  bukem played his usual well-mixed
> set of tame liquidy d&b and conrad was exactly like
> he's been for years.  enjoyable but exactly what i
> expected.
>

> & lights were great, the crowd was having it and the
> security was forgiving- they confiscated my flyers but

> bukem played.  the drinks were expensive but stiff as
> a board.  all in all i had a good time!!!

From sfraves-return-112240-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 28 06:39:44 2004

From: JBlaze112@aol.com

Date: Wed, 28 Apr 2004 02:39:27 EDT
To: SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com, sarilion@sarilion.org, sfraves@hyperreal.org

Subject: RE: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes

--part1_15c.3312722c.2dc0ab9f_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

     I think there is some psychiatric double talk gonig on on this list, of 
the Sean Hannity type... Yes of course rich people pay more taxes, we know 
that, we're not stupid. It works on percentages. But the idea of finding ways to 
tax rich people more, and poor people less, is still a very valid idea. 
Because look, after all the tax's are over... what do you know? Rich people are 
still rich, and poor people are still poor. And although it is harsh for one 
person to have to technically pay "more" than another, it can never be as harsh as 
it is to actually be poor yourself. 
     Think if you were out with your friends and some emergency situation 
happened and you were all stranded somewhere and they each had $5 and you had 
$100. Who would bail everyone out and get a taxi? You would! would you even have 
to think twice about it? Now just try to think of a grander scale and replace 
your friends with the people of the United States... granted, you probably 
don't like everyone in the United States, especially all the poor people, 
especially if you're rich because perhaps they desereve it, perhaps they dug their 
own hole, perhaps they are lazy but... in most circumstances, rich people 
inherite their money, or their money-making-habits from family and/or just knowing 
the "right" people. Not everyone has the same luck. Consequently when taxes 
come around not everyone should have the same luck either.
     And just because my statement may relate to what some people think of as 
"socialism" doesn't make it wrong. It doesn't take implementation of 
"survival of the fittest" in order to encourage people to work hard. I have been known 
to compleately forget to clock in at work and forget to pick up my pay 
checks... while still working much harder than everyone else in my crew. I've been kn
own to go out of my way to help people who would never buy something, even 
when I'm on commision. There are lots of people out there like me who work for a 
sense of responsibility and honor amung the human race. There are people who 
just concentrate on the effeciancy of GETTING THINGS ACTUALLY DONE and 
progressing and evolving in the world. Rather than going through-out thier lives 
conjuring up how much money they can make, and invest and make more money. The 
idea of that seems fictional to me, and yet we all support that? How is it that 
we see capitalism as such a hero and socialism as such a leach? The truth is, 
it is the other way around.
     Now if I were to go to some American Indian reservation... and spend all 
my time picking all the fruit off their trees, then cutting their trees down 
and making stuff out of the wood, and working my butt off day in and day out, 
ravaging their land and putting it in my little storage bin, while they were 
all out being lazy playing Indian ball and what not, enjoying life... And then 
one day when they got hungry and needed things I said "HEY you all are lazy 
bastards that play Indian ball all day, I've been working my butt off reaping 
all of your resources and putting them in my little storrage bin! You all have 
to BUY them from me now!" What would I be? That's right I'd be a Capitalist. A 
Capitalist in not your real friend, but just someone who uses you for what 
you're worth untill you fall... and they'll be right there to pick you up, for 
the right price that is. They basically own you because after a certain gap is 
reached you'll never be able to compete with them. (now am I gonna get stoned 
for this or is there anyone sensible enough to agree??) - jaze
                                                                              
           

--part1_15c.3312722c.2dc0ab9f_boundary--

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Inner Child Keeps Smiling

------=_NextPart_000_0029_01C42CAE.C1964940
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hello to All on the List,
Today I had the old song by Qkumba Zoo going through my head, "The Child =
Inside" (circa 1996), and it made me wonder about life in general.

Do we, as ravers, have a particular "inner child" or hidden spirit of =
dancing that others do not understand?

A few years ago, my Dad actually told some other people close to me that =
I was like a child in some ways, something that they never forget to =
remind me about!

But the funny thing is, I LIKE being a child inside. I think it keeps me =
immune from the modern-day ailments like depression, anxiety, and drug =
abuse. It also makes me smile, something my grandmother always =
appreciates, even today (she misses me in Louisiana, her home state).

Grandma reminded me one day that I used to "lay hands" on her, and pray =
for God to make her feel better.=20

I don't pray much anymore, but I still smile, especially when dancing, =
or when I see the bright eyes of a young innocent child.

Sincerely,
Greg Van Pelt




------=_NextPart_000_0029_01C42CAE.C1964940--

Good selections for such a cheap price. I just won a lot of like 10 records 
off of eBay for around $20. The guy lives here in the bay area, and I'm 
meeting him to get the vinyl and avoid shipping charges. There were two 
records in the lot that alone were worth the $20 I paid - the best being 
Deepcuts Vol.2 by Scam. If y'all haven't heard Scam yet - he/she/they 
(whoever it is) is badass funky/nuskool breaks. One of the tracks has this 
Ska kinda feel to it, which would normally make me cringe - but they manage 
to make it work to maximum funkitude. That was a huge score for me.

>From: John B. <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
>To: "Gavin Varitech" <nesound@hotmail.com>
>CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR: LTJ Bukem @ Ruby Skye?
>Date: Tue, 27 Apr 2004 20:05:11 -0700
>
>I wouldn't go so far as to say that I hate it.  I've never actually  made 
>it past the door.... only even tried that one time actually.
>
>I choose not to go, though, because for a place that books all kind of  DJs 
>who play *dance* music, they have an incredibly bass-ackwards dress  code 
>that makes it impossible to go there in anything that would be  comfortable 
>to DANCE in!  What's worse than the dress code, though, is  the fact that 
>it extends to your SHOES as well; which is even worse for  a place that 
>plays DANCE music.
>
>I found all this out the hard way, back when I had my dotcom job, and a  
>bunch of us decided to go to see $some_big_dj_or_another.  Hell, we  KNEW 
>it was a "dress to impress" place, and even dressed fairly clubby  and 
>glossy.  But we were going there for the DJ, not to play the club  game, to 
>"see and be seen", or to "hook up".  So all but one of us got  turned away 
>at the door because we were not wearing  
>hard-ass-uncomfortable-can't-dance-for-shit-in-them-leather shoes.
>
>I'm not totally unwilling to dress up on occasion.  But I wear  
>uncomfortable shoes for no one.
>
>So I don't go to Ruby Skye.
>
>
>cya,
>john
>

The National Electronic Dance Music Conference
And

Remix Magazine

     We are proud to announce Remix Magazine's role as a sponsor for the =
National Electronic Dance Music Conference.=20


***The National Electronic Dance Music Conference***=20

http://www.nedmc.com

***New registration fees online***

Early registration specials are online and available until April 30th.

Regular registration-Reg. $275 Until April 30th- $210
Economy/Student registration-Reg. $150 Until April 30th- $110

8x10 Exhibit booth- Reg. $1500 Until April 30th- $1150
8x20 Exhibit booth- Reg. $2250 Until April 30th- $2000

We have also included new options for those wanting to attend or =
participate in the NEDMC. Check out the website for more info.

  Please visit http://www.nedmc.com/seminars.html for information =
regarding our seminars and panels.

  In Washington D.C. on September 3rd through 6th 2004, the National EDM =
Conference will take place at the Omni Shoreham Hotel. We will be =
utilizing the entire space of the hotel to bring you the best possible =
environment to network with others in the EDM industry. We will be =
hosting all genres, from hip hop to hardcore, from house to industrial. =
As well, we will also be showcasing the newest technologies for the =
coming year and beyond, as well as offering seminars and focus groups to =
help dj's, producers, and gear manufacturer's push the envelope of music =
production and presentation.

  We have chosen D.C. to host this event because it is a central =
location on the east coast, offering easy access from many spots around =
the country, as well as being home to one of the nations largest EDM =
focused communities. We will be working closely with all businesses =
involved to ensure top notch production on all sides for after hours =
events, as well as demonstrations of said products. There will be also =
attendee only events, so be sure to sign up early to gain access to =
these events, held exclusively in the hotel.

  If you are interested in speaking on a panel or having your company =
host a seminar, please email seminars@nedmc.com

  To stay up to date on all the happenings of the NEDMC, including =
seminar information, hotel and registration discounts, and event =
information, please visit http://www.nedmc.com/contact.html

  For further information on either sponsoring, exhibiting, attending, =
or hosting an official event, please email info@nedmc.com , or visit our =
site at http://www.nedmc.com .

  If you would like to help out with the NEDMC, please e-mail =
work@nedmc.com for intern and volunteering opportunites.=20

  For booking consideration, please send all cd's to:=20
NEDMC Booking
4331 Farm House Lane
Farifax, VA 22032


http://www.nedmc.com
The National Electronic Dance Music Conference
P.O. Box 3616
Fairfax, VA 22038
O:703-503-1020
F:703-503-1269
info@nedmc.com

to be removed from this list, please email info@nedmc.com

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 28 Apr 2004 19:10:31.0042 (UTC) FILETIME=[79659620:01C42D54]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Inner Child Keeps Smiling

I think by dancing it helps us recconect to ourselves.  It is a solo 
mission, breathing, sweating, feeling...you start to get into a zone, it 
relaxes us on many levels.   We live in a society where we are programmed to 
focus away, giving lots of attention to jobs, family, friends...obligations 
without being able to recconect.  Reconnecting to your spirit is DIRE! Great 
music, great times and people is great, and it gives us a chance to play, 
which we have not been able to do for so long.  So when your dad tells you 
you are a child, tell him "Thank you!"
=)
Danny
(another child of the universe)



"Øder tis moodle in der noggin tu smacken der ouchey und vinger-slingers ur 
to smacken-backen und fix de morkin, yøobetcha! "
-The Swedish Chef





>From: "Greg Van Pelt" <gregvp@comcast.net>
>To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Inner Child Keeps Smiling
>Date: Tue, 27 Apr 2004 23:24:14 -0700
>
>Hello to All on the List,
>Today I had the old song by Qkumba Zoo going through my head, "The Child 
>Inside" (circa 1996), and it made me wonder about life in general.
>
>Do we, as ravers, have a particular "inner child" or hidden spirit of 
>dancing that others do not understand?
>
>A few years ago, my Dad actually told some other people close to me that I 
>was like a child in some ways, something that they never forget to remind 
>me about!
>
>But the funny thing is, I LIKE being a child inside. I think it keeps me 
>immune from the modern-day ailments like depression, anxiety, and drug 
>abuse. It also makes me smile, something my grandmother always appreciates, 
>even today (she misses me in Louisiana, her home state).
>
>Grandma reminded me one day that I used to "lay hands" on her, and pray for 
>God to make her feel better.
>
>I don't pray much anymore, but I still smile, especially when dancing, or 
>when I see the bright eyes of a young innocent child.
>
>Sincerely,
>Greg Van Pelt
>
>
>

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) "fair share" of taxes

	I don't believe in eternal debt or other forms of the original sin  
doctrine that say people are born guilty, but I certainly agree that  
Indian tribes should be left alone. The problem isn't that they *are*  
allowed to have gambling facilities -- the problem is that the rest of  
us *are not*.

	This is kind of the equivalent of medical marijuana -- everyone should  
be able to use pot, but politically we've had to take it a step at a  
time because of the resistance from the prudes. And since that means  
someone getting it first, I can't think anyone I'd rather it be than  
medical users. I feel the same way about Indians and gaming.

	I just hope that when it comes time to allow non-Indian gaming in  
California and other places, that the tribes don't get greedy and use  
their new financial clout to try to keep a monopoly on it. I know,  
that's probably wishful thinking.

					<<< Starchild >>>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


FRIDAY, April 30th, Club 6
On the Corner Productions & Safe in Sound presents:

SF SESSIONS w/
EAST COAST BOOGIEMEN

Ken Christensen and Juan Zapata have received acclaim across the globe for 
their innovative brand of deep funky house music. Adopting an unusual and 
spectacular four or six turntable/two mixer tag team set-up, they use their 
exceptional musical talent to weave diverging elements into an amazing 
listening experience. Their extraordinary performances showcase their 
wildly unique, multi-layered sets and on-the-spot remixes, while 
maintaining an unyielding energy always leaving the stage with crowds 
begging for more!

Having solidified their permanent standing in the global House scene, the 
duo produce music at an astonishing rate, with over 30 releases on labels: 
Odds and Ends, Aroma, Amenti, Brique Rouge, Lowdown / Doubledown, 
Moonshine, Astralwerks, Deep Funk Records, Dust Traxx and beyond. Securing 
a place in the 2002 URB's Next 100, ECB is scheduled to release their full 
length album on their own label (Odds and Ends Music) in the next year. 
Watch for them in 2004 and beyond!

Along with:
Jonene (stompy)
M3 (green gorrila / fully loaded / velvetshop)
Mike Frugaletti (Good Family Recordings)
Rob Zemo (throwdown / basic)

In the lounge:
Mike Tello (flavor / uniting souls)
Nomandeeq (flavor / uniting souls)
Moses (uniting souls)


PRICE: $10
TIME: 9pm-4am
MUSIC: House
MORE INFO:
<http://www.eastcoastboogiemen.com/>eastcoastboogiemen.com<http://safeinsoundmusic.com> 
safeinsoundmusic.com

"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

	This to me is a big part of what raving is really all about -- 
recapturing the innocence, wonder, and excitement of being a kid. 
Children, toys, cartoons, etc., have been big themes in rave fliers, 
parties, and music, especially early on I think.

On Tuesday, April 27, 2004, at 11:24  PM, Greg Van Pelt wrote:

> Hello to All on the List,
> Today I had the old song by Qkumba Zoo going through my head, "The 
> Child Inside" (circa 1996), and it made me wonder about life in 
> general.
>
> Do we, as ravers, have a particular "inner child" or hidden spirit of 
> dancing that others do not understand?
>
> A few years ago, my Dad actually told some other people close to me 
> that I was like a child in some ways, something that they never forget 
> to remind me about!
>
> But the funny thing is, I LIKE being a child inside. I think it keeps 
> me immune from the modern-day ailments like depression, anxiety, and 
> drug abuse. It also makes me smile, something my grandmother always 
> appreciates, even today (she misses me in Louisiana, her home state).
>
> Grandma reminded me one day that I used to "lay hands" on her, and 
> pray for God to make her feel better.
>
> I don't pray much anymore, but I still smile, especially when dancing, 
> or when I see the bright eyes of a young innocent child.
>
> Sincerely,
> Greg Van Pelt
